PETITION.TITLE: Telstra: Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators, and to the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that:
As members of the Australian community, considering:

PARA.TAB: the strategic important of Telstra in the national economy;
the high levels of foreign ownership in the rest of the telecommunications industry;
the growing importance of communications services to the lives of all Australians;
the threat that privatisation poses to the universal availability of both present and future communications services;

PETITION.PARA: We believe that it is in the national interest for Telstra to be kept in full public ownership.

We therefore call on the Federal Government to abandon its proposal to privatise Telstra, the nation's chief telecommunications provider, and to explore alternative means of funding its environmental policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bourne (from 905 citizens), Senator Carr (from 1,059 citizens), Senator Cooney (from 935 citizens)and Senator Robert Ray (from 1,591 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Triple J
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that the potential funding cuts to Radio Triple J will drastically affect services and public broadcasts to the youth of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to retain the current level of funding for Triple J.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned draws the Senate's attention to our serious concerns at the Government's announced funding cuts to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and in particular the impact these cuts will have on the maintenance of ABC services to regional Australia. We are of the view that the loss of $65 million in funds will decimate the ABC and force it to commercialise by seeking corporate sponsors. This in turn will destroy its independence and quality.
We urge the Senate to reject these funding cuts and place `our ABC' on a financial footing that will ensure its viability and continuance of existing ABC services and programs.

PETITION.TITLE: Ramsar Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia in Geelong requests that the Senate examine the proposal to set aside land currently protected under the Ramsar Treaty in order to provide for a chemical storage facility at Pt Lillias. Further, we request the Senate to examine whether the proposal to set aside an area alternate to the one now nominated by the Ramsar Treaty is in accordance with the requirement of that Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Dental Health Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of Citizens of the Nillumbik Shire and Surrounds draws to the attention of the Senate that the closure of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program will result in considerable pain and suffering to those people who are Health Care Card holders and their dependents.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate restore the Commonwealth Dental Health Program for Health Care Card holders and their dependents in the 1996/97 budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On Monday I asked the Australian Democrats a question in relation to their Internet page and in it indicated that I did not believe we had received any communications that had their source from that Internet page. Perhaps I will make that a bit clearer, Madam President. The Democrats' Internet page indicates in a number of areas that, if you want to send a protest, you should click on a particular word on the screen and the protest will be sent.

SPEECH.PARA: I raised a concern that we had not received the protests and asked whether what the Democrats were in fact doing was using the Internet to improperly collect issue based mailing lists. Having raised that question in the Senate, I took the opportunity of raising the matter with Senator Kernot later that night, because I think privacy principles and the use of the Internet are a genuine matter of concern to everybody. She indicated to me, not in these precise words, that this was not a matter that she had direct knowledge of, but that she would investigate the matter. And she did, promptly.

She sent me a letter yesterday before question time indicating that she believed we had received some messages from an Internet page—if I can be forgiven for being uncharitable, a peculiarly small number of messages. There were other matters raised in relation to concerns over the Democrats' use of their Internet page. I still have those concerns, but this is not the appropriate time to raise them and I will raise them at another time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:

Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to this bill, and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
This bill contains several important measures announced in the 1996 Budget for the social security portfolio.

Madam President, in most cases, single people who share accommodation face lower costs through economies of scale, compared with the costs of living alone. The Government has decided to set a new maximum rate of rent assistance for single people who share accommodation from 1 July 1997. The new maximum rate for single sharers will be two‐thirds of the maximum rate for singles living independently.
However, a number of groups will be exempt from the new rate. These groups comprise the following:
single people with dependent children;
boarders and lodgers;
nursing home residents; and
people who live alone in caravans, mobile homes or vessels.
In certain situations, people who live only with their non‐dependent children will also be excluded.
Madam President, the second measure contained in the bill deals with the treatment of assets held in superannuation and rollover funds.

Before March 1993, compulsorily preserved superannuation and rollover assets were exempt from the social security income and assets tests until age pension age. From March 1993, all superannuation benefits held in superannuation or rollover funds have been exempted from these tests until age pension age. This initiative involved estimated additional outlays of $4.1m in 1992‐93, increasing to $17.1m in 1995‐96.

Given that superannuation savings are generally not subject to compulsory preservation after a person reaches the age of 55 and retires, people in these circumstances (including people who may not wish to retire but who have poor prospects of returning to work) can access their superannuation savings if they choose to do so. Consistent with the treatment of other savings, the Government considers that a person's superannuation savings should be taken into account in working out how much income support can be paid.

Accordingly, from 20 September 1997, the assets test exemption of assets held in superannuation and rollover funds by social security pensioners and allowees under age pension age will be removed for people aged between 55 and age pension age after 39 weeks on income support since turning 55. For income test purposes, affected customers' superannuation and rollover assets will be added to their other financial assets and assessed under extended deeming rules.

The anticipated savings from this measure are much greater than the estimated costs of the 1993 initiative. One reason why the latter estimated costs are significantly smaller is because they reflected only the additional costs of exempting non‐compulsorily preserved superannuation and rollover assets from the social security assets and income tests until age pension age. However, a significant reason for the difference is because of the extent to which customers who are effectively retired, invested in superannuation and rollover funds as a means of avoiding the operation of the assets and income tests.

Neither the assets nor income test treatment of annuities and pensions, including allocated annuities and pensions, will change. These products will continue to be assessed under existing rules. This situation is, however, presently under review.

Madam President, the Government is committed to ensuring that social security customers receive their rightful entitlement. At the same time, the Government considers that the Australian taxpayer has a right to expect that the Government will do all it can to minimise the scope for overpayments.

Overpayments often arise during holiday periods such as Easter when social security allowance payments are programmed in advance to be paid automatically on predetermined days that are earlier than usual if the customer's normal payday falls on a holiday. This can result in overpayments for the holiday period, some of which are not recoverable.

To that end, the third measure contained in the bill provides for a modified application form for certain social security and youth training allowances to be submitted before payment. The modified form will require a declaration of any changes anticipated for the remainder of the payment period. If any overpayments arise for the payment period, they will be recoverable.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in 1997, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the Chair of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances (Senator O'Chee), I present a position paper by the Working Party of Representatives of Scrutiny of Legislation Committees throughout Australia, entitled Scrutiny of national schemes of legislation .

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The constitutional framework within which a nation goes forward into the future is crucial to its welfare. Australia's constitutional development is always in process, perhaps in most dramatic form through the decisions of the High Court. It is essential that the constitutional development of the nation is anticipated by the various parliaments around Australia.

One of the developments that has been going on for some time is the growth of national schemes of legislation. It is a process that will become more and more pronounced as time goes by. National schemes of legislation are schemes like the Corporations Law which guides the way our companies and securities are controlled throughout Australia. Legislation with respect to these schemes is passed in the various states and territories and at the Commonwealth level. Such legislation guides the way we go about our corporate business.

Another uniform scheme is the censorship scheme which controls the censorship of various material in Australia. Another scheme is the consumer credit code. That is an interesting scheme in the sense that the Commonwealth is not part of it but the states and territories are. This is an illustration of the growth of common schemes throughout this nation. They can only become common legislative schemes when they are agreed to by the governments of various states and territories or the Commonwealth.

Ministers or heads of state come together at SCAG, the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General, or COAG, the Council of Australian Governments, and agree upon a common legislative scheme that is for the good of Australia. That is a good process. We do not cavil with that. The effect is that once ministers gather around and come to an agreement on a common piece of legislation it is then a problem whether the parliament can have a sufficient say in the standard and status of that legislation and the way that legislation has been brought forward. The particular concern that the scrutiny committees have is that there might be in that legislation, innocently of course, provisions which take away from human rights and human liberties.

There is no effective way for the various parliaments around Australia to look at the common legislation which has been agreed to by the ministers. The ministers do not want what has been agreed to unravelled. If it is unravelled months and perhaps years of work will be lost. They want the legislation to stay as it is. They are concerned that parliament would undo the bill before it becomes an act. The various scrutiny committees around Australia have attempted to develop a scheme whereby members of parliament can have an effective say in the making of this common legislation or, once it is made, to have an effective say in how it goes through parliament in the same way they would if legislation discrete to their individual parliaments was processed.

We have before us today a discussion paper. It is hoped that all parliamentarians will read it. It is hoped that after they read it they will make suggestions to the committee about how this problem may be solved—that is, the problem of ensuring parliamentarians have an effective say in the making of national legislative schemes in a way that, in the opinion of ministers, does not violate the essence of the agreement that they have reached. It is an important matter. As a committee we hope that some productive ideas are advanced.

I would like to mention the people who have had something to do with the production of this important report at some time. This report will be seen Australia wide. These people have done outstanding work. I will start by noting and praising the work done by the secretary of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, Mr Peter Crawford. It is good to see him in the chamber. He was assisted and guided by Professor Jim Davis from the Australian National University and Mrs Margaret Lindeman who works for the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

I present this report jointly with Senator O'Chee. He would no doubt want to mention the people who helped him. The secretary of Senator O'Chee's committee, David Creed, Professor Douglas Whalan from the Australian National University and Janice Paull from the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances have all done great work.

Others who have been involved with this report are Ms Louisa Pink from the Queensland Scrutiny of Legislation Committee and her assistant Lisa Shuttleworth, Tom Duncan from the Scrutiny of Bills and Subordinate Legislation Committee in the ACT—Madam President, you would be pleased to hear him mentioned because he comes from the place that you represent so well—Mr Greg Hogg from the Regulations Review Committee of New South Wales and Ms Helen Mason and Ms Tanya Coleman from the Scrutiny of Acts and Regulations Committee of Victoria, my home state. Both Ms Mason and Ms Coleman have done outstanding work in this area.

I would also like to mention Mr David Pegram from the Legislative Review Committee in South Australia, Ms Wendy Peddle from the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Subordinate Legislation in Tasmania, Mr Stuart Kay and Ms Jan Paniperis from the Joint Standing Committee on Delegated Legislation in Western Australia, Ms Melina Newnan and Mr Keith Kendrick from the Standing Committee on Uniform Legislation and Intergovernmental Agreements in Western Australia, and Ms Helen Allmich from the Subordinate Legislation and Tabled Papers Committee from the Northern Territory.

It can be seen that these people, from all round Australia, have done quite magnificent work in getting this report together. I think they have made a great contribution to the constitutional development of Australia.

I also mention Senator Colston and Senator Troeth, who have been chairs of my committee and who have done work in this area. The following people are no longer there but they ought be remembered: Mr Victor Perton—an outstanding figure in this area—in Victoria; Mr Jon Sullivan in Queensland; Mr Adrian Cruickshank in New South Wales; and Mr Tony Benneworth in Tasmania.

I also mention the present chairs of these committees: Rosemary Follett, from your territory, Madam President; Mr Doug Shedden from New South Wales; Mr Rick Setter from the Northern Territory; Mr Tony Elliott from Queensland; Mr Robert Lawson from South Australia; Mr John Loone from Tasmania; Mr Peter Ryan from Victoria; Mr Bruce Donaldson from Western Australia; and, of course, Mr Phillip Pendal from Western Australia, who has been a great driving force behind this scheme. All these people are people who ought be put on the record as contributing to a very important document. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I talked about the particular impact that the deregulation of the labour market would have on women and that proposed deregulation, as indicated in the bill, would disproportionately affect women. I was backed up in my comments by a book that had been prepared which looked specifically at this issue. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Because women have generally relied more heavily on legislation to protect them from the adverse effects of the market, labour market regulations have been necessary to remedy market failures and distortions which are likely to affect women more than men.

Removal of such regulations, especially those dealing with labour market discrimination, could leave women exposed to important disadvantages. They would be subject to unequal hiring and promotion standards, unequal opportunities for training and retraining, unequal opportunity for occupational mobility, unequal pay for equal work and/or unequal likelihood of being retrenched.

The danger is that deregulation sanctions and encourages bad practices. The weakening of the protective framework and institutional safeguards may very well open the floodgates for more serious exploitation with no guarantee that standards will be reinstated by employers of their own accord even in the long term.

I think that quote is very relevant to this debate. I remind honourable senators that this comes against the background that I mentioned yesterday of John Bradford, a member of the coalition, calling for the abolition of the Affirmative Action Agency, not to mention the ministry for the status of women.

I think that all the gains that have been made and the fact that you, Madam President, now preside over this chamber are very much a reflection of the change of attitudes in the community—a change of practice. But not all women have yet benefited from these changes of attitudes and changes of practices. We cannot assume that just because there have been so many changes—with women participating much more in the workplace, being involved in non‐traditional areas of the workplace—it is a trend that will continue unless there are protective mechanisms in place. Those protective mechanisms include the Affirmative Action Agency and, certainly, the Industrial Relations Commission maintaining its watching brief over award conditions.

In the time remaining, I would like to address a particularly good submission by the National Pay Equity Coalition to a Senate committee. Not only did it have an excellent submission—I will come to the executive summary in a moment—but I will later seek leave to incorporate or table its bibliography, because it contains 37 articles and reports, seven wage cases and five Australian Bureau of Statistics publications. It is a very useful reference.The National Pay Equity Coalition's submission raises serious concerns about the likely impact of the proposed new industrial relations bill on women workers.

The book draws on a wealth of research—which is why I will seek leave to incorporate the bibliography—which shows that, the more deregulated the labour market, the more women are disadvantaged. In the last decade there has been a significant shift in the industrial relations system from national wage cases and conditions regulated by awards to one where more and more decisions affecting people's working lives are determined by their bargaining power at workplace level. The proposed system, the National Pay Equity Coalition argues, is not deregulation but reregulation, and reregulation in the interests of employers. It is cloaked in rhetoric about choice and freedom for women but under the proposed bill women will be less able to access their rights, less able to protect their existing entitlements and less able to improve their labour market position.

The National Pay Equity Coalition, after it had participated in its presentation to the Senate committee and had had some consultations with minister Peter Reith, wrote again to me and, I am sure, to other senators. It made the point that, notwithstanding some of the clarifications the minister had made, it still remained concerned about these issues:
We believe that the legislation will widen the pay equity gap.

At present the ratio of women's earnings to men's earnings, the hourly rate, stands at 83.3 per cent. In spite of this evidence of structural inequality in the work force, the draft legislation substantially reduces the pay equity provisions of the Industrial Relations Act of 1988 by restricting provisions to equal pay rather than equal remuneration. This means that the over-award rates and conditions are not subject to equal pay provisions. That has not been emphasised enough in debate.

I see that my colleague Senator Rosemary Crowley has just come into the chamber. I am sure she will be pursuing this issue because, although many honourable senators on this side of the chamber have raised it, it has not been an issue that the government has wanted to debate publicly.

There is no evidence to suggest that a deregulated industrial relations system will contribute to improving the labour market position of women. To the contrary—both domestic and overseas research proves that a substantial loss of pay equity occurs with a movement to enterprise and individualised bargaining systems. On this point it is important to note that the highest pay equity ratio achieved by women in Australia, 84.6 per cent, was prior to the onset of enterprise bargaining.

The patterns of enterprise bargaining that have taken place reveal that a significant number of agreements exclude women and that women are more likely than men to be covered by agreements that provided for an increase in working hours. Despite this evidence, the legislation does not provide for scrutiny of the proposed Australian workplace agreements through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to ensure that women are not disadvantaged in the process.

There is substantial evidence to prove that women will be disadvantaged by the restriction on the ambit of awards. At present the minimum requirements for awards excluded a number of areas—I detailed them earlier in my speech—which have a key impact on working women.

The changes proposed by the government will have a serious effect on all workers, but particularly on women workers. I reiterate them: weakening the power of the Industrial Relations Commission to set employment conditions and to vet workplace agreements, both of which changes seriously limit the commission's capacity to protect those most in need and particularly women; and reducing the coverage of awards to a bare minimum of conditions, which means that women will lose important protections relating to hours of work, including the operation of part-time work, meal and clothing provisions, sexual harassment and equal opportunity procedures and conditions above the standards such as paid maternity leave.

The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Jocelyn Newman, has been outspoken in a number of areas of importance to women, and I commend her for that, but has not been vocal on this issue. I wonder to what extent she was consulted. Finally, removing the commission's powers to deal with discriminatory over-award payments, which remain a key component in women's battle to achieve equal pay in practice, will put the onus on individual workers to make complaints about discriminatory or otherwise unlawful agreements. That puts the worker in the position of having to prove that discrimination and prove that disadvantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, I am not listed to speak at this time. Senator Reynolds said that she felt sure that I would want to reiterate all that she said, and indeed I do. I thank her for her contribution to this debate. The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 is, as the government has made clear, an absolutely pivotal part of its policies. That is why the Labor opposition is so strenuous in fighting it.

BREAK.PARA: This pivotal legislation makes clear the government's view about a whole lot of things—in particular, their view of how the world ought to be. They have introduced into this community a budget that is without any doubt a Thatcher‐Tory budget. The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is exactly in sync with that. It is legislation that is ideologically driven. It is a bill designed to reduce the power and the rights of workers. It fits absolutely with the changes in the budget that do away with many services and hard won gains for many people in the community.

Prime Minister Howard promised that he would have a country that will be comfortable and relaxed. Under this bill, most workers would certainly cease to be relaxed, and many of them would be much less comfortable, even in terms of `comfortable' meaning `reasonably paid'.

The other important thing about this piece of legislation is that it will not create one new job. It will do nothing to help the unemployed, and this government does not put a figure on the number of unemployed. It cannot do that because it has policies that have already seen an increase in the number of unemployed, such as direct cutbacks in the Public Service, but also policies that are quite clearly intent on seeing the unemployed figures rise—hence no commitment to any estimate of getting the numbers down. At least Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, in a moment of forgetful honesty, said that if they do not get the figures down they will not be re‐elected. But even she baulked at putting a figure on it.

This government's Tory‐Thatcher budget has hung the unemployed out to dry. I know that when I once before made that comment in debate in this place Senator Newman was up on her feet protesting that that was not the truth. That just meant that it stung her. It stung her because it is true. The unemployed have been forgotten. Their numbers will only increase under this government and its policies, and this piece of legislation will ensure that their lot is even worse: there will be not one new job created by this piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—My colleague Senator Hogg assists me here by reiterating that that is absolutely the case. The unemployed are ignored and forgotten. This piece of so‐called primacy legislation, pivotal legislation, will do nothing to help the unemployed. It will not create one job.

BREAK.PARA: The legislation has a goal of cooperative workplace relations. That is the language, and yet what it will be doing is building on and designing secret agreements between employer and employee. You will not know what your workmate is getting, and that is not good for cooperative workplace arrangements.

It will do away with many of the things that the workers and the union movement have fought for for 100 years. It will remove equal pay provisions and the award protection for part‐time and casual workers, most of whom are women. Indeed, I am very pleased to follow my colleague Senator Reynolds because this legislation is very damaging to women workers in particular. When you put that with this government's policies of increasing the costs of child care, despite earnest promises that they would not, and if you put it with their policies to have a modest tax benefit for families where one spouse is at home—usually the woman—you see a package of policy, secret not overt, in which this government would like to see women out of the work force and back into the home.

I noted over the weekend that there was an article by Geoffrey Blainey saying that the decade of the century was the decade of the 40s. Certainly, if you have to have a decade that encompasses the Second World War, it is not without significance. As I read it, one of the points that Professor Blainey wanted to make about the significance of the 1940s—and maybe the article did not do full justice to him—was that, despite all those men who returned to Australia, all those people out of the forces coming back to Australia, some hundreds of thousands, there was no loss of employment; they were just absorbed into the work force and `Wasn't that fantastic!'

Yes, indeed, Professor Blainey, but did you count what happened to the women? The reason that so many men went into the work force was because so many women came out of it, and I am surprised that a historian of Professor Blainey's standing did not actually make that point. How do you measure unemployment? How do you measure full employment if you are not talking about labour force participation and if you are not talking about the huge contribution of women to the work force in this country during the war—if you are not talking about large numbers of the jobs being taken by men after the women were removed back to the home? That is what is on the agenda again.

Sometimes we talk about Mr Howard taking us back to the 1960s. Personally, I think we should go back to the 1950s and, after reading that article by Professor Blainey, I believe that, no, it is right back to the 1940s. `A woman's place is in the home' is certainly the view of a large number of the government, particularly those in the Lyons Forum. And we were assisted in our thinking about what they have to say by the Queensland member, Mr Bradford, who has come out in the press over the weekend saying that we should abolish the Affirmative Action Agency and the Office of the Status of Women because women are too advantaged in this country and men are disadvantaged. There is another example of very conservative thinking hauling us back into the past, and here is this piece of legislation that is making its contribution to exactly that.

This government also boasts the importance of so many women being elected to parliament in the coalition ranks, and I am on the record as saying, `Well done.' I have been one of those people who congratulate women being successful in parliament, but I certainly make a clear distinction between a Labor woman and a Liberal woman and Labor policies and Liberal policies—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a big difference.
—Because the Liberal women that you are so boastful about over there, Senator Minchin, are very quiet on this issue.
—You are tempting me to have a go.

—Here they are—and I will come to what Senator Patterson had to say in a minute—all these women, voting to disadvantage women. They will be in here in the next little while voting to see the costs of child care increase. How are they going to say to the women in their electorates that that is a good thing for women? Already the community is outraged about the increased costs of child care and the costs are only pre‐figured at this stage. Not one, not two but three major promises in child care have been broken just like that—broken without a flick.

BREAK.PARA: What is the government going to do? Increase the costs of child care. And what is that going to do? Make it so much harder for women to go to work, to study, to train, to re‐enter the work force. And who is voting for it? All the women on the coalition benches, who do not have the strength or the numbers to persuade their Liberal colleagues that that is not good for women.

We know there are a few whispers of division over there. If it is not from the Lyons Forum it could be from the John Stuart Mill group—not a faction, you understand, but just a different way of thinking about the world. It must be fun when you have your little party room brawls.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing like yours.

—No, absolutely not. Ours are factionalised, civilised and proper. We accommodated it years ago. What is more, Senator Minchin, we put policies for women on the political agenda. You have succeeded, and we congratulate you for some of your successes, but we do not congratulate you for getting women into parliament to vote down the achievements for women. That is what you are doing. Just you wait until the people in the community say to coalition women members, `Why are you voting to make child care cost more? Why are you voting, under this piece of legislation, to do away with award protection for part-time and casual workers? Why are you voting to take away the equal pay commitment?' It has taken 100 years of union movement graft, persuasion and argument to finally get an equal pay commitment and you lot over there have deleted it. Go out and tell that to the women of Australia, and tell them that all the women on the government bench are doing it. Ha! That is what I say—ha!
—Say it again.

—I can't because Hansard can't spell it three times in a row, Senator. They can, but I will not ask them to. You actually boast about your increased representation of women. As I say, all you are doing is asking those women to—and seeing them—vote for the abolition of gains for women.

BREAK.PARA: There are a couple of points that I want to pick up from earlier contributions. I had the opportunity of listening to Senator Patterson speaking in this debate. I suppose it is problematic that she is now doing chair duty and, therefore, unable to respond at this time. It is not for that reason that I want to draw attention to Senator Patterson's comments.

First of all, Senator Patterson talked about the problems of closed shops—that if you are not in a union you do not get a job. Well, Senator Patterson, I am sure that there are situations like that in Australia, but come with me to the small businesses and the big businesses around Australia that are closed shops to anyone who smells of a union. How dare you suggest that there is only fault in one direction. There are thousands of people who cannot get near employment if they have a union card. There are closed shops absolutely preventing and proscribing anybody from a union—even a worker who is a member of a union—from coming into that workplace let alone giving the opportunity for union representatives to visit those workers. I note that a lot of the gains—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley, I would prefer it if you do not use the word `you'. Could you use `Senator Patterson' and direct it through the chair. If I have to be impartial you can be too.

—I thank you for this assistance, Madam Acting Deputy President, who is, for the record, Senator Patterson. You are quite right. Every time it says `you' the record should note that it should be `Senator Patterson'—who proposed this quite curious argument that there are closed shops, that this is a bad thing and that the coalition's industrial relations legislation change, the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, is somehow going to free up workplaces from being closed shops. If you can give us a guarantee that the closed shops that will not let a non-unionised person in will be equally matched by closed shops that will not let anybody who has a union card in, that might be a gain. But we know you do not mean that.

BREAK.PARA: The next point that Senator Patterson made in her contribution was to use that very disappointing argument: nobody in the Labor Party has ever been in a small business; therefore, they cannot talk about it because they do not know what they are talking about. As a doctor, I have often thought that argument would mean that I could never talk about the pain of a broken leg, having not had one myself. It is a nonsense argument and Senator Patterson knows that.

She went on to illustrate the point by saying that nobody on the Labor side should talk about small business because none of them is in them and they do not know what they are talking about. She then went on to talk at great length about the evils of unions, about which she knows nothing, of which she has never been a member and about which she has, in the past, made points about how she would not be a unionist. If Senator Patterson wants to argue that we cannot talk about small businesses because none of us has experienced them—and I would not test the facts of that statement—then strictly, according to her own logic, she cannot talk about unions because she has no knowledge of them.

Senator Patterson can make her points about unions and, equally, the Labor Party can make its points about small business. What the Labor Party did with its previous legislation was to move towards enterprise agreements and freeing up the labour market, freeing up opportunities in the workplace and encouraging small business as well as large business. I note, for the record, that it was Senator Schacht, as minister responsible for small business, who proposed and introduced legislation dealing with unconscionable conduct. The coalition failed to address it, even though that would have been of great benefit to small business. It depends on the size of the small business—and, having looked at all your share dealings over the last day or so, it seems that many of you travel very closely with very large business indeed. That is a spurious argument of Senator Patterson and I sincerely hope she does not use it again.

The next person I want to take issue with is Senator Troeth who actually argued that what we were suggesting in debate was that women would be incapable of making or negotiating an agreement for themselves. That is about as stupid a remark as it is offensive from Senator Troeth. Women are very capable, in certain circumstances, of negotiating agreements. It was Senator Troeth and her colleagues on the other side who regularly got stuck into the Labor government, complaining that women would be disadvantaged in all sorts of situations if they had to, for example, return to the work force after some years out of the work force.

Those opposite also seem to contradict themselves entirely if you consider the case of a 16-, 17- or 18-year-old young woman going for her first employment after leaving school. What is her capacity to satisfactorily and on her own negotiate an agreement when she no longer has the protection of an award? Where does she go? Does she ring up somebody and say, `I'm going off for my first job interview; I need to know the legislative requirements and the terms of the possible agreement that I can negotiate?' Most young people going for work are desperate for a job, will settle for what is offered to them and will certainly not be in a position to bargain on their own behalf. You know and have argued in this place, as I have, the difficulties facing women returning to the work force after years out of it. They are people who are not fully confident and not people who, with all the assurance, can go in and negotiate a fair agreement for themselves.

Senator Reynolds has spelt out how bad this legislation is over a variety of areas, but in particular it is very tough on women. It removes the equal pay provisions and it will remove the award protection for part‐time and casual workers, most of whom are women. How can you argue that this legislation will advantage women?

Already, thousands of women in the community know that what you say is not what you mean. The legislation's attack on women and the increased cost of child care—to say nothing of any other changes—are two changes alone that send the message to women that they would be better off going home. That is what the coalition Howard government wants.

Women in the community have said, `We have employment, we have job opportunities, we like our part‐time work, we like mixing work and family responsibilities, we like being professional women, we like being horse trainers, we like being jockeys, we like doing all of those things. We want the services of child care to support us and, no, we do not want legislation that weakens our hand, that removes our equal pay, that disadvantages us and loses us the benefits we have been trying to win over years and years of argument.' In particular, they do not want less money.

`No worker will be worse off,' Mr Howard promised. Mr Howard is delivering another broken promise. It is rhubarb, and everybody will know that, because not only will people have lost conditions and protections, they will not get so much money. Other speakers in this debate have spelt out particular examples. The Victorian nurses are one case in point. Quite clearly, they have less money and are worse off.

I want to finish by saying that it has taken over 100 years of fighting to get this far, and to see that wiped out by this piece of legislation would be a tragedy. In my state of South Australia, in 1890, the first working women's union was formed. In 1891 the Liquor Trades Union was formed, as were a number of other unions. In my state in 1894 the women won the right to vote and stand for parliament.

The Women's Christian Temperance Union and the Women's Suffrage Movement were both very political organisations, not the bunch of wowsers that they have been labelled since. They were arguing for equal pay, a fair day's pay for a fair day's work and safety in the workplace. They were asking for something more than sixpence for a shirt manufactured by piecework. They were arguing for better health conditions and educational opportunities for their children, the same sorts of things that 100 years on we have to argue for again—protection and rights for workers, protection and rights for women.

In South Australia we are revisiting that fight a whole century on. If anyone is interested, go and look at the debates and understand that what I have said is exactly true—100 years ago women were arguing and fighting for wage justice, wage protection and decent employment. This legislation, if it passes, will make all those battles start again—wage justice for women, safety in the workplace, protection of awards—for all the conditions and terms that women have struggled to get.
In particular, this legislation damages women. It does not give them protection, and the women on the other side should be voting against it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I too rise to oppose the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. I do so as a senator who has had a lifetime's experience in industrial relations, and as a senator who, for three years, was a minister for industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill should be defeated because it breaches a rock‐solid guarantee by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that nobody will be worse off. It should be defeated because it opens the door to cutting youth wages and introducing a $3 per hour youth wage. It should be defeated because it removes the fairness that is entrenched in the existing industrial relations system. It should be defeated because it does not recognise the legitimacy and desirability of employees organising and bargaining collectively.

BREAK.PARA: It should be defeated because it proceeds from a fundamentally flawed assumption that the parties to the employment relationship have equal bargaining power. It should be defeated because it severely restricts the central role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the industrial relations system. It should also be defeated because it undermines the award system as the dynamic framework for the protection and advancement of wages and conditions.

It should be defeated because it removes workplace and enterprise bargaining from the protection of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Further, it should be defeated because it will aggravate problems of inequality for women, young people and those most vulnerable in the labour market. It should be defeated because it fails to provide a core framework for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes.

It should be defeated because it emphasises the punishment of industrial action rather than its resolution. And it should be defeated because it fails to ensure that Australia's labour standards meet those of our international obligations. For those reasons, this bill should be defeated. It should not be withdrawn and rewritten so much as simply withdrawn.

The outcry against this legislation is in itself enough to condemn it. Legislation that promises to promote industrial harmony but which attracts such division in society obviously cannot succeed in its goal. Therefore, on its immediate face it is plainly legislation which is provocative, divisive, bringing a lack of harmony and cooperation, and reintroducing confrontation into the Australian workplace.

That is an example of what is happening now. If this bill were to pass into law, that is what would happen in practice. That is not in Australia's interest. There has to be a way of bringing the parties back together and having a more common view, a greater consensus about the way forward in industrial relations, than this legislation provides.

One of my greatest problems with this bill is the language used to sell it and the language used to explain it. That language is distorted. That language does not corroborate the true meaning of English. It is used to allay worry. It is used to gull the unwary. It is used to confuse the ignorant. And it is used to reassure the apathetic.

The language used to sell this bill is almost as evil as some of the clauses in this legislation. That is the immediate problem that the electors of Australia have in trying to work out the truth here. If they believe the language used to flog this legislation in the community, they will be absolutely misguided as to what this legislation does.

I just think there is a real case for some truth in advertising or truth in politics about what really is at play rather than what people claim to be at play. This bill is predicated on a number of principles. They are that it will uphold the rights of individuals, that it will encourage greater productivity, that it will streamline dispute settlement and that it will be in the national good. Those who wrought this legislation and explain it use those principles and invoke the majesty of those ideals as their defence. The trouble is it does not deliver on any of them and while this bill is called reform one could hardly call something reform when it makes the situation worse. While it is continually bruited abroad as reform, people think it may have elements of good.

I wish I could find some elements of good so I could balance my remarks from a considered point of view and say, `On one hand there are all these bad things but there are some elements of good.' That would be a reasonable position to take. I cannot find those elements of good in this legislation to try to find a balanced position. I am therefore put in a position of having no alternative but to reject the legislation. The truth of this legislation does not fit the facts and so those who have promoted it have decided that the facts are expendable.

Let me go to the details so I do not just say that as rhetoric. It is said that this bill will introduce greater wage flexibility. In fact, that is true. Greater wage flexibility will be introduced by this bill, but it will be flexibility for wages to fall, not rise. There might be occasions on which some wages for workers in very strong bargaining positions, in key positions of the production process, are able to use their bargaining power to lift wages. But for the vast majority of Australians, this bill means that the flexibility that is bruited abroad and claimed as a key feature of this bill is the flexibility for wage cuts, not wage increases or greater recognition of productivity.

It is said that this bill will introduce greater choice for individuals and, therefore, on the basis of freedom of choice this bill should pass. That choice takes the form that you can choose an award or a contract or an individual contract. The fact is that those words are meaningless and superficial. They are used because they have an appeal and seemingly embody a good ideal. But the truth is that you cannot consider choice without considering the bargaining strengths of the participants in the process.

Last week we saw a key example of what bargaining strength looks like. We saw an advertisement for 40 apprentices in Newcastle—and 1,900 people applied for those jobs. For the individual choice argument to hold, any one of those 1,900 people who are trying to obtain employment as an apprentice has to be assumed to have equal bargaining power with the employer who will engage them. They can then stand up for their rights and demand higher wages if they believe their productivity and contribution to the workplace justify it.

Can anyone seriously comprehend that any of those young people seeking the job of an apprentice—the 1,900 of them—has an equal bargaining position with their employer in those circumstances? That is an extraordinary proposition yet we are told that this is a freedom of choice. The assumption is, therefore, that all of those 1,900 young people are free to make a choice. In reality the free choice they are entitled to make in these circumstances—the only one they have open to them—is a choice of accepting what is offered or accepting unemployment; and that is no choice at all. When we hear those words `greater freedom of choice' one has to bear that in mind.

We also know that not all employers are going to be unscrupulous. There are many employers in this country who are committed to achieving a good outcome for their workers. The problem for those employers is that they are undermined by this bill too, because if they are in competition with employers who are unscrupulous and who will drive down wages and exploit workers, and produce a product or a service at the end of the day because of that exploitation, which is cheaper than the employers who want to do the right thing by their work force, the good employers go out of business and the bad employers succeed. They succeed because they have exploited their workers and cut their wages. They have reduced their costs and made a bigger profit; and they have driven their competition off the block. When one talks about flexibility and greater choice one has to bear that in mind.

We are told that this bill will ensure that third parties do not interfere in the bargaining process. The third party, unspoken but malevolently referred to here, is of course a union. A union exists to protect and represent the interests of its members and not to do it individually so much as as a collective. If that body is unable to speak in this bargaining process, the bargaining power of which I spoke a moment ago is unequal. If all of those 1,900 apprentices who applied for the 40 positions in Newcastle last week were represented by a common bargaining agent, namely their union, and it could negotiate a reasonable wage all of them would be competing equally for those 40 positions, knowing that the wages and working conditions were not a factor.

If you remove that union from the equation, those people are competing on their merit as potential employees as well as bargaining away their rights and reducing their cost. That is a key case of exploitation. So when we hear this argument about third parties not interfering, that means we are shifting the bargaining strengths away from the two parties being in balance to one in which one party is predominant and the other is open to exploitation. Workers in those situations have limited choices.

It is said of this legislation that it will allow unions to compete for members—but compete with whom? It will mean competing with their employers as this legislation is set out because if it is true—as it is—that the clarion cry of unions is `Unity is strength; together we can bargain' then the clarion cry for unscrupulous employers is `Divide and conquer.' That means that the so‐called competition for members, which sounds on the face of it to be a reasonable thing to do, means that you undermine the strength of unions by dividing and conquering them, and by separating out the members individually and dealing with them away from the collective and away from their common good. Thus, you again succeed in the goal of reducing wages.

It is said of this bill that Australia will become a more productive nation and will focus on productivity, and that that will be a good thing. It is a good thing to focus on productivity. Historically, in labour productivity and capital productivity, this nation enjoyed record rates of productivity growth under the previous government. By international comparisons within its peer group economies of the OECD, Australia's productivity growth has been growing much faster than that of many other countries. So what is the problem? The problem is that this is claimed to be an increase in productivity by making people work harder—not by making people work smarter, not by being better trained and skilled and thus better able to work the complex and sophisticated plant and equipment to deliver high quality services, but, rather, by working faster and harder as in the concept of the old days of the industrial revolution. That is stupid.

The psychology of this bill is, in fact, against greater productivity. To achieve greater productivity these days, it does not matter whether individuals work harder. That is determined by the speed of the production line. It means that if we are going to work smarter as a country, manufacture high quality, sophisticated consumer products and deliver high quality, sophisticated services, the emphasis must be on training in the use of the plant and equipment to produce more per head through sophisticated technology than individuals can possibly achieve.

It is said of this bill that the Industrial Relations Commission continues. It does in name only, not in fact. The Industrial Relations Commission that was given birth in Australia over 100 years ago by the troubles of the 1890s is an industrial relations commission that we will not recognise in future if this legislation proceeds. That Industrial Relations Commission was built on three basic precepts which have endured and stood the test of time. Its determinations are based on the principles of justice, equity and the substantial merits of the case.

The argument here is that it does not matter how poor or lacking in strength you are; if there is a process of arbitration, the merit of your case and your claim can be determined. The rich and powerful are equal to one opportunity to put their case on merit and the poor and weak are equal to one opportunity to put their case on merit; and an experienced arbitrator, used to the practical way of life, decides. Essentially, that is the theory of arbitration as we know it.

This system and the so‐called system that will continue arbitration will remove the powers of that umpire, take away their whistle, restrict them to a narrow area of law and prevent them from determining issues that affect the working lives of men and women and employers and companies in this country across the board. That will mean a limitation of power. The Industrial Relations Commission as we know it will not continue.

It is said of this bill that no worker will be worse off. We know that young workers will be worse off. We know that women workers will be worse off. We know that workers in positions of weak bargaining power will be worse off. Before this election, the Prime Minister said that no worker would be worse off. That was obviously not a core promise; it has been devalued. We already know that workers will be worse off. To see that workers are genuinely worse off, one only has to look at the comparisons of the state jurisdictions in Australia where look‐alike legislation has been passed and is now applied

I have done a quick survey of some of the more outrageous claims of what this legislation is about. When one applies the searchlight of practical reality, they are revealed as empty, hollow, misleading and argumentative in the sense that they are trying to con people and not explain to people what the legislation is about.

I said that in the 1890s Australia went through an upheaval in its industrial relations system. It did. The outcry that rang across the nation then was `There must be a better way. We can't be continually racked with the major disputes that go on endlessly with no possibility of resolution and with the bitterness of their aftermath that endures endlessly. We can't do that.' Australia then created the system of arbitration. That has evolved over time. It is predictable, understandable and is what Australians know as the way to industrial justice. That is what we are used to. It is a system that works. The old cry `If it ain't broke don't fix it' does not apply. This system ain't broke and it does not need to be thrown out and recast through this legislation.

This system always needs improvement; it always needs to be upgraded according to the circumstances. Over time the arbitration system has been, and during the last period of the Labor government it was. It was broadened and deepened and made more flexible to meet the needs of Australia's economy moving into the global economy and reduced levels of protection in this country. It was done in a way in which it protected the rights of Australians but with a safety net protection that ensured that no‐one could be exploited, while the opportunity and encouragement was there for workers to choose collective bargaining as a way of collaborating with their employers to increase the productivity of their company and, by increasing their productivity, get a greater income for that company on the basis that shareholders and management, workers and employees would share equally and fairly in the increased productivity that those that provide the investment, those that provide the managerial skills and those that provide the practical workplace skills to make a product or deliver a service participated in so the shares would be equal, no‐one would be exploited and there could be a basis for common cooperation. That was the basis on which we amended legislation. It was optional and it was free. No force or coercion was applied. There was opportunity and inducement. If people did not want to take it then there was a managerial task to find a way in which they could.

This legislation introduces force and coercion. It introduces a system to force people out of awards. One only has to look at the statistics of some of the look‐alike states like Victoria and Western Australia to see how that has happened. We have had a system that has served this nation well, has evolved over time, has been modified to the circumstances, has worked well, was predictable and understood, was known about and was not broken. That will all be cast out and a new system, which has created major problems elsewhere in Australia, will be introduced.

This is not an academic argument, though. There is an empirical test here. There is basic evidence now as to the differences between the system that Labor had and the system that this coalition government proposes to introduce. It is none other than a report by the Department of Industrial Relations into enterprise bargaining in Australia, the annual report in 1995, which is a voluminous document, too complex to go into now.

Essentially, it is able to compare how many workers went into enterprise or workplace bargains at the federal level under the industrial regulation of the former government and how many and what type of bargains they went into at the state level under the Kennett government and the Court government, how those bargains operated, what the satisfaction level was and what the productivity outcomes were.

The unequivocal finding is that the system that we had worked; that 60 per cent of workplaces with 10 or more employees under the federal system went into those bargains, compared with hardly any, unless they were forced, at the state level; that 75 per cent of all those employees that went into those bargains expressed a high level of satisfaction; and that, from October 1991 to April 1996, 8,000 federal agreements were ratified. So the system is working. The arguments that we need to make a revolutionary change are not justified and the proposals here therefore should be scotched. I reject the legislation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It occurred to me, when I was considering comments that had been made by various senators about workplace agreements during this debate on the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, and the reality of those documents in the real world in terms of, for example, the points that Senator Cook has just been making in respect of young people who will not have access to the significant resources that are provided by trade unions and so on, that the reality of what will actually happen in respect of employees' real knowledge of those agreements at that level of the community could not be exemplified any better than by the current debate that we are engaged upon, which has so far claimed the scalps of two government frontbenchers. Were the rules to apply fairly, as of this day, as of this moment, it would certainly equally claim the scalps of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr Moore, and of the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, without going any further through the cabinet.

SPEECH.PARA: In real terms—and I reflected on this when I went back through the Cabinet Handbook again this morning—the code of conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for his ministers is their workplace enterprise agreement. Those are precisely the conditions under which they are employed, the rules with which they will have to comply. It is clear from this current debate that few of them have even bothered to read it and those few who did bother to read it have clearly not understood it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They ignored it.

—Or ignored it. In terms of that ministerial enterprise agreement, if this country's arguably leading citizens, that is, the federal cabinet, have so much trouble understanding their enterprise agreement that it has already cost two of them their jobs in consecutive 24‐hour periods and has placed a whole heap of others in real jeopardy, what hope in real terms have people in the community got, particularly those younger people who will be very much the victims of this new system? If the federal cabinet cannot get their enterprise agreement right, what chance has anyone else got of doing so? They will be vulnerable indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Cook and others have said, the real core of this entire operation, and we all know it, is to strike down the award system in Australia, to remove that safety net which underpins employer‐employee relationships in Australia, and to substitute a free‐for‐all. It is not a new argument. It is as old as politics itself. In fact, the arguments of protection—tariffs, if you like—or marketplace rules go back hundreds of years.

Madam Acting Deputy President, as you would know, one of the fundamental debates, particularly in places like Great Britain, for hundreds of years was that the market should set the rules for labour. This is a very ancient conservative argument. There is nothing new about it. The repercussions, of course, of letting the marketplace rule in respect of the conditions and pay of employees who did not enjoy the same negotiating strength as the people who sit on the other side of the table from them has been well known in the past and no doubt will be revisited in the future.

It has been very largely a product of the situation in New Zealand and, without question, in terms of the debate that led up to their election, was instrumental in bringing about the result that we have now had; that is, that this prosperity which New Zealand has enjoyed in terms of its overall economic statistics has not been enjoyed by the majority of the population in New Zealand, who have in fact been used as the pawns to produce some of that wealth, none of which they are the beneficiaries of. In fact, as the leader of the Labour Party and the potential new Prime Minister of that country has observed in the past few days, all of that national prosperity is not much good at the end of the day when people are still needing assistance to feed their families.

There have been some interesting contributions to this debate and a great deal of the traditional anti‐union rhetoric. I thought the point was very well made by my colleagues Senator Reynolds and Senator Crowley, who spoke a short time ago, and who talked about these one‐way rules that apply in the debate on industrial relations. We on this side of the house are continually being accused of not being in business and never having had experience in small business. I am not quite sure what a doctor's surgery is if it is not a small business, but these epithets are constantly thrown across the chamber in an attempt to make a platform for saying we should therefore not discuss these issues. It does not stop the same people, who constantly give you the impression they would not sit in the same room as a union official and certainly would never join one, going forth at great length about the sins and omissions of unions.

I had the opportunity of being a workplace union delegate when I worked for the CSIRO. Even though it is a long time ago, there is one thing that I can still remember from those days in terms of the real position in the world in respect of conditions.

People go on at great length about the declining membership of unions in Australia. That is a fact of life, and it is a fact of life that the unions have to grapple with. I certainly know from first-hand experience as a workplace union delegate one of the reasons for that declining membership, but I am pleased to say that it did not happen in the small workplace that I was involved in. Nevertheless, one of my jobs was to discuss with new employees the work that the union did on their behalf, to discuss the dues that would need to be paid—whether they wanted them deducted from their salary, et cetera—and, indeed, to discuss whether they wanted to join the union at all.

There was a reaction which I often got during those discussions. After I had explained that there was an annual round of discussions between the union that represented us in terms of our wages and conditions, after I had discussed the fact that the union was always available as a resource when employees needed it and after I had particularly discussed the wages, conditions and service that we negotiated, one question that I would be asked was, `If I don't join the union and if I don't pay those dues, will I still get the wages and the conditions?' In respect of my workplace, the answer to that was, `Yes, you will—if you want to ride on the backs of the rest of us who actually provide our union dues out of our salaries in order to help you secure the wages and conditions that you get.' I am pleased to say that in all cases—certainly while I was there—that was an argument that won the day, and there was a 100 per cent union membership in that workplace.

There is no question that there are a lot of workers who are quite happy to accept the benefits—and they are significant—that the resources of an organised and professional union can bring to a workplace without having to endure the obligation of paying the dues. That is certainly one of the reasons for the decline in union membership.

Other speakers have canvassed a whole range of issues to do with this debate which I will not go over again. I want to highlight one potential negative result for workers if this legislation is carried through this house. This legislation will have an extremely detrimental effect on workers in the part of the world where I come from and, Madam Acting Deputy President Reynolds—if I may be forgiven for addressing the chair directly—where you come from, that is, in the more remote and regional locations of Australia.

None of the conditions that workers have had unions fight for and achieve over many years and that are provided for them in northern Australia will be protected if this legislation passes through the Senate in the way it is currently drafted. The conditions will be all up for grabs and will be all, potentially, dumped. There is no question at all, considering the track record of the negotiations that I am very familiar with in northern Australia, that the first reaction of many employers will be to dump the conditions and the enterprise agreements in this brave new world.

PARA.BREAK: What we are talking about are things like the district allowance, accommodation assistance and airconditioning subsidies that are provided in remote locations in northern Australia, where climatic conditions, I con fess, are very stressful at certain times of the year. We are also talking about the annual recreation leave air fares that are provided as part of awards and the additional recreation leave, which we have had in the Northern Territory for as long as I can remember. All of those additional benefits to workers will be up for grabs. Also, there are the fares out of isolated localities for specified purposes—that is for medical, dental and specialist treatment or on compassionate grounds—which are also commonplace. None of those will be protected if this legislation passes through the Senate as it is currently drafted.

SPEECH.PARA: I have received just in the last week letters from territorians who have been in the position of having to utilise these additional benefits for medical treatment. I am actually talking about real people—not the Wright family; the manufactured, fictional family of Senator Vanstone. I am actually talking about real people with real experiences who have only recently been alerted to what might happen. I might add that they have been alerted by the activities of the Community and Public Sector Union in the Northern Territory, by the submissions that were given to the Senate committee which sat in Darwin and by the publicity that ensued.

I received these shock, horror letters from people—and this is the way it happens in the real world—who suddenly realised for the first time that none of these conditions which were part of their awards would be guaranteed under this new legislation. One letter described in graphic detail the serious problems that one family would have been in had they not been able to exercise the condition they had for getting an air fare out of the Northern Territory in a medical emergency. Due to our small population we do not enjoy a number of specialist services—such as oncology, for example—that the more popular centres of Australia have. Those additional benefits can be fully justified and, in the past, they have been justified and approved by the Industrial Relations Commission as a result of the hard work that the unions have done collectively on behalf of us all in the Northern Territory.

I might add that education fares assistance is also on that quite long list of additional benefits and conditions in remote localities, none of which will be protected under the workplace relations bill that we are debating now. Just to give honourable senators who may be interested an idea—probably in most cases I think they would be completely unaware that these things exist—of just how far-flung these effects will be, I want to make the point that these remote locality benefits are not confined to the Northern Territory. A number of them are linked to areas of Australia that qualify for district allowance, and that is how the link is made in the awards.

I will just give the Senate a few examples of places to show how many workers will potentially be affected by this bill going through—I am sure a lot of senators will not be aware of them. These places include Broken Hill, Burke, Cobar, Coonamble, Moree, Narrabri and Walgett—all of which are in the more remote regions of the state of New South Wales. It also includes places like Atherton, Ingham, Innisfail, Mareeba, Roma, Sandy Cape, Townsville, Tully, Charters Towers, Charleville, Cairns, Bowen, Biloela and Ayr—all in Queensland. They all have award conditions, none of which are protected by this legislation. Other areas include Ceduna in South Australia, Queenstown in Tasmania, and Wilsons Promontory Lighthouse in Victoria. It is getting harder to find remote locations in Victoria but, nevertheless, they are still there. Of course, there is a long list in Western Australia, as you would expect, Madam Acting Deputy President. All of these places have significant additional provisions in their awards, none of which are protected.

PARA.BREAK: I will give the Senate an example of the airconditioning subsidy that is provided as part of awards. Let me tell the Senate it is a significant expense if you live in the north. Again, there is a long list of communities in Western Australia that receive this subsidy, including Broome, Carnarvon, Dampier, Derby, Exmouth, Halls Creek, Karratha, Kununurra, Port Hedland and so on. It also applies to many localities in the Northern Territory and in Queensland. There is also a whole range of localities that currently enjoy additional leave. All of these areas are con tained in the evidence before the Senate committee inquiring into this matter. That is why I do not need to go into it any further in here.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, the reason I wanted to raise this particular aspect that has not been canvassed before in this debate is that, when you consider the very large number of remote localities in Western Australia, Queensland, New South Wales and South Australia, I would put a very large sum of money indeed on the fact that the majority of senators in here—certainly on the government benches—would be completely unaware that so many workers in their electorates are going to be potentially disadvantaged by the lack of protection of these conditions. I am sure that I would win that bet.

I have to confess to the Senate that I have lost a few other bets in recent days. The Senate Hansard actually bears record to the bet I had in here—I think it was in September—with the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). I bet him $5 that Senator Short would not resign in the next six months. I did this on the basis that I am in the habit of putting small sums of money on bets that I hope I will lose. I did pay the $5 to Senator Faulkner.

But I was so encouraged by the investment that the following day I had a standing bet with Senator Faulkner as a job lot covering the entire ministry, including parliamentary secretaries, at $5 a head and lost another $5 on the following day. I have now paid to Senator Faulkner the $10 that I owe him. I think it is an extremely good investment in terms of the good governance of Australia at $5 a head. I am doing rather well. I am prepared to place a large bet—and I think I would win—that very few senators and I might say many government members that represent these areas in the House of Representatives would be totally unaware that the legislation that they are so enthusiastically pushing through this parliament will so severely disadvantage the workers in their regions. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a member of the Senate Economics References Committee that held public hearings throughout Australia into the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. During the course of the public hearings, government senators often raised the situation in New Zealand to support this government's agenda. My colleagues on the other side often referred to New Zealand's experience since the introduction of the Employment Contracts Act 1991 to support their case. They would have us believe that they actually know what they are talking about. I quote Senator Crane:

SPEECH.PARA: I have also been to New Zealand and I have had a look at New Zealand.
He goes on to say:

It is absolutely true that wages in New Zealand from 1994 until now are less . . . I prefer to use not stagnated but stabilised in terms of that drop in unemployment from 12 to six per cent. I do not think the participation rate is relevant to that, but the important thing is that during that particular time New Zealand has got on top of its current account problem—
Senator Crane also said:
When we say it has not gone into work as it has gone into profits, it has gone into balancing the budget in New Zealand, and that is incredibly important to us all.
That is a bit convoluted and rambling, but I think we got the point in terms of what he was trying to say.

Let us have a look at the reality. I refer to a report called `The report of the study program on structural adjustment and social change'. The preface to this report was written by three academics. They are Mr Fred Argy, a visiting fellow in the public policy program at the ANU; Professor Fred Gruen from the Centre for Economic Policy Research at the ANU; and Professor Bettina Cass, Professor of Sociology and Social Policy at the University of Sydney. These are respected academics with no axe to grind and they clearly disputed the wisdom of Australia heading down the same path of industrial reform as New Zealand.

They noted that the economic results in New Zealand, `taken in isolation', may be regarded as impressive, but to favourably compare the New Zealand economic reform path with that of the previous Labor Australian government is premature, based on the evidence and proper analysis. Their report makes three main points:

First, New Zealand's better growth performance appears to be due more to a more rapid accumulation of raw factors of production (capital and labour) rather than to relative improvements in resource utilisation or in the quality of human capital.
