The New Zealand factor and labour productivity growth have not been good, not even matching Australia's performance. New Zealand's reforms have had little impact on efficiency and that is not a good sign. They state:
Secondly, much of New Zealand's recent strong economic growth can be attributed to temporary factors.

These experts claim, quite rightly, that a lot of New Zealand's recent growth is merely a catch‐up period. New Zealand's economy performed so poorly in the 1980s that a period of improvement was inevitable and this cannot be attributed to the New Zealand process of economic reform. The third and most telling point is:
The potential gains from New Zealand‐type reform need to be weighed against the social costs.

This bill, like the New Zealand employment act, the keystone of their reform package, is a short‐sighted or visionless quick fix. It is about providing a pool of cheap labour. It is about increasing profit for a few—and at whose expense? It can be shown that some New Zealanders have benefited significantly during the period of short‐term economic recovery—at the top end, might I say, similar to the United States. But, as this government would like to do with this bill, New Zealand went too far. I quote from the report:
The main losers have been the already disadvantaged—low income earners and recipients of social welfare.

What did New Zealand do to achieve this stunning result? They dismantled arbitration and collective bargaining and replaced this with individual employee contracts. They allowed the market and social wage safety nets to be eroded. Does that sound familiar?

The New Zealand Employment Contract Act is responsible for lowering the standard of living of thousands of Maoris, migrants, young people and women. It has seen the demise of proper industry policy and planning and led to extreme hardship where awards have disappeared, and with them paid rates and fair working conditions.

Workplace based training has dried up to a trickle—sound familiar?—and a level of skill shortage has developed: so alarming that changes to immigration levels are being considered to solve this problem. This is somewhat ironic given the debate that is going on in Australia at the moment.

It was in no small part due to the detrimental effects of the Employment Contract Act that the New Zealand parliament was held to be undemocratic and profound changes have been made to the electoral system. The first election in New Zealand under MMP was held on Saturday. The result in this election mirrored the recent polling, with one exception. Labour polled seven per cent more than most pundits predicted.

TALK.START.PARA: —They got up to 28 per cent. It was brilliant!
—Hang on, I have not finished, Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, people wanted a change from the Nationals' policy of industrial relations. Even the Nationals' splinter party, New Zealand First, had a pre‐election policy of reforming the Employment Contract Act.

It all points to the people of New Zealand seeking changes to their labour market. That is what they wanted. They wanted change. Over 66 per cent of people in New Zealand voted for parties that promised reform to this legislation and this system.

I hope my colleagues opposite are getting the message loud and clear. It is also going to be an unpopular vote for the government. It is going to lose the government votes. Now that is fine for us on this side but, in the meantime, a lot of people are going to get hurt and suffer. That is the major point.

During the Senate hearings, we heard evidence on how the Employment Contract Act has been working and why it was introduced in New Zealand. Tony Short, from the school of law of the University of South Australia, told the committee he spoke to the New Zealand minister for labour at a conference in 1990. When he asked the minister what arguments persuaded him that this industrial reform was the way New Zealand could go, the minister simply could not answer the question.

The question was then answered by the chief executive officer of the employers federation, who basically said, `Our members wanted it.' That was the primary reason for the legislation. They wanted the legislation for a reason: because it provides a pool of labour which is cheap, a pool of labour which they can exploit in a relatively unfettered way.

It is clear that this legislation was introduced purely for ideological reasons, not for the benefit of average New Zealanders. Let us look at what it has `achieved'—I say somewhat facetiously—for the workers of New Zealand. I would enlighten senators as to some of the practices taking place in New Zealand, again from evidence given to the Senate hearing. A local supermarket hired children for weekend and evening work. They were paid from $1.40 to $2.00 per hour for that work. Is that what we want to happen in Australia? I and those on this side of the chamber do not want that to happen.

Tony Short gave an example of an employer on New Zealand's South Island, a Mr Schwartzberg ,who inserted a clause in the contract for his employees which stated that employees have to go to the bathroom in their own time. I am not sure how you would measure that. It is unbelievable, but true.

Nobody seems to dispute that the deregulation of the labour market has seen real wages fail to keep up with inflation. For the vast majority of employees in New Zealand, the Employment Contracts Act has been a failure. The Employment Contracts Act has created a new class—the working poor. Is this the path we want Australia to take? I hope not. This is the path this bill is leading us down.

I would like to remind senators of a statement made by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard. Mr Howard said that the current award system will remain in place and be available for all workers. Clearly, that is another broken promise. Mr Howard should have said that he planned to reduce workers' rights to a few basic minima—taking from workers rights and conditions already bargained and fought for.

The working men and women of Australia can be forgiven for believing Mr Howard. They did not know at that stage of the game that coalition promises come in two forms—core and non‐core. This is obviously a non-core promise—a promise the coalition believes it does not have to keep.

This bill does not give workers the right to choose a current award and it clearly gives primacy to Australian workplace agreements over awards. You may ask what workplace agreements will give workers. I will tell you—uncertainty in wages, uncertainty in working hours, an imbalance in bargaining power and the threat of `no sign, no start'. They will not get the choice that the coalition bleats on about.
Let us look at some very real examples of what could and would happen if the coalition is successful with this bill. A year 12 student who worked as a casual shop assistant told the Senate committee:

. . . I went in to work one day to find that my name was not on the roster. I approached my manager only to be told that if I wanted hours I had to sign a workplace agreement . . . a substantial reduction in my wages. I could not see any alternative so I did sign the agreement and immediately I had an abundance of work.

Upon reflection, this young woman changed her mind and indicated that she wanted that agreement cancelled. This act resulted in her being taken off the roster and receiving no hours whatsoever. She now has no job and no money. Another case—and this person contacted my office—is that of a person who is a qualified mechanic with 10 years experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good choice.
—It is the sort of choice that you would make, but it is not really a choice, is it?
—No choice at all.

—It is no choice at all. This qualified mechanic was asked to sign an agreement. In this agreement his rate of pay was that of an unqualified person, not a tradesperson with 10 years experience. After speaking to his prospective employer about this situation he was told, `If you're not happy, don't bother coming in to start there are plenty of people out there who need jobs.' This is an appalling situation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear there is no choice for employees whose employers require them to sign a workplace agreement as a precondition on being offered a job. Unfortunately, these cases—and I can assure you that there are too many like this—clearly show that the government's proposal that workplace agreements can be entered into before employment commences can only lead to intimidation of workers, diminution of wages and exploitation of workers. The signing of an agreement before you get the job is a very real concern for workers. The only choice this gives them is take what you are offered or remain unemployed. This is the government's idea of choice. This is the level playing field the government has been talking about.

This government seems very keen on employees signing employment contracts before they are offered a job. Why? It is leave workers with little bargaining power and out on their own without the protection of an award or a union. The only reason workplace agreements are elevated in status is so that individual arrangements are accorded supremacy over awards and primacy over any other sort of legislation, including state legislation.

The emphasis of this bill is to take what little bargaining power workers may have through the process of collective bargaining and give it as a thank you for their support to those who already possess considerable power over workers in this nation. This government would like to see an end to collective bargaining and an end to the protection of workers through the award system. This bill in its present form will clearly allow unscrupulous employers to design workplace agreements which will remove the fair terms and conditions which workers in this country have fought long and hard for.

What are government members saying? They are saying that workplace agreements will be vetted and, not to worry, it is all okay. These are the same workplace agreements that are confidential and shrouded in secrecy. This government proposes that workplace agreements do not require a pre‐agreement review. We on this side of the chamber say that workplace agreements must be reviewed in public by the Industrial Relations Commission and comply with a genuine no disadvantage test.

I will give a case in point. In Western Australia, under similar legislation, an employee had an agreement that said he had five days sick leave. The minimum conditions are 10 days sick leave. How could this agreement be registered? How could this agreement be valid? The employee's union wrote to the Western Australia Commissioner of Workplace Agreements, and the reply was:
You will appreciate that confidentiality provisions prevent me acknowledging or otherwise indicating whether or not there is any such workplace agreement, registered or otherwise.

With workplace agreements accorded these secrecy provisions, how can unions represent the interests of their members? How can workers ensure that they are actually getting a fair deal? These secrecy provisions are only in place to ensure that the erosion of workers' wages and conditions are kept hidden, are kept secret, so people do not know what is going on.

Another way this government has devised to further isolate workers and deprive them of bargaining power is this bill's right of entry provisions. In their submission to the Senate references committee on the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, the International Centre for Trade Union Rights set out a number of fundamental objections to the bill's implementation. Objections to this bill put forward by the centre concerned the breaches of international law that this bill will entail, particularly in relation to the right to strike, the undermining of the organisational autonomy of trade unions, and the dismantling of trade union structures and the right of entry.

In relation to the right of entry, the International Centre for Trade Union Rights submitted to the Senate committee that `the provisions relating to right of entry are clearly and directly in breach of international law'. The majority of the Senate committee agreed that there is strong evidence to support this objection.

Under the current situation, right of entry gives the union official the right to enter workplaces for the purpose of ensuring that workplace award obligations are followed. This right is fundamental to a union's ability to protect its members' interests, ensure compliance with workplace awards and maintain contact with its members. In relation to the union's right of entry, the majority of the Senate committee conclude:
The limits the bill proposes to place on existing right of entry arrangements should be rejected.
The majority of the committee noted that:
. . . right of entry plays an important role in ensuring compliance with workplace awards and agreements, at no cost to the government.
It is free. This, the majority of the Senate committee submitted, gives:
. . . comfort to business competitors who can be more confident that they are not being undercut by unscrupulous operators.
Basically, it is bad business, apart from anything else. The majority of the committee also said:

This compliance function will be severely curtailed by the proposed need for a written invitation, and a proposed requirement that this invitation or a certificate obtained in lieu be shown to the employer. These limitations seem burdensome and bureaucratic, and could permit intimidation of employees.

I think that is putting it mildly. Clearly, the threat posed by this bill to employees is the very real possibility of workplace intimidation by some employers—not all employers, probably not a majority of employers, but there is a proportion out there who will use it.

The coalition's proposal limits the right of entry in number of ways. It can only be exercised where one or more employees who are members of the union invite it to enter the workplace—therefore clearly allowing for identification of the employee. This will lead to workers being too scared to talk their unions about breaches, too scared to talk to anybody—their fellow workers—about breaches.

A woman contacted my office stating that she was concerned that after contacting her union regarding an occupational health and safety matter, employees were subjected to questioning as to who called in the union. This went on for a month after the matter had been settled.

When John Howard proclaimed that the coalition would govern for all Australians, some Australians could be forgiven for believing that Mr Howard meant `all Australians'. It is not all Australians; it is some Australians. It is privileged Australians. It is those who have actually got the power currently. That is what this bill is about.

The coalition's workplace relations bill is more concerned with shoring up business alliances rather than providing an equitable outcome for all. Considering the number of shares people opposite have in business, I guess that is a reasonable outcome if you are a government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's how companies employee people.

—Oh! What we are seeing from the coalition with this bill is a total contempt for working women and men of Australia which, in effect, amounts to a disenfranchising of workers' rights by stealth. The coalition would like the people of Australia to think of this bill as a reform of industrial relations. However, it is quite clear that the intent of this bill is not to reform but to herald a return; that is, a return to the days when employers dictated the rights and conditions for employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened intently to Senator Mackay's contribution to this debate, hoping perhaps that I might hear something new because, having travelled with Senator Mackay for a period of four weeks on the industrial relations inquiry, I have heard most of it before. I do not know whether it has something to do with her coming from an island state, but she seems to have an obsession with New Zealand—an obsession which I have heard quite often in question time and at other times.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand her obsession with New Zealand because, as she said in her speech, the Labor Party in Australia and the Labour Party in New Zealand have a lot common: they are both polling roughly less than a third of the vote. She considers it a great improvement when the New Zealand Labour Party gets up to 28 per cent of the vote, with the likelihood of providing a Prime Minister from that sort of popular vote amongst the people. I think the analogies that Senator Mackay drew with New Zealand are misplaced. She did so on the basis that the Australian Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is based on New Zealand experience when, in fact, we know that is simply not the case.

Senator Mackay chose to quote various people who gave evidence at our inquiry. Many of those people were specially hand‐picked to be there and there were some others who, because of the nature of their position, were there anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you attacking the witnesses who appeared before the committee?
—I would like to quote somebody else at the inquiry, somebody whose opinions perhaps Senator Mackay is not so keen on.
—You are in contempt of the committee, are you?

—I listened to Senator Mackay in silence, but I can say see that I must be touching a very raw nerve for Senator Neal to interject so much. I would like to quote from some of the evidence that we had in inquiry from Professor Judith Sloan, and Senator Mackay will remember her. We have had her quotes; perhaps we will have some from the other side. Professor Sloan said early in her evidence that she wanted to make a number of general comments. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: The first is that the bill is 300 pages and the explanatory memorandum is about 200 pages, I think. Perhaps it may not be a convincing proposition to all of the senators—
I think she was referring to Senator Jacinta Collins, who just walked in, and Senator Mackay—

but this bill actually makes quite modest changes. It is a bill which is basically a gradual transformation. It basically builds on the kind of patchy progress that has been made in industrial relations towards enterprise bargaining.
Let me say—
Senator Jacinta Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are going to hear one side of the story—
—Order! Senator Collins, if you are going to interject, would you please resume your normal seat.

—I am pleased that Senator Collins is here because it shows that some of these issues that are raised are actually hitting on a raw nerve that prompts Senator Collins and Senator Mackay to interject. But can I say that Professor Sloan, in her evidence, said that the bill actually represents quite modest changes. I think even the Democrat senator on our committee said that it was a natural—
—You think, or you know?

—If you read the evidence you will find that he said that it was a natural progression from the 1993 bill that we move on in the area of industrial relations reform. I am pleased that Senator Collins is here because, although I did not have the opportunity to hear Senator Collins's speech, I read what she had to say. A couple of things Senator Collins said need to be refuted. From some of the comments that she has made, I certainly do not know how she draws the conclusions that she does.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things she said was that my desire to attend another committee hearing, a hearing of the Public Works Committee, compromised the program of the inquiry. To suggest that my attendance at another committee hearing of this parliament compromised the program of the inquiry is beyond the realms of any probability or believability because this committee can continue at any time as long as there is a quorum. I reject outright the suggestion that I compromised the program of this inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say you compromised.

—That was the word that you used. You said that my desire to attend compromised the program of the inquiry. That is not true. I refute that suggestion. She also said in the same section of her speech that Senator Chapman was in the United States when we concluded the public hearings. He certainly was, having attended, I think, just about every day of public hearings for 17 days. For the last two days he was on a pre-arranged visit to the Republican Convention in the United States, which had been arranged a long time in advance.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins says that Senator Chapman was in the United States when we concluded the public hearings and she reflects on the senator's absence in a way that is not proper. For 17 days Senator Chapman went to, I think, every day of the hearings. So to suggest that any government members of the committee compromised the hearing in any way needs to be refuted, and it was.

TALK.START.PARA: —You started it. You started improper conduct.

—Senator Collins says that we started it. I presume that she is referring to mention that was made of Senator Sherry's non-attendance for two weeks while he was on holiday in Bali. If this bill had gone to the correct committee, if it had gone to the legislation committee, Senator Sherry would not have had to be put on this committee to replace another senator. Senator Sherry would have been a member of this committee as a member of the legislation committee, and so would Senator Cook. Many would not have had to be replaced. There is a suggestion that Senator Sherry was desperate to be on this hearing and reference was made as to how important it was that the shadow minister was on the inquiry. Let me say that in my time in this place shadow ministers have rarely been on committees. For Senator Collins to use the example that a shadow minister was needed—and the shadow minister then cleared out for two weeks—I am afraid is drawing a very long bow.

SPEECH.PARA: Further on in her speech she said she was very pleased to see that I had returned because she was afraid that I was going to be overseas while the bill was being debated. I am not sure what she was implying, but I was part of a parliamentary delegation with two of her colleagues to Poland, Hungary and Berlin—a delegation, I might add, that I enjoyed. I also enjoyed the company of your colleagues. If a person who goes on a parliamentary delegation in this place is to be reflected on in this way—

TALK.START.PARA: —In what way?
—You said that you were afraid that I was going to be overseas while the bill was being debated. So you were making insinuations—
—Deal with facts—not insinuations or inferences.
—I do not mind interjections but it is very difficult to talk over a constant barrage from the other side.
—I was going to suggest that Senator Collins remain silent to allow Senator Ferguson to make his remarks.

—Can I just raise two other issues, because I have promised the whip on this side that I will not speak for more than 10 minutes. I refer to the committee's inquiry because it was spoken of at length by Senator Collins; Senator Mackay referred to it at length as well. There has been an attempt in Senator Collins's speech to suggest that she acquiesced to no-one in the course of this inquiry. On the final night of our hearings when we had the President of the ACTU attend and respond to matters that had been raised, and when I asked her a question about the ACTU's involvement and organisation of this inquiry, she said she objected to the question. After I asked her why she objected to the question it is fair to say that she admitted that yes, she did see it as their role to play an important part in the running of this inquiry. They are not her exact words but they are words that she used.

SPEECH.PARA: So right from the start to the finish of this whole inquiry and since this bill has been introduced, the Labor Party, and the ACTU in particular, have seen this as an opportunity to try to build up their falling stocks, to try to somehow recruit a greater membership because their membership force has fallen to an all-time low. All it has done has been to show that the ACTU's involvement in this inquiry certainly was far greater than its involvement in any other parliamentary inquiry that I have been involved with. The talk about 1,000 submissions—people with form letters—that many people, responding out of the 2.3 million union members throughout Australia is an indication of just how much concern there is amongst workers in Australia with this workplace relations reform bill. The best thing we can do is get on with it and get this bill passed so that people in Australia will have far greater opportunity than they have had over the past 13 years of a Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in opposition to the bill. I must say that I was quite amused by Senator Ferguson's reference to `falling stocks for the Labor Party'. In light of what has been happening over the last week in this chamber I would have thought that it was a term that he might have avoided to save himself and his friends further embarrassment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) would have us believe that there is currently an environment of economic decline, racing wages growth and seething industrial dispute, and that this is a situation that has existed since Labor won government in 1983. I just want to put on the record Senator Panizza's reference to my husband. He seems to have a particular obsession with him but I am glad to have his name put on the record.

Mr Howard justifies his attack on the working families of Australia on this basis. He states that the scales are tilted in favour of employees and that he is just fixing the playing field up by tilting it in favour of employers, which is going to put them on an equal basis with workers. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The period of 13 years of Labor government was marked not by industrial uproar and dispute but by tranquil negotiation and cooperation between industry and workers. The results achieved by the accords were an increasing social wage which took into account both take‐home wages and social benefits. The period was marked by employment growth, increasing productivity and micro‐economic reform.

BREAK.PARA: The average economic growth during the period of the Labor government was 3.7 per cent and only 2.2 per cent while John Howard was Treasurer. Employment growth was 2.3 per cent on average over 13 years of Labor and employment growth under Howard as Treasurer was just 0.8 per cent.
In the area of industrial disputes, during the period of Labor, 200 working days were lost per 1,000 employees. And what is the record of Howard while he was Treasurer?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the correct terminology is `The Prime Minister'.

—I take your guidance, Mr Acting Deputy President. I apologise for that omission. While Mr Howard was Treasurer, three times as many days were lost by industrial dispute as during the period of Labor, that is, 600 working days per 1,000 employees—not a very proud record and not something that I would be harking back to.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Howard is obviously nostalgic for this era. He is nostalgic for a period of confrontation, dispute and disharmony that he remembers from when he was Treasurer, when he last held the reins of government. The vehicle that he is using to return to this era is not only his style of leadership but also this workplace relations bill.

This bill reduces the assistance previously provided to workers to enable them to negotiate on an equal basis with employers. Australian workers are not greedy. They want just four simple things: a job, decent working conditions, fair remuneration for the work that they have done, and job security. This bill undermines these four essentials.

Mr Howard, the present Prime Minister, made a rock solid guarantee that no‐one would be worse off. This must be one of the non‐core promises that Mr Howard made because he certainly has shown by this bill that he has no intention of keeping it. The bill is complex, convoluted and long, and neither workers nor business will benefit. It will create further administrative difficulties for business and, at the same time, nurture and encourage industrial unrest. The bill threatens reasonable wage rises, promotion on merit, employee redress for unfair treatment at the hands of employers, and existing conditions.

I am not able to deal with the bill as a whole in the time available, but there are a number of changes that I really think need particular attention and maybe have not been focused on by previous speakers. The first is the undermining of the principle of equal pay. I must confess that, despite ideological differences with people on the other side, I would have thought that there were certain principles that are sacrosanct. But this bill and this provision certainly indicate to me that that is no longer the case.

This bill repeals the power of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to make orders in relation to over‐award payments to ensure that employees covered by the orders will have equal remuneration for work of equal value. What that really means is that the commission can no longer ensure that men and women are paid the same amount.

This occurs by schedule 8 of the bill which repeals division 2 of part VIA of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. The effect of this schedule is to repeal schedule 6 of the Industrial Relations Act, which contains the International Labour Organisation's Equal Remuneration Convention 1951 on Equal Remuneration for Men and Women Workers for Work of Equal Value.

Schedule 8 of the bill also repeals schedule 7 of the Industrial Relations Act, which contains the ILO's Recommendation on Equal Remuneration for Men and Women Workers for Work of Equal Value. It also repeals the use of the `Anti‐Discrimination Conventions' definitions contained in the Equal Remuneration Convention, the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, the Convention concerning Discrimination in respect of Employment and Occupation, articles 3 and 7 of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural rights and it repeals the use of `Equal Remuneration Convention' in definitions.

What all this means is that this government no longer intends to comply with international conventions with regard to wages equality. It is a particularly sad thing to see this government pursuing. It is showing complete and utter disregard for international conventions that the Australian government has signed—a very distressing and humiliating course for me as a member of the Australian parliament.

It is particularly sad to see that this conservative Australian government is one of the few governments of the world that is in accord with the Taliban of Afghanistan in pushing back the gains already achieved by women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has more females in parliament?

—The quest for equal pay for equal work has been an arduous one for women in Australia—and I have to take up that interjection by the good senator who suggests that somehow, if they have more women in parliament, that is a substitute for fair and equal conditions for women. Let me tell you that it is not. The women of Australia expect to be treated equally in terms of pay and other provisions. No matter how many women you have in parliament, women will not put up with these sorts of changes.

BREAK.PARA: The changes that have occurred for women in Australia have not come naturally. They have been extraordinarily difficult and have been brought about by endless activity and incremental change. Women did not receive equal pay until 1969. The principle of equal pay for equal work across different jobs was not endorsed until 1972.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—You are right. It is a major shame. It is an even greater shame that now in 1996 this government should see fit in this bill to reverse that some 24 years on. Women still receive less in wages than men. The Senate economics committee report stated that in 1992 women still received only 84.5 per cent of the total wages received by men.

BREAK.PARA: It is apparent that a larger part of this differential is made up of over‐award payments and cash benefits such as bonuses, work cars and entertainment allowances. Women earn only 54.7 per cent of men's equivalent over‐award payments. These over‐award payments are exactly the provisions that this bill overrides and says that the commission can no longer deal with.

It seems extraordinary to me that, in the face of evidence that women are still not treated equally in the workplace, this government sees fit to further undermine the quest for women to be treated equally and to have their work and talents equally recognised. Currently, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has the power to make orders to ensure there is equal remuneration for women in straightforward wages or in over‐award payments. The fact is that women will be seriously affected by the repeal of this power. The present situation where women receive only 85 per cent of wages received by men will slip further and further as time passes and as their over‐award payments are not kept equal to those of men.

There has been some suggestion by the coalition government that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will somehow be able to fill this gap. But the fact is that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission does not make industrial instruments and will not be able to in the future. Further, there is some debate that their orders are not enforceable. The fact is that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will not be able to take on the role of the Industrial Relations Commission in preventing the slide of women's wages backwards.

The second area of this bill that I find particularly offensive is the changes in relation to unfair dismissal. There has been some argument put forward that, in fact, there are no major changes to unfair dismissal and that the remedies remain much the same. What the bill does in amending the Workplace Relations Act 1996 is to reduce the number of people it applies to.The commission will not have jurisdiction over employees that are not federal award employees, Commonwealth public sector employees or territory employees. Many employees will not be covered by the commission even when their state remedy is inadequate.

PARA.BREAK: Further, the commission's power to compensate unfairly dismissed employees is constrained. The commission must, under this bill, have regard to the viability of the employer's business when assessing for pay ment of compensation. In other words, if a business that is not doing as well as might have been expected has not paid to a worker wages that it should have fairly paid or has unfairly terminated the employment of a worker, the worker will not be compensated.

BREAK.PARA: It is quite extraordinary that in the industrial arena principles such as this should be applied when they are not applied in any other forum. Can you imagine if a plaintiff suing someone for unlawfully injuring them was told that they would not be successful in their claim because the defendant's financial position was not particularly good? I do not think that would be seen as reasonable by most people and I certainly do not see that as being reasonable in the industrial arena.

The third restriction that is being introduced by the bill is that the court has no power to review, vary or set aside the contracts made by independent contractors. There will be no independent industrial courts looking at these contracts—a major change from the present situation. Workers entering into these sorts of contracts will be open to unfair conditions and to dismissal virtually at a whim.

These are only two areas that I have dealt with. There is a vast array of others and I hope that, from the length of the debate and from the amount of interest that is being shown in this bill, all the areas will be canvassed. Unfortunately, some will be missed, but at least it will draw to the attention of members of the community what is occurring as a result of this bill and how they may well be affected.

Labor will be putting forward a number of amendments to the bill generally. But, in relation to the areas I have raised, there will be major objection. I am hoping that that will be dealt with at a later stage. In my view, the industrial relations system under Labor and presently has worked effectively in the interests of both employers and employees. It seems unfortunate to me that this government should see fit to return industrial relations to unrest, disharmony and dispute when cooperation and negotiation are a much more effective way of getting things done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —This Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 is perhaps the most important piece of legislation that has come before this chamber, certainly in my time in the parliament. There are many things that I would have liked to have spoken about in this debate, but for reasons which I will mention briefly I have been asked to curtail my remarks quite considerably, as have all of those on the government side.

SPEECH.PARA: As all honourable senators will know, the coalition was elected by a huge majority at the last election. In my state of Queensland, the Labor Party is left with two electorates out of 26. That showed what the people of my state thought about the Labor Party, it indicated what they wanted done and it indicated their support for our policies.

In the Senate generally, at the last election, the coalition received a unique vote of confidence and achieved an almost unique victory such that in this chamber we now have the quite unusual situation where the coalition has 37 seats, nine more than the Australian Labor Party. Even if you add to that the Labor Party hangers‐on, the Australian Democrats, the coalition still has more seats in this chamber than have the Labor Party and their hangers‐on, the Democrats, combined.

Given the way this chamber is elected, that is quite unusual. Even if you add to that the left wing of the Labor Party, the Greens, they still do not have more senators than the coalition has. That indicates the way in which the people of Australia voted for the coalition because they wanted us to implement our policy.

In my home state, the Liberal Party in the Senate received some 680,000 votes and the National Party some 288,000 votes, a total of almost a million votes. The Democrats, by contrast, could not get a quota in my state—

TALK.START.PARA: —With their leader!

—And, in spite of the best efforts of the ABC, could not even get a quota. My own vote in the last Senate election was some 30 times greater than that achieved by the Tasmanian Greens. We were elected because of a number of specific policies in addition to our general philosophy.

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of this massive endorsement for the Liberal Party and the National Party at the last election, we have a situation now where the reforms and the legislation that we pledged to bring in have been hijacked by people, like the Greens and the Democrats, who received virtually no support from the Australian public. It is because of this selfish self‐indulgence—if that is not a tautology—of the Greens and the Democrats particularly, chatting away on matters in which Australians generally were not interested at the election, and because the Labor Party keeps regurgitating their tired old union line of class hatred, arguments that really belong to yesteryear, that we are curtailed in what we on this side have to say.

Why are we curtailed? The passage of this bill is the thing most commonly spoken about everywhere I go in Queensland. No matter where I go, no matter what problems are confronting people, they always say to me, `Can you get that workplace reform bill through?', because that is the underlying element of what will get the country going and address the unemployment problem. Wherever I go, wherever my colleagues go, it is the most raised matter. That is why I will curtail my remarks—to get this bill voted on and get it into operation so that Australia and all Australians can benefit.

In the few minutes I have left I want to mention briefly a couple of things. Firstly, all of the arguments put so concisely and well in this debate by my colleagues I support. Secondly, I want to mention that this bill, when it is passed, might bring about a change to the quite scandalous situation in the sugar industry whereby the AWU holds that industry to ransom, insisting on compulsory unionism; otherwise the cane will not be harvested. Hopefully, this bill will address that particular problem.

Thirdly, an approach was made to me and to a lot of my colleagues—and, I am sure, to people on the other side too—by a Christian group, the Brethren, which has some real concerns, not about our legislation, but about industrial relations generally. They have said, as I put to Mr Reith, that some concessions should be made in this bill, as has happened in the past, to ensure that the unions do not interfere in workplaces in a way that interferes with people's religious beliefs. I hope that Mr Reith is able to take that into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —The master‐servant relationship. Do you support the master‐servant relationship?
—I am talking about legislation that the New South Wales Labor government has supported. If your interjection is arguing with the New South Wales Labor government, you should make that point.

SPEECH.PARA: The next point I will briefly mention—although I did want to talk about it at more length—is that of the terrible waterfront situation, one which, hopefully, can be overcome by this bill. The people working on the waterfront, the wharfies, are getting average wages of $75,000 and their supervisors some $90,000. Consequently, the ordinary, average, battling Australian—the sort of person who will be voting in Lindsay on Saturday—pays more for all of the goods that come into Australia because of present waterfront practices. I certainly hope that with the passage of this bill ordinary, average Australians, battling Australians, can get a better deal on the goods they buy because the enormous add‐on costs currently incurred across the waterfront will not be there.

A colleague from Queensland, Senator MacGibbon, has asked me to refer briefly in my presentation to a pretty illogical argument put by Senator Ray in his speech. I mention it because Senator Ray usually can be relied upon for at least logical arguments in this chamber. But in his contribution to this debate he said, according to the AAP report, in relation to the Seaview Air disaster, that the aeroplane company exploited the vulnerability of pilots in order to drive down conditions and safety standards. He later went on to say that unscrupulous employers would misuse their powers over employees for commercial gain. He also said that, currently, this exploitation is illegal and able to be scrutinised by union presence.

BREAK.PARA: Where the illogicality comes about in Senator Ray's comments is that the actions that he complains about, this driving down of conditions and driving down of safety standards, all happened under your government, under the great workers' government, under the Labor government—and Senator Ray complains about it. If you people knew so much about it, why didn't you do something about the working conditions? So that argument is quite illogical. I indicated to Senator MacGibbon that in my contribution I would make a brief reference to that.

I note in passing that I do not think the Labor Party have declared their interest in this debate. This debate, from the Labor Party's point of view, is all about enhancing and retaining the powers and privileges of the union movement—and all the rorts they are involved in. Mr Deputy President, would you believe that Senator Carr, Senator Childs, Senator Conroy, Senator Cook, Senator Evans, Senator Foreman, Senator Forshaw, Senator Gibbs, Senator Hogg, Senator Lundy, Senator Mackay, Senator McKiernan, Senator Murphy, Senator Neal, Senator O'Brien, Senator Schacht and Senator Sherry all came to this parliament out of the union movement. There is nothing wrong with the union movement—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did, too!

—There are some others. I am sorry if I have missed them out; I do apologise. It shows the narrowness of views that come from the Labor Party and the way the Labor Party are so determined to oppose this so that the privileges and powers of their old union colleagues can be retained. I would have hoped that they would at least have had the courtesy to get up and declare their interest in this matter before the debate began.

BREAK.PARA: This bill, when it is passed, will bring back some freedom of choice to workers. If they want to join a union they will be perfectly entitled to and will do so with the encouragement of all senators on this side but if they do not want to join a union they will not be forced to. That is about freedom of choice; that is what the Australian nation and the Australian psyche are all about.

It saddens me to see that the Labor Party are so determined to keep that choice away from the workers. With those few remarks in the brief time available to me I want to urge senators to support this bill in its entirety so Australia can get going, so the economy can get the boost it needs and so we can look forward to better employment figures in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in opposition to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. This bill represents the repudiation of principles that have been at the core of my beliefs and political activity since I was a high school student. Not in response to Senator Macdonald, I had prepared to say that I declare proudly my membership of the United Firefighters Union of Australia and the Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: My interest is not a pecuniary one; it is not as some coalition members have suggested part of some plot to protect union power and influence; it is a reflection of my experiences, my beliefs, my philosophy, my ideology and my prejudice. The right to organise and take collective action is essential to the development of the Australian trade union movement and the Australian Labor Party. I believe that in unity is strength. I recognise the value of collective action; that in a less than perfect world where power is a factor, individuals, by combining together, can assert their rights with greater effect and success without diminishing the rights of any individual member of that group.

Australian society has developed with that principle as one of its cores. The Conciliation and Arbitration Act and its successors have since 1904 had among their primary objects the encouragement of the formation of trade unions of employers and employees. For 93 years the Australian Senate has held that Australian workers need the protection of trade unions and need the right to bargain collectively. That has been a view shared by both sides in the parliament. Parliament has continued to insist on ensuring these protections against the unfettered making of employment contracts between Australian workers and their employers.

BREAK.PARA: The parliament has accepted that the balance of interests would otherwise be unfairly tilted in favour of employers. But this bill takes us back to prior to 1904, by rejecting the years of development of industrial relations practice in this country. This bill elevates once again the individual employment contract to a place where it is the pre‐eminent method of regulating industrial relations.

The protection provided by our industrial relations system is to be removed to allow the free interplay of market forces. The bill goes much further than merely providing the choice the coalition members claim. It systematically dismantles any protection against the power of the employer in the relationship by undermining collective bargaining, restricting the rights and roles of trade unions, emasculating the role of the industrial commission and shrouding the agreement processes in secrecy.

I cannot in this speech discuss the areas that I think will be the key issues of debate in the Senate when we get commence the committee stages of this bill because I am unaware of what concessions the government has made in its secret negotiations with the Democrats. So I have to stick to generalities at this stage because, unlike Senator Macdonald, I know as everyone else does that the bill will not be passed in its entirety.

The fundamental dispute in this debate, in my view, is the withdrawal of legislative support for the encouragement and promotion of collective bargaining and the bill's replacement of that approach by giving primacy to individual workplace agreements. Those of us who support collective bargaining start from the premise that an individual employee or prospective employee is at a power disadvantage in negotiating employment conditions with their employer. By joining together in a union workers can bargain collectively with their employer and a more equal power relationship is established. That is why, as part of regulating industrial relations in this country, we have always provided positive encouragement for the formation and activities of unions. As a counter measure we have always then sought to regulate their activities and make them accountable.

Employers and those who represent their interests have long feared the impact of the combination of workers and collective action. The English combination acts were designed to prevent workers combining in order to advocate their rights. Civilised society has long since recognised the fundamental importance of collective bargaining in redressing the unfair power balance faced by individual workers in dealing with their employers. Australia's international obligations to encourage and promote collective bargaining are clear and unequivocal. These obligations include support for the principle that collective representation and collective agreements or awards should be promoted and encouraged, and have primacy over individual representation and individual agreements.

Secondly, that employees and their unions must be lawfully able to engage in industrial action to support and advance claims made in the bargaining process. Thirdly, in keeping with the principles of freedom of association and the right to negotiate freely about terms and conditions of employment, the scope of collective agreements ought not to be restricted by the authorities.

This bill clearly fails to give effect to these principles and fails to honour Australia's international obligations. The bill instead gives primacy to individual contracts of employment. These individual contracts are no longer an adjunct established over and above award entitlements but will be encouraged as a superior method of regulating industrial relations. The framework of the bill provides encouragement for the development of Australian workplace agreements negotiated without the involvement of unions and largely without the involvement of the Industrial Relations Commission.

Conservatives always seek to represent this attack on workers' rights to act collectively as redressing the imbalance that they claim was brought about by the power of unions. If they are to justify this bill, they must do more than assert that unions are too powerful. They must establish their case that an individual worker or job applicant in seeking an employment contract with an employer is not in an unequal bargaining position. I accept that in cases of highly skilled workers who might have skills that are in demand this is not always the case; but at a time of 8½ per cent unemployment, it is the case for most workers in Australian society.

Therefore, those that argue for individual employment contracts without an award or safety net argue, in my view, for the institutionalisation of unfair bargains in the workplace. They represent sectional employers interests and not the broader community interests that this parliament should be concerning itself with.

Many other provisions of the bill serve to confirm the point that there is no obligation on the employer to bargain at all let alone in good faith. The bill severely curtails workers' ability to seek third party intervention in the case of a dispute, a worker's right to take industrial action is curtailed and the rights of unions to organise are severely restricted and limited. The bill is about removing the 90‐year‐old protection of workers from exploitation in individual bargaining situations where the employer enjoys superior bargaining power.

It is not purely for parochial reasons that I now turn to a discussion of industrial legislation in my own state of Western Australia. There are a number of good reasons why a discussion of the experience in WA under the State Workplace Agreements Act 1993 and the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act 1993 are highly relevant.

Firstly, the provisions of those two acts are similar to those contained in the workplace relations bill. Secondly, John Howard's stated view is that he `would like to see, throughout Australia, an industrial relations system that is largely similar to what the coalition government has implemented in Western Australia'. Thirdly, the workplace relations bill provides that a registered agreement in a state jurisdiction overrides a federal award.

Therefore, the bill not only seeks to reflect the system of primacy of individual contracts contained in the WA act, it gives further effect to that system by providing for it to operate additionally in the place of any federal award. The bill will institutionalise and encourage individual work contracts permitted under the WA legislation.

Fourthly, the claims made on behalf of this bill are largely the same as those made on behalf of the WA legislation at the time of its introduction. Claims, I might add, that are not seriously argued by anyone these days. Pre‐eminent among those claims are that: the employees will be offered choice and flexibility in the workplace; and that no employee will lose wages or be worse off as a result of the legislation. The WA experience clearly proves that those claims cannot be met. The experience of WA workers is quite different to that claimed by proponents of this bill.

There is a difficulty in establishing the case either way based on the experience in Western Australia because of secrecy provisions similar to those contained in this bill. It is very hard to get a clear analysis of the impact of workplace agreements in Western Australia. I and my office have done a lot of work collecting case studies, examining their impact and comparing them with the relevant awards. A number of other groups have tried to do the same. But you have to search out and get private access to those agreements because they are not publicly available.

I want to make it clear that there is a dichotomy in experience of workplace agreements under the WA legislation. The first group is that in highly unionised, well paid employment areas where a number of employers have successfully bought out the role of unions. They have gone to a group of workers and said, `In return for you signing individual workplace agreements, we will increase your total rate of pay and conditions instead of the award or agreement system that was in place.' That has been the experience in a number of mining company operations. It has largely occurred in cases where there were highly unionised work forces on very good wages and conditions. Some of those people would see the system as having delivered them benefits because their individual contract is now superior to that of the award. Employers have decided, to rid themselves of unions, by paying, in some cases, a very high price.

There is a real dichotomy in the system because the experience of the low paid and the unskilled is quite different. Their experiences under workplace agreements are more those of having been exploited, having their conditions reduced and having very little ability to negotiate those conditions.

The key issue advocated on behalf of this bill, as with the WA legislation, is this argument about choice. In Western Australia the legislation was much heralded as providing choice for employees. But a legal opinion written by Ian Viner QC and Regno Le Maire QC for the trades and labour council clearly established that there was no protection and no choice for employees under the WA legislation. They could sign or resign; they could sign a contract or not accept a job; and no recourse was available to them. Our experience has been that there has been no recourse for these individuals.

Large numbers of people in Western Australia have gone public on their experiences under the individual contract system explaining where they have been refused a job because they refused to take a workplace agreement, or where they had their conditions diminished as a result of being forced to sign a workplace agreement if they wanted to take or retain a job. It is now common to see signs in shop windows which make it clear that if you want to apply for a job in that particular shop or establishment, you will be required to sign a workplace agreement.

No‐one seriously argues any longer that there is a choice for employees in Western Australia. They either take the agreement, which is in many cases inferior to the award, or they do not get or keep the job. Many employees are now faced by standardised contracts drawn up by organisations such as the WA chamber of industry. All the employer does is fill in the amount of the hourly rate and hand it to the employee. Some contracts are less than a page long and barely cover the most basic conditions. It is clearly established that the contracts in place in Western Australia provide for a `sign or resign' situation or a `sign or no job' situation in terms of individual workplace agreements.

This bill gives legitimacy to those contracts. This bill seeks to replicate them and it seeks to give force to their operation in Western Australia so that even a federal award properly obtained can be overridden by a worker signing an individual contract placed before them by an employer. The government is seeking by this bill to institutionalise and further spread the workplace agreements experience we have had in Western Australia, an experience which leaves no choice to employees, which leaves them in a totally unequal bargaining position and which has seen many thousands of Western Australian workers exploited.

The other claim often made in support of the bill is that no worker will be worse off. But this bill does nothing to provide minimum conditions for those on workplace agreements in Western Australia that will be recognised under the bill. The list of minimum conditions contained in the bill to apply to AWAs do not apply to individual contracts operating in Western Australia and which are recognised and given primacy by this bill. There are no provisions for a no disadvantage test applying to those WA contracts and there are no provisions for providing for conciliatory, arbitral or judicial review of those contracts.

As I said, the secrecy provisions make it very hard to do a proper analysis of Western Australian experience, but two reports have been completed. One is by the Commissioner of Workplace Agreements, Summary Statistics and Other Information, June 1996. The other is a WA TLC commissioned report by the Australian Centre for Industrial Relations Research and Training compiled in late 1995. The Commissioner of Workplace Agreements' report claims that the majority of agreements provide for a higher rate of pay. I think he claims that is the case in 83 per cent of workplace agreements.

PARA.BREAK: Although I cannot check the figures because of the secrecy provisions, I suspect they are probably right. My experience of looking at agreements is that what usually occurs is that the contract replaces the penalties, the overtime and all the other conditions applicable under the award with a flat hourly rate. So it is easy for the employer to offer a slightly higher base hourly rate because that is the only rate payable on all occasions. On Sun days, Christmas Day or whenever the one rate is applicable. So while the hourly rate might be slightly higher, the total remuneration package at the end of the week for a worker in a job which does not involve working Monday to Friday, nine to five, is considerably lower.

BREAK.PARA: The places where these contracts have become popular have been in those sorts of industries where workers are working unsociable hours. They are not getting rewarded for those unsociable hours. They are entering into agreements which provide only for a base hourly rate to be paid on all occasions. For that, they are often employed as casuals. They are employed as casuals despite the fact they might work 40 hours or more a week and they might have worked for the employer for many years.

What we are seeing is the total downgrading of conditions in Western Australia, the abolition of penalty rates, overtime rates, annual leave—a whole range of conditions that we would consider minimums and which the federal government in this bill says ought to be minimum conditions in terms of the operation of AWAs.

The TLC commissioned report confirms that pattern of activity and confirms that workers, despite on occasions getting slightly higher hourly rates, are in fact having their total package largely reduced, which has an enormous impact on their way of life. A large number of them are having to work a huge number of hours as a result of signing the contract. As I say, they are largely employed on a casual basis. This trend has been confirmed by the Workplace Agreements Commissioner, who indicated, by way of a letter to the West Australian on 12 February 1996:
. . . in some of the cases the agreement offered was less than award wages and conditions and that this trend was increasing in industries that employed casuals on a regular basis.

Clearly, in Western Australia, those with low bargaining power are having inferior workplace agreements forced upon them. The young, women, migrants and unskilled workers all face accepting contracts that diminish award conditions if they are to work. This bill incorporates that system into the federal framework and seeks to replicate it in those states which currently do not have a similar system.

Finally, I wish to address some remarks to the role of the Democrats in this debate. I am not one of those who seek to constantly denigrate the role that the Democrats play in this chamber, but they must recognise the fundamental conflict at the heart of this bill. As I said earlier, this bill is about repudiating the right to collectively bargain and the right of unions to organise. It seeks to overturn 90 years of encouragement and protection of those rights and, in place, elevate the individual work contract.

I know the Democrats have determined that they have a political imperative to let this bill pass. They have decided they will not deny the government its Telstra sale and also its industrial relations legislation. They have announced they will give the government their bill largely intact. It is obvious that the secret negotiations they are holding with the government on the package have not gone as smoothly as hoped. I must say I am not surprised. That is because the core principles of this bill must be anathema to the Democrats. They have been the self‐styled champions of the battler. They have claimed to represent those in society without power—the unemployed, the consumer, the student, the social security recipient.

They have argued for countervailing intervention in the market to protect the weak and those without power on numerous occasions. They have done this so often that Senator Ian Macdonald often refers to the Democrats as the fourth faction of the Labor Party. I know how much that hurts both of us. But it does reflect the fact that we agree on some of those fundamental principles.

PARA.BREAK: John Howard cannot claim victory in his long campaign on industrial relations without the core principles of the bill surviving the Senate. The Democrats cannot give him what he needs without abandoning the philosophy they have championed in the Senate for years. This fundamental attack on basic employee rights which are recognised by the ILO and all civilised society cannot be ameliorated. You cannot patch over the inherent contradic tions in promoting individual contracts and then pretend a collective bargaining system still exists. A fundamental clash of principles is at stake. There is no win‐win situation for the Democrats and the Liberals here. One must lose or one must sell out their principles. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Possibly no issue is guaranteed to get a unionist and an employer hotter under the collar faster than the prospect of changes to workplace relations. I make that statement with some confidence, having spent the first seven weeks of my time as a senator sitting on the Senate committee inquiring into this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: That committee proved to be an incredibly valuable experience. For anyone with an open mind and the interests of our society at heart, it provided a conduit for concerned unions, business and community groups—and a wide range of concerned workers and individuals—to participate in Senate decision making on a vitally important piece of legislation.

The Democrats approached the committee process with an open mind, with a genuine desire to identify the strengths and weaknesses of the current system and to make recommendations which improve the current act and the proposed bill. In analysing the evidence, we started from three basic principles already alluded to by Senator Kernot. They were support for a strong award system, support for an independent umpire in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and support for John Howard's pre-election commitment that no worker be made worse off as a result of the government's reforms. From those principles and based on that evidence, I submitted a supplementary report to the Senate committee report outlining the Democrats' response to the workplace relations bill.

It was these recommendations which we carried into our consultations with the Minister for Industrial Relations, Peter Reith. They are the recommendations which I believe will, if accepted, ensure that an unfair and unbalanced workplace relations bill becomes a positive and evolutionary piece of reform legislation worthy of the support of the Senate.

As Senator Kernot has said, our discussions with the government do not preclude a full debate of the bill in the committee stage in the Senate. Some senators in the second reading debate, out of inexperience, inadequacy or irrelevancy, have been motivated to question this consultative process. We felt that private consultations with the government have been essential to permit open and frank dialogue with them designed to overcome the many conflicts that arise from our often opposing philosophies. I can say that, after over 45 hours of meetings over eight weeks, we have comprehensively canvassed all major elements of the bill. The outcome of this consultation and the amendments which we expect to flow from it will be fully disclosed when they are finalised before the committee debate commences.

I want to briefly outline the 10 most essential ingredients for a bill to be passed by this Senate with Democrat support. The first key principle is a fair, up-to-date, enforceable and user‐friendly award system. The award system must be capable of covering the essential elements of the employment relationship. In areas like public sector employment, this should be able to take the form of a paid rates award covering all conditions of employment and the actual rates of pay.

We support the strengthening of the award modernisation process commenced by the previous Labor government. The process in this bill is more effective than Labor's section 150A process. We support a process that will lead to awards which are easier to understand and easiest to apply. The government has put up a model of award modernisation and simplification which we believe at this stage is too draconian. It appears to leave out many matters which are necessary for the effective operation of awards. Because the section 89A list of allowable award matters also acts as a limiter on the arbitration powers of the commission, it also fails to ensure that the commission can intervene to correct employment conditions which are harsh or unjust.

This leads to the second key Democrat principle—maintaining the central role of the AIRC as the umpire and watchdog. This is particularly important in the vetting of Australian workplace agreements. Workers, particularly the two-thirds of workers not represented by unions, need to know that they are not being dudded by their industrial arrangements. Every conservative state but Victoria has provided pre‐approval vetting of workplace agreements, and this bill should also do so. The fact that the bill as it stands does not do that is one of the worst failings of Mr Reith's package.

The president of the Victorian Employee Relations Commission has been very critical of the lack of vetting of agreements under her act. Many employees, she argues, believe that agreements which have been lodged with the commission have been approved by it when this is not the case at all. As a result, many employees end up accepting substandard conditions in the mistaken belief that they have been approved. Mr Reith's bill, requiring AWAs to be merely lodged with the employment advocate, would result in similar misunderstandings.

Our third key principle is providing an appropriate interchange between the state and federal systems. The Democrats have in the past supported the fast-track arrangements for employees to move from the substandard Victorian system to the federal industrial relations system. That process of transfer of workers is now almost complete and should be allowed to conclude. The fast-track provisions also included the ability to obtain interim federal awards for pre-election where state award coverage was threatened. These provisions also remain of value.

The bill as its stands seeks to not just appeal these provisions but to allow state agreements to override federal awards. These provisions create major problems for the Democrats, as was outlined in the speech by my colleague Senator Allison.

Our fourth area of concern is the ability of unions to organise effectively and responsibly. This bill contains a range of anti-union provisions which will make this much more difficult. The proposals to do away with the conveniently belong rule and open up union coverage—to severely restrict union rights to enter and inspect workplaces—will make life extremely difficult for unions.

Industrial action could dramatically increase as unions try to prove how hairy chested they are as they seek to poach members off each other. Combined with the proposals to set up enterprise branches, the confusing disamalgamation provisions and the open-ended allowance of new unions to open up, union officials can expect to be tied up in legal wrangling in the courts for years as a result of this bill.

The Democrats support freedom of association and the removal of compulsory unionism, but an orderly conduct of trade union affairs remains an essential element of a workable industrial relations system in Australia. In the committee stage we will be seeking a fairer balance for the rights of trade unions.

The fifth key principle is the establishment of a decent no disadvantage test for AWAs and certified agreements to ensure that workers are not worse off as a result of entering into agreements. We believe that such a test must have three elements. It must firstly ensure that the conditions in the agreement, considered as a whole, are not inferior to the conditions provided in the award. The test is the one currently applied to certified agreements.

It must secondly ensure that the workers have genuinely agreed to the agreement. This goes further than the government's proposed very narrow test of looking at whether the agreement was entered into under duress. It looks at the whole negotiating process instead. It must thirdly not discriminate against or unfairly exclude different classes of workers. The special interests of disadvantaged workers should be taken into account.

The sixth key principle the Democrats believe must be reflected in the legislation is the protection of particular groups of workers with special needs. I would list three groups of workers—part-timers, juniors and independent contractors. Awards should not be allowed to restrict access to part-time employment to suit the whim of trade union officials. Quotas, minimum hours which are set too high and maximum hours which are set too low all act to do this and should be taken out of awards.

Provisions which would significantly improve the lot of part-time workers—the guarantee of regularity of hours and pro rata entitlements—should be required in all awards and agreements by the legislation. That way we can prevent the casualisation of part-time employment.

In relation to young workers, the Democrats in 1993 supported the insertion of the provision in the current act giving the parties three years to eliminate junior rates in awards. It remains, in our view, a fundamental unfairness that a 15-year-old worker can be paid just half the salary of a 21-year-old, working side by side and doing exactly the same work. We believe that junior wages should be replaced by wages rates determined on the basis of skills, schooling, experience and work value under the supervision of the Industrial Relations Commission. My colleague Senator Stott Despoja has already outlined our views on this.

In relation to independent contractors, the Democrats believe that there should be access to a low cost dispute resolution process, allowing contractors and other small businesses to challenge unfair contracts. Such a jurisdiction could be modelled on the provisions in the New South Wales and Queensland acts—inserted, I might add, by conservative governments. The prospect of repealing the provisions in the Industrial Relations Act for independent contractors and replacing them with nothing but the common law is, in my view, simply bad policy.

The seventh key principle is enforcement. The Democrats believe that the flip side of allowing responsible unions to organise without undue restriction is that irresponsible unionism, irresponsible industrial action, is subject to appropriate and effective directions. The commission does now have the power to make orders, but too often unions have ignored commission orders. The Democrats believe that the powers of enforcement of AIRC orders need to be strengthened.

We are also prepared to review the operation of current secondary boycott provisions inserted three years ago to ensure that they are working effectively. In doing so, we would always insist that the enforcement provisions properly balance the commercial considerations of the employer and the industrial considerations of the dispute, particularly boycotts that are essentially primary in nature. We will oppose the extension of secondary boycott provisions to cover consumer and environmental boycotts and primary boycotts. To pick up such provisions in the Trade Practices Act or the Industrial Relations Act and to threaten environmental protesters or consumer lobbyists with injunctions, contempt of court and civil damages is, in our view, a draconian restriction on the right to peaceful protest and must be opposed.

The eighth key principle is ensuring that the industrial relations system is responsive to the needs of small business. I have already spoken about the need to put some teeth into the modernisation of the award system. Given that the majority of small businesses rely on the award system for key information about the labour market, this is vitally important. But I think we should also be encouraging small business to improve their workplace relations and arrangements through formalised but low cost enterprise bargaining. Small businesses wanting to negotiate an agreement at present face high potential costs engaging consultants or employer bodies to assist them.

The absence of unions from this sector—90 per cent of small business employees are not in unions, just as 70 per cent of small businesses are not in employer organisations—means deals are often done in an information vacuum to the detriment of both parties. The Democrats believe that a pro-active employment advocate, geared specifically to the needs of this growing non-unionised sector, could play a major role in encouraging and mediating quality enterprise agreements for small business.

The ninth key principle, also important to small business, is reform of unfair dismissals. The Democrats support the thrust of the government's legislation, provided the government guarantees that the system will still be open to Victorian employees. There are only a few minor technical issues which we will deal with in the committee stage.

BREAK.PARA: The tenth and final principle is ensuring that the bill improves the balance between work and family responsibilities. The overall package of principles I have outlined will go some way to achieving this, but more pro-active measures should also be enacted to ensure that this important object of the bill actually means something. This we believe should be developed as an effective role of the employment advocate.

The Democrats will be proposing a number of amendments in the committee stage. These are still being developed in discussions with the government, the Department of Industrial Relations, the ACTU, the ACCI and others. We aim to ensure, through our consultations with government and through our amendments, that the bill is fair and balanced while moving reform of industrial relations and workplace practices forward.

We want to ensure that the capacity for productivity improvement is maximised by this bill, while also ensuring that workers and their families are adequately protected. That balancing act is not an easy one. I do not expect to win any popularity contests by attempting it. My aim, and the aim of the Democrats, is to ensure that the review of this legislation is governed by good policy and practicality, not by ideology or political grandstanding. I am confident that the result of the committee stage review by the Senate will be a much fairer and more workable bill than the one presently before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak on this bill, but since the minister, Senator Hill, will be coming into the chamber in a couple of minutes, I think it is appropriate for me to speak rather than to finish the debate off now.

PARA.BREAK: I make a couple of points. I did attend the hearing on this bill in Hobart. I was certainly impressed by the evidence given by the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce. They put forward some very telling points.
