I was rather amused—and this seemed to be the case around a lot of the other hearings—that the local unions had private meetings with the Labor members of the committee outside to put their points of view rather than put them inside. I did take note of the excellent evi dence that was given by the Trades and Labour Council in Hobart. I am just trying to think of a name.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you know them all?
—I do not know them all by name, Senator. I was just trying to think who has taken over the position of secretary to the Trades and Labour Council down there, replacing Jim Bacon.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been something like 13 speakers since we started re‐debating this bill. Most of them, naturally, have come from the opposition side. Obviously, as has been said before in debate here on vested interests, most of the senators on the other side do have a trade union background, so it is not unusual that they should be commenting at length on this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! You must know something about the bill.
—Yes, there is a lot about the bill. The unfair dismissal laws are certainly in need of change. Like my colleague, who I heard earlier—
—You have to be able to say more than him on the bill.

—Oh, no, Senator Ian Macdonald was making the point that, wherever he goes in Queensland, he gets a lot of people asking about that. To those senators over on the other side who may be interested, I relate the story of a hairdresser next to my office.
—That is a touchy subject—the hairdressers.

—The hairdresser had an employee who was working in his shop and stealing money. He dismissed her, she took him to the tribunal and he had to reinstate her. Unfortunately, the same thing happened again further down the track. It ended up that he went to court twice. He is now being charged. It has cost him the best part of $30,000. Those kinds of things just have to be taken out and that is why these unfair dismissal laws are creating such a problem for small businesses.
—What a lot of garbage.

—Well, you go and talk to the small businesses, Senator Forshaw, and see what they have to say. The major complaint they have about the industrial relations laws are the unfair dismissal laws. They are working against small business. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

Unfortunately, Senator Brown has, as a result of that resolution, sought to misrepresent the government's position on East Timor. I think it is important that the government's position, although it is well known by all, is nevertheless restated on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The Foreign Minister offered congratulations to the Nobel Laureates upon hearing of the award's conferment
. the Government shares with the Laureates a commitment to a peaceful East Timor
We hope this award will stimulate the parties concerned to make further efforts to resolve outstanding differences.
For its part, the Australian Government will continue to support efforts to reach a just and internationally acceptable solution of the East Timor issue
Successive Australian Governments have recognised Indonesia's sovereignty over East Timor since 1979.

There has been no change to the Government's policy on East Timor including the East Timorese right of self‐determination. From the outset, in 1975/6 Australia made it clear that it did not approve of the way in which Indonesia incorporated East Timor into Indonesia, but we do acknowledge that any form of self‐determination will need the cooperation of the Indonesian Government
. how that might be exercised is a matter for the UN, working with the parties concerned
This Government believes—as has its predecessors over the last 17 years
. that the best means of bringing about positive change in East Timor and encouraging peace is by recognising the reality of Indonesian sovereignty

PARA.TAB: . that in no way indicates approval of the way Indonesia incorporated East Timor into Indonesia
. nor does it derogate from the Government's recognition of the valiant efforts of Timorese who fought alongside Australian soldiers during World War II.

The Government believes that there are several aspects of the currently unsatisfactory situation in the territory which clearly need to be addressed by the Indonesian Government

The Commission's Report includes sensible recommendations concerning follow up action in a number of areas; in particular it calls for

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity today to address the issue of statehood for the Northern Territory. As a senator for the Northern Territory, I am pleased to take this opportunity—and I will seek leave at the end of my speech to do this—to table the final draft constitution for the Northern Territory, which has been prepared by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly's Sessional Committee on Constitutional Development. I will also seek leave to table an accompanying speech that the chairman of the committee, the Hon. Steve Hatton MLA, delivered in the Northern Territory parliament when the final draft constitution was tabled in August.

SPEECH.PARA: My interest in tabling the final draft constitution and Mr Hatton's speech in this place is twofold. Firstly, it is to inform my fellow senators and members of the House of Representatives of the progress the Northern Territory parliament has made in the area of constitutional development. Secondly, and more importantly, it is to highlight the futility of the current debate surrounding the proposal that the federal parliament override the Northern Territory parliament's legislative capacity in light of the Territory's current move towards statehood. I refer very particularly to the debate that is currently being proposed in the House of Representatives on the matter of voluntary euthanasia.

PARA.BREAK: Upon attaining statehood, the parliament of the Northern Territory will be within its rights, as all states currently are, to legislate without interference from the federal par liament. Given the constitutional maturity of the territory that I would argue very strongly for, I envisage—as do my Northern Territory parliamentary colleagues—that statehood for the Northern Territory will not be too far over the horizon.

SPEECH.PARA: This is certainly a view held strongly by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Shane Stone, whose leadership in recent years has steered the Northern Territory on a new and determined course towards statehood.

I would now like to take some time to examine a number of the unique features of this final draft constitution before revisiting the significance of the Northern Territory's constitutional maturity in relation to this parliament.

The Northern Territory has a proud history of constitutional development as progressed by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly since its inception in 1974. At that time, I was personally involved in the Northern Territory parliament as a member of the initial working party on constitutional issues which involved the federal and Northern Territory parliaments.

In 1978, self-government was achieved under the Everingham‐Perron leadership. Since 1985, the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly's Sessional Committee on Constitutional Development has published a number of discussion and information papers in the lead‐up to the tabling of the final draft constitution. Mr Hatton said when tabling the document in August:
The process of constitution‐making should be an open, democratic process, with maximum opportunity for input by all the community.

Many of the unique features of the final draft constitution are a testament to this open consultative process—acknowledging the territory's cultural diversity and, perhaps most importantly, acknowledging the affinity the Aboriginal people of the area have with the Northern Territory. The first paragraph of the preamble reads:

Before the proclamation of the colony of New South Wales in 1788 and since immemorial all or most of the geographical area of Australia that now constitutes the Northern Territory of Australia (the Northern Territory) was occupied by various groups of Aboriginal people under an orderly and mutually recognised system of governance and laws by which they lived and defined their relationships between each other, with the land and with their natural and spiritual environment.
This will be the first Australian constitution to acknowledge the prior existence of Aboriginal society.

Throughout the consultative process, the committee received a great deal of representations from Aboriginal people who were concerned about the implications statehood would have on issues such as land rights and the protection of sacred sites. In order to safeguard existing Aboriginal interests and rights from amendment by future state parliaments of the Northern Territory, the committee has borrowed the concept of `organic law' from the Papua New Guinea system of government.

In the transition towards statehood, the committee has envisaged that existing Commonwealth acts pertinent to the interests of Aboriginal people, for example the Land Rights Act, will be transferred across to the Northern Territory and be enacted as organic law. The concept of organic law, as it applies in this context, was explained by Mr Hatton in his tabling speech as follows:

. . . such a law can only be amended in the future with bipartisan support under a special majority in the parliament, and following extensive opportunities for public debate and after inquiry and report by a standing parliamentary committee.

The final draft constitution also suggests that Aboriginal customary law be recognised as having the same constitutional status as common law. With Aboriginal people constituting over 25 per cent of the population of the Northern Territory, this is a very important initiative. Customary law remains an integral part of the lives and social order of many Aboriginal people in the territory and, as such, should be recognised within the constitution of the Northern Territory. The final draft constitution states that Aboriginal customary law `shall be recognised as a source of law in the Northern Territory'. In his tabling speech, Mr Hatton explained:

. . . this is not a `two law' concept. Rather, it is designed to recognise that the Aboriginal people in the territory are presently faced with two systems of laws, one recognised by our existing constitu tional system and one that in the main is not presently recognised, and can put these people in a position of double jeopardy. The challenge before us is to bring these two systems into a form of mutuality and reciprocity within a common constitutional framework, a gradual harmonisation of laws, but without any undesirable or unfair side‐effects.

Perhaps one of the most unique features proposed by the committee in this final draft constitution is the incorporation of a series of rights. Whilst these rights do not constitute a bill of rights as such they do enumerate a number of rights which will in future go a long way to ensuring Aboriginal people and people who practice different cultures have their place in what will be an open and tolerate system. I note the 15th item of the preamble reads:

The people of the Northern Territory are concerned to preserve a harmonious, tolerant and united multicultural society, and to this end, it is desirable that no person should be unreasonably denied the right—
(a) to use his or her language in communicating with others speaking or understanding the same languages;
(b) to observe and practice his or her own social and cultural customs and traditions in common with others of the same tradition; and
(c) to manifest his or her own religion or belief in worship, ceremony, observance, practice or teaching,

and that within the framework of such a society, the people of the Northern Territory recognise that the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory are entitled, under and in accordance with this constitution and the laws of the Northern Territory, to self determination in the control of their daily affairs.

Part 7 of the final draft constitution deals specifically with the protection of Aboriginal land rights and Aboriginal sacred sites. Part 8 is titled `Rights in respect of language, social, cultural and religious matters'. Whilst I acknowledge the problems associated with the incorporation of a bill of rights into other constitutions, I believe the particular rights enumerated in this draft constitution will serve all territorians well, securing the future of a multicultural, multiracial community.

The various provisions incorporated into the final draft constitution, which secure the interests and rights of the broad cultural spectrum of people, specifically Aboriginal people, in my mind demonstrate the absolute commitment of the Northern Territory parliament to responsible government. This final draft constitution enjoys strong bipartisan support within the Northern Territory parliament and is a testament to the maturity of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly.

Overall, the current system of government will, for the most part, continue unchanged by statehood. The same Westminster model consisting of the legislature, executive and judiciary will remain, as will the unicameral parliamentary model for the Legislative Assembly. The committee has envisaged that in the transition to statehood, the current Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act will be repealed and the final draft constitution enacted. Disruption to the current system will be minimal, with the fundamental and most important difference being that the federal parliament will no longer have the power to interfere in Northern Territory legislation.

I am confident that fellow senators and members of the federal parliament will acknowledge the hard work that Territorians from all walks of life and all political persuasions have contributed to its development. The concept of Northern Territory statehood enjoys overwhelming support not only within the territory but right across Australia, and this support is growing. Australians are obviously familiar with the territory's track record of nearly 20 years of responsible government and are receptive to the message that the territory has proven itself more than a worthy candidate for statehood.

The Northern Territory economy and population is growing faster than any other jurisdiction in Australia. With an average growth rate of 5.4 per cent over the past decade, its growth is more than double the national average and is comparable with the growth of the newly industrialised countries of South-East Asia—the world's fastest growing region. The territory is perfectly positioned on the edge of this region to link Australia with what is widely anticipated to be the economic hub of the world for the next two decades.

With an estimated merchandise trade surplus of $768 million, or 15.2 per cent of GSP, and with 67 per cent of exports channelled directly to Asia, the Northern Territory has already developed major inroads to the Asian marketplace. However, relative to the potential trading opportunities, this is really just the beginning of what is anticipated to be a long period of strong, steady growth for the Northern Territory.

In conclusion, I recommend that all senators and members obtain a copy of the final draft constitution for the Northern Territory and give serious consideration to the points I have raised today. Whilst in the short term this parliament may very well be able to overturn the legislation of the independent jurisdictions of the Northern Territory, in the longer term any such attempt will prove futile.

I am very pleased to table the final draft constitution for the Northern Territory and also a speech by the Chairman of the Northern Territory Sessional Committee on Constitutional Development, the Hon. Steve Hatton MLA, dated 22 August 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I rise to discuss a matter of great public interest and importance—that is, standards of parliamentary and political integrity and leadership. Events of recent days, involving the shareholdings and conflicts of interests of certain ministers of the Howard government, demonstrate clearly that when it comes to the crunch, the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, is all talk and no action.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Howard has long trumpeted that he is a person who demands and expects the highest standards of integrity and honesty in public life. It was John Howard who went to the people on 2 March claiming that he would raise the standards of politics and of parliamentary debate in this country. I do not accept for one moment that the standards of honesty and integrity of former ALP governments under Prime Ministers Hawke and Keating were anything but of the highest order. They were governments of high integrity and high standards. The record shows that in over 13 years of ALP governments, from 1983 to 1996, there were only a couple of isolated instances where ministers were required to resign. Indeed, in nearly all of those cases there was no fundamental breach of guidelines or principles. But, in accordance with Westminster traditions, the ministers nevertheless took the honourable course. The record of the Labor government contrasts markedly with that of the previous Fraser government, where it became almost a monthly occurrence for ministers to be required to resign their commission for breaches of conflict of interest or of misleading the parliament.

When John Howard, the now Prime Minister, set out to be holier than thou, when he established his code of ministerial conduct, he said to the people and to the parliament that he would expect nothing less than absolute adherence to those guidelines that he laid down. What have we seen within a period of only six months since the government came to office in March? We have seen at least five ministers be in breach of those very guidelines. Ministers Anderson, Herron and Short, Parliamentary Secretary Gibson and now Mr John Moore. Who knows? There may well be more to come as the days pass and events unfold.

Faced with this situation of these ministers being in breach, the Prime Minister has been left floundering. He has failed to act, notwithstanding that day after day proof has been given of conflicts of interests and of non‐adherence to or breaches of the code of conduct. The Prime Minister failed to act until forced to do so by circumstances and by embarrassment caused to him and to his government.

PARA.BREAK: What do we get still from the Prime Minister? We get pathetic attempts to defend the conduct of his ministers—conduct which should be condemned. But, more so, we get a pathetic counterattack—a disgraceful attack—by members of the government upon opposition members simply because they happen to be members of trade unions. They attack people because they are members of trade unions, as if that meant that you are some lower form of human being and not fit to represent the people in the parliament, or indeed in any form of public life; that, some how, if you have been a trade unionist, you have never had a real job or a real commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not attack members of the opposition because they happen to be shareholders or because they happen to be company directors. We happen to believe in, and have advocated through all of our existence, the importance of the private sector in the economy of this country. But what we will attack is the hypocrisy and the failure to comply with standards of conduct demanded of ministers. It is nothing short of pathetic and disgraceful for members of the government to single out people in the opposition simply because of their membership of trade unions. I remind members of the government that people such as Lech Walesa, Nelson Mandela or Caesar Chavez have proudly spoken of their membership of trade unions—and I do not think anybody would ever suggest that they are not people of integrity and commitment.

Similarly, on the issue of the disgraceful racist rantings of the member for Oxley, Ms Pauline Hanson, the Prime Minister has failed to demonstrate the leadership necessary, and has singularly failed to stand up for the very principles that he espouses and that I believe he adheres to. But it is not a question of Mr Howard's beliefs so much that is at issue here; it is the question of his responsibilities as Prime Minister. He has declined until very recently, I understand, to condemn in any real way the outrageous, divisive, inflammatory, scurrilous, despicable, erroneous and racist views of Ms Hanson. Despite numerous calls for the Prime Minister to speak out, he has declined. Rather, he has responded by saying that he believed in freedom of speech, and that he actually believed this had somehow been suppressed under previous governments and he was going to stand up for it.

Frankly, the right to free speech is something to be defended, as Voltaire so correctly put it many years ago. But the right to free speech does not involve the right to attack people because of the colour of their skin or their ethnic background. And it is about time that the Prime Minister, instead of just waxing on about the right of free speech, actually stood up and defended the right of indigenous Australians and Australians of ethnic background to live in a tolerant society free of racial abuse.

When Voltaire proclaimed those noble words, that he would defend to the death the right of people to put alternative views, I cannot imagine that he ever had in mind that that involved defending those who would seek to attack and demean people simply on the basis of the colour of their skin. Voltaire believed in the dignity and the equality of all people. That is what is at issue here and that is what the Prime Minister should stand up for.

I might say in passing that I note in today's press that there are now some moves towards a bipartisan approach which would involve the Prime Minister in endorsing the recent statements of the Governor‐General calling for a recommitment to the principles of reconciliation. If that comes to pass, I certainly believe that would be a vast improvement on the recent failure of the Prime Minister to stand up and be counted on this issue.

My concern—and the public concern about this issue—also extends to what is happening within the Liberal Party itself, particularly in the south‐east region of Sydney in the federal electorates of Cook and Hughes for which I happen to be the duty ALP senator. It appears—and is certainly acknowledged by spokespersons within the Liberal Party—that extreme right wing elements have infiltrated the Liberal Party in that area. Some very dangerous elements appear to be gaining influence and control. I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 July and I would like to quote a few paragraphs from it.

The article is entitled `P‐plate Libs in race for power' and it deals with the young members of a new right wing faction seizing control of Liberal Party branches in south‐east Sydney. The article says:
The Mother's Day massacre of the Menai branch—
Menai being a suburb in the Sutherland shire—

as party moderates have described the May 12 meeting, has highlighted an internal storm that some believe could threaten the factional stability of the party in New South Wales. Moderates in the party have become increasingly concerned about the growing influence of a new right‐wing faction, known loosely as the Team, whose activities centre on the south‐west of Sydney. They believe the activities could tip the tenuous balance of factional dominance to the right wing of the party.

The Herald has been given a list of electorates where branch control has allegedly been taken over by the right‐wing group, including Wollongong, Cabramatta, Fairfield, Campbelltown, Granville, St Marys, Mt Druitt, Smithfield and Bankstown.

Allegations of sneaky tactics and branch stacking have come thick and fast in recent months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is similar to the one raised by my colleague Senator O'Chee. SPEECH.PARA: The matter I wish to raise in this debate relates to the field station, Chiswick, outside Armidale, which is part of the CSIRO. What I want to do is put the cause for not only the retention of Chiswick but the expansion of this excellent facility. This issue began in June this year, following a decision by the CSIRO bureaucrats, which initially was to close the station altogether. This decision led to howls of protest from the local area because of the enormous contribution that people at the Chiswick Research Station have made to the northern New South Wales area. They have carried out vital research in relation to drought effects and the drought tolerance of particular pasture species. The establishment of temperate pasture species has also been investigated. They have done excellent work in soil fertility and soil science research. They have carried out world leading research in animal production and reproduction and other matters relating to that, including animal health, bacterial and viral disease and the effects of parasites.

It seems strange that the CSIRO has decided to close such an excellent facility. I believe the original advice from the CSIRO on this matter was flawed. I would like particularly to note for the Senate that the CSIRO's action ran totally counter to a committee inquiry and report to the Senate which was tabled at the end of 1994.

The effects of such a closure in the New England area were going to be quite major. It involved the loss of over 70 staff, including senior scientists and technical staff. It involved the removal of on‐site property based research and evaluation of products for the wool and the beef industries. It would involve the curtailment of vital long‐term applied research projects and, curiously, the transfer of many of those projects to Prospect, in the middle of Sydney. Here we have a field station that involves research and involves field trials in controlled environments in a rural area, yet much of this research was going to be moved to Sydney—a very curious decision indeed, particularly when you consider that the facilities that were actually built at Chiswick, with the new laboratories, were only three years old. It was with some pride that I looked through those labs three years ago in their final stages of construction. Not to use this facility that has been set up in a rural area seems a most curious decision indeed.

When the original plans to close Chiswick were announced, Dr Malcolm McIntosh, the Chief Executive Officer of the CSIRO, was inundated with protests from the New England and north‐west region of New South Wales. Local government councils, including Armidale and Tamworth, carried out major protests. The mayor of the rural shire of Dumaresq, which surrounds Armidale, Councillor Peter Monley, led the charge to save Chiswick—to his great credit. The New South Wales Farmers Association, the University of New England in Armidale and federal and state MPs all made deputations and representations to keep this excellent research facility open.

Following the representations of a number of coalition MPs, the Minister for Science and Technology, Peter McGauran—to his great credit—revised this decision. Minister McGauran came to Chiswick in late September and announced that the facility would remain open indefinitely, initially with a staffing of 20, which has now been revised up to 35. The minister, when he did come to Armidale, set out a long‐term plan to retain Chiswick in that area. The plan involves the attraction of more private funding and collaborative research projects so that they can build on the number of the 35 staff that are left there. The government, the CSIRO, industry and the community are now working together to secure the future of this excellent research facility, and I welcome the minister's announcement.

Two weeks ago, shortly after the minister's decision was made public, I met with all the stakeholders in Chiswick, and regional people did greet this news with great relief. It is another example of the coalition being flexible and listening to the concerns of people in rural and regional Australia, which is quite a change after the last 13 years of Labor government—particularly, a change from the decision of the New South Wales Labor government to close the vet lab in Armidale. I do not see that government revisiting that decision. What we have done is in great contrast.

Following discussions with senior researchers at Chiswick, I believe that the staff level should be increased from the announced level of 35 to ensure its long‐term viability. I have spoken to the minister about that, and will continue to make the case for Chiswick with increased staffing. The minister, I assure the Senate, is listening to that argument and that is a possible outcome.

There are excellent reasons why this overall facility should remain in place with viable staffing numbers. Firstly, there is value in applied research in primary industry carried out by the CSIRO in the country on property that it owns. It is central to the Chiswick research effort. It is crucial, particularly with applied research, and this cannot be carried out in the centre of Sydney, at Prospect.

Chiswick and its associated properties must be retained. Research on pharmaceutical products for animals requires an intermediate stage to assess the impact of the product, and it must be carried out in a controlled environment where the scientists can actually monitor the research. This cannot be done effectively by the CSIRO on private farm animals.

To take one example, there is research by the CSIRO on an agent that would de‐fleece sheep. There are real risks, if products like this are not evaluated properly, of chemical residue problems and animal welfare issues. The evaluation of this de‐fleecing agent showed a major side effect which would not have been picked up in laboratories: you had to do field station research to see it. The product did de‐fleece the sheep, but it also induced spontaneous abortions in pregnant ewes. Obviously, if you had not had the field trials, you would have ended up with a product on the market that would have had that sort of effect.

Secondly, the case for retaining Chiswick relates to the collaborative research projects that are carried out by the CSIRO in the New England district and the University of New England; and the case for keeping that collaborative research going is overwhelming. The two institutions—the CSIRO and the University of New England—have been involved in collaborative research in this area for over 50 years. Both institutions have derived huge advantages, with young researchers gaining valuable field experience within the CSIRO. We need to retain that link and the link with cooperative research centres, because it is in the synergy between these sorts of bodies that new developments take place and Australia helps maintain its world‐class record in groundbreaking research. This is particularly the case in relation to primary industries.

PARA.BREAK: I believe the minister will, over time, further review the staffing levels at Chiswick. Let me place on record some powerful arguments which I hope affect the eventual deci sion by the CSIRO. The current decision to keep Chiswick open with 35 staff leaves the research effort weakened. Of the 35 remaining staff, just six are research scientists. Important research projects of great value to Australia may need to be terminated or severely reduced in the current situation. For example, integrated parasite control in sheep and cattle, which has produced international cutting‐edge research, may under the plan be relocated to Prospect; a project examining the relationship between stress and immune competence in beef cattle is being severely downsized; and the sustainable grazing system project is to close, and it will be tragedy if that decision goes ahead. This project, which is now 50 years old, has been carried out on lands near Chiswick, and it is irreplaceable in terms of the way the history of the sustainable grazing system has developed. It should also be retained, particularly the world‐class work of Dr Jim Scott of UNE and soil biologist Dr Kath King.

SPEECH.PARA: I have pleasure in putting the case for continuing a strong federal government and private sector investment in Chiswick, as the work is too valuable, and the commitment of those researchers is too dedicated, to be overlooked. Some scientists who have accepted a redundancy package will, fortunately, remain in the Armidale area, and the opportunity is there for those people to be re‐employed if Chiswick does expand further.

I close by thanking the minister for the turnaround in the position and the leadership he has taken in keeping this world‐class research facility open. I urge that the government now move on from this position and that, as well as getting private assistance, it bring back to Chiswick a number of those world‐class projects to make this a viable long‐term research facility into the next century.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that I wish to raise in the matters of public interest debate this afternoon is the ever mounting and growing bill occasioned by the taxpayers of Australia as a result of the ACTU's activities here at Parliament House on 19 August 1996.

BREAK.PARA: The reality is that the damages bill to be faced by the Australian people will now, in my estimation, exceed $1 million. That is a huge sum of money. Honourable senators would be aware of my interest in this matter because on 21 August 1996, only two days after those events, in this very debate I addressed the Senate about my concerns as to what had happened on the previous Monday. At that time I pointed out that our Parliament House is a symbol of the Australian way of life and our democratic process, and that any assault on our parliament is, in fact, an attack on our way of life and our democratic process. It is an attack on our freedoms. I dealt with the matter on the basis of principle.

Madam Acting Deputy President Patterson, if I recall, you asked a question of the President of the Senate in relation to the damages bill that was known at that time, and it was in the vicinity of $90,000. I then used the opportunity of the Senate estimates committee to determine how much actual damage had been occasioned to Parliament House itself. That questioning revealed that the damage to Parliament House and the gift shop amounted to slightly in excess of $300,000. When I got that information, I issued a media release headed `Outrage as riot bill tops $300,000'. I can tell you, now that I know that that figure was a very conservative estimate, I am a lot more outraged because of the costs that the Australian taxpayer will have to bear.

You will recall that we were advised in this Senate that a damages bill of $91,000 to Parliament House was determined by Madam President some time ago. She then advised, through the Senate estimates process, that that figure would more likely be $300,000. I then had occasion, through the Senate estimates process, to ask the Australian Federal Police as to the costs that were occasioned by them in relation to the riot. I have got to say to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the statistics are quite horrific.

One hundred and sixteen officers were injured in the riot at parliament. Chances are that most of them would have been members of the police union, and there they were being attacked and bloodied, their ribs being broken, allegedly, by fellow trade unionists. It is hardly the sort of behaviour that one would expect. Out of those 116 who have reported injuries, 74 members have submitted accident and injury claim forms and 12 have completed Comcare claims. In addition, as at 17 September, 560 hours of compensation leave has been utilised by members.
I sought to ask the Australian Federal Police when they could give us a final figure as to the costs that the taxpayers will have to pay as a result of the riot. The answer which they provided was:
It is not possible to provide details of the costs to be incurred by Comcare at this time as it may be several years before the extent of injuries and claims are fully known.
So the people of Australia will not know the damages bill that they face, courtesy of the ACTU, for approximately another few years.

Simply, the cost of overtime and penalties—just that alone—that had to be paid because of the events on 19 August 1996 occasioned to the Australian taxpayer an extra payment of some $78,800. Damage to police property was $1,341.91. Damage to the personal property of police officers was estimated at $1,894.95. Travel costs for the investigations which are still under way were $2,347.40. They are the costs that can actually be quantified.

There are, however, a lot of unquantifiable costs at this stage, such as the cost of medical treatment and the Comcare costs, which undoubtedly will be huge because personal injury claims may well flow in consequence of the broken ribs and other injuries sustained by the 116 officers who were injured courtesy of the ACTU inspired rally. Up to 17 September, 560 hours of leave had been taken by various police officers. The cost of the investigation and the prosecution costs, to date and ongoing, are still not known. We already have actual costs in the vicinity of $400,000. It would be fair to say that, after all the legal costs, investigation costs, prosecution costs, medical costs and compensation costs are paid, all of which are not quantified at this stage, the Australian taxpayer could well be looking at a bill in excess of $1 million.

The people of Australia need to be reminded that that occasion of the $1 million that they will be paying courtesy of the ACTU was described by their secretary as one of the most successful rallies ever held by the ACTU. One wonders how Mr Kelty and the others in the trade union movement judge success. One would have thought that the extent of the havoc and cost to taxpayers of the ACTU riot might have made the trade union movement engage in at least some apology and acknowledge what they were involved in, but they seem to have no shame and no concern for the odium which the ACTU and Labor must carry for their involvement.

Whilst it is quite clearly on the public record that people such as Jennie George and Bill Kelty are unwilling to apologise, we do now know that there are genuine trade unionists within the community who are prepared to apologise and who are desperate to disassociate themselves from the trade union movement and the extreme elements within it. To highlight that, as a result of Senate estimates inquiries, I was provided with certain information which included this letter from a trade unionist. I will read it into the record:
Dear Mr Speaker,

As a member of a union, I was appalled at the behaviour and the destruction caused by those involved in the demonstration at Parliament House last week. I was also disgusted at the comments by Mr Kelty about the demonstration and, as a result of this, I have resigned from the union.

Enclosed in this letter is a cheque of $117, which is the amount that I owe the union as I have to give three months notice and dues when you resign. Therefore, instead of giving these dues to the union, I am redirecting the money to the parliament to help pay the damage that the union caused to our House.

That is a view, I suggest, which is reflected by many trade unionists right around this country. What was also revealing was two letters that were sent to the Australian Federal Police, by people who will remain nameless, indicating what their involvement in the rally and violence was. This is a letter dated 19 August, which you would recall was the day of the so‐called rally, more aptly described as a riot. The letter reads:

I participated in the rally on the 19th of August 1996. Whilst standing outside Parliament House, a riot broke out in which windows were broken. Standing out front, an older demonstrator was handing out merchandise from the shop in which I accepted the goods. I did not vandalise the place, nor meant to take what was not mine. Being my first rally, I felt carried away with what was happening around me. I apologise for my behaviour and consider it to be inappropriate and have enclosed the merchandise I was handed. I have not enclosed my name in fear of prosecution.
Another person who wrote to the Australian Federal Police had this to say:
To whom it may concern:

I am writing this letter to apologise. First I will tell you why I'm apologising. It started off when I was bored because it was my first rally I have ever been to and I had nothing to do. So I went up to the front door when everyone started pushing and I ended up in the souvenir shop where this lady was passing the souvenirs to everyone and she passed me a couple of things and then I went back outside. When I got home I realised what I had done so I wanted to return the stolen goods to you.
If those participants have the capacity to say that what they were involved in was wrong—

TALK.START.PARA: —How did you get the letters that went to the Federal Police?

—Senator Neal is asking how I got these letters. A very simple process, Senator Neal: have you heard of the Senate estimates process where you can ask questions, the questions are taken on notice, and then the department responds to you? The department responded to me and provided me with those letters. It is a very simple process. Undoubtedly, the shadow minister for consumer affairs does not know about one of these important Senate procedures. But I should not distract myself with that embarrassing interjection from Senator Neal.

BREAK.PARA: The point I want to make is this: that person who wrote said they were bored, they did not know what they were doing there—and you cannot blame that person for being bored. Just imagine having to listen to speeches from Kim Beazley, Senator Kernot, Jennie George, Bob Brown—it would drive anybody to distraction. But it would not excuse the behaviour that was undertaken. It is interesting to note—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Abetz, I suggest you call those people by their titles.

—Of course—the honourable leader of the Labor Party, the long‐term Leader of the Opposition, the honourable Kim Beazley, and the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot. That allows me to highlight yet again those people's involvement in this rally, and that the honourable Leader of the Opposition used most extreme language in addressing the crowd, using the word `hate' at least half a dozen times—saying that the Liberal Party hated our Aboriginal community, hated students, hated workers, hated women. He was, of course, completely oblivious of the fact that the vast majority of women voted for us and that, for the first time, the Liberal Party scored more No. 1 votes out of the students than the Australian Labor Party did. Oblivious to all that, he used that highly inflammatory language.

BREAK.PARA: In those letters, there was no hint, no suggestion, that those people's involvement was as a result of anger at John Howard or the Liberal Party's policies. Rather, they were part of a rent‐a‐crowd shipped there by the ACTU to try to swell the numbers. If these ordinary citizens have the decency to apologise for their activities, why on earth can't the leadership of the ACTU, the Labor Party, the Democrats and the Greens, who inflamed the crowd, have the capacity to apologise in a similar manner?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak this afternoon on a matter of some particular importance to New South Wales residents at large, but particularly to residents of the Central Coast, that is, the issue of regional development or, should I say, the lack of interest in regional development by this coalition government. The budget was very much bad news for the regions. The government pushed the purported positives of the budget but, at the same time, the tarnished items, the items that were going to be damaging to the community at large, were kept hidden.

SPEECH.PARA: Tax rebates and other initiatives made families feel they were getting freebies, but there is no such thing as a free lunch, as I am sure the community will learn as time passes. The government is putting up fees for health and associated medical expenses, for our children's education and for aged care.

The government has particularly attacked regional Australia by targeting regional programs and closing government offices in regional areas. The coalition abolished the Department of Regional Development and this has sent a big signal to regional Australia, particularly to regional areas such as the Central Coast, that to this coalition government the people of regional Australia are not important. Frankly, I am a little bit surprised at the lack of interest in this issue that the National Party, the coalition partner, has shown. The major preoccupation of the National Party and its leader, Mr Fischer, seems to have been ensuring that the fuel rebate was retained for its constituency. But, at the same time, regional and country areas of Australia have been ignored. In fact, the whole department of regional development has been abolished.

Previously the Labor government provided $150 million for the regional development organisations, RDOs. For the short period of time that these organisations existed they were quite successful. The Orana gas pipeline was established by the Orana Regional Development Organisation (ORDO) with just $2 million. This RDO covered the Riverina and Orange areas and was able to secure from the New South Wales government $42 million. As a result of receiving those funds it was able to construct a pipeline. The areas now receive natural gas at a cost which is comparable to that in the metropolitan areas of Sydney.

Regional development is particularly important for the Central Coast as a unique and fast growing area north of Sydney. The cuts to regional development funds have really hurt the people of the Central Coast but do not seem to have caused a concern to be recognised by this coalition government. The Central Coast Regional Development Organisation—relatively new—received approximately $150,000 and was expected to receive further funding before the election. That has changed, of course. No further funding has been provided for RDOs whatsoever.

BREAK.PARA: The RDO on the Central Coast was instrumental in trying to find further employment opportunities for young Central Coast residents. As you are probably aware, youth unemployment is a particularly large problem in areas outside major cities and certainly is a growing problem on the Central Coast. Unemployment has risen 2.6 per cent over the last month generally on the Central Coast, to 9.1 per cent. Youth unemployment in just one month has risen 4.5 per cent. Yet the vehicle for doing something about this problem, the Central Coast RDO, has no longer been provided with funding.

I would like to say a little bit about Bob Kennedy, who has been the chairman of the RDO on the Central Coast since its formation and who continues to attempt to do something about the problem of youth unemployment, despite the fact that the RDO is no longer funded. Bob Kennedy is the managing director of Masterfoods on the Central Coast, one of the largest employers.

As well as running an effective and successful business which continues to employ large numbers of people, he sees fit to spend his time and energies in furthering the interests of the community and has shown particular concern for the generation of employment—in particular, the generation of employment for our young people in the area. Despite the RDO being no longer funded, Bob Kennedy has continued, along with other members of the organisation, to run a forum and allow young people to have a voice and to play a role in seeking out opportunities for job promotion.

At the same time as the coalition abandoned the Department of Regional Development, it abandoned significant job programs on the Central Coast. Also, through a convoluted process, the government has cut flood mitigation funding in regional areas. The government had flood mitigation programs in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for both urban and rural areas. Prior to regional development being wound down, urban flood mitigation was transferred to the Department of Transport and Regional Development. Included in this transfer was funding for the Gosford City Council amounting to $1 million for flood mitigation. The government then announced in the budget—lo and behold—that the Department of Regional Development would be abolished. But it failed to transfer the responsibility for funding for flood mitigation to any other department.

Losing the funds provided by the federal government is not only a tragedy, it is an extra loss for the area of the Central Coast. Previously, the funds provided federally were matched by both the state government and Gosford City Council. This means that the Central Coast community was three times worse off last year as a result of this decision.

All levels of governments acknowledged the difficulty of dealing with flooding problems, particularly in the area of the Central Coast which has had a rapid increase in urbanisation and a level of infrastructure development that it really is not capable of keeping up with. The Gosford City Council has budgeted to provide its one‐third of the funds for the necessary flood mitigation works but, alas, in light of the federal government's failure to recognise the problem and continue the funding—as had been provided by the Labor government for the last few years—the funds available are not going to deal with the problem.

Work is necessary in the Wingello, Narara and Erina Creeks. Failure to deal with these problems will mean that businesses and homes are once again flooded—certainly a situation that I would not have thought this government would like to see.

The Gosford City Council now has to overhaul its total drainage program in light of this funding shortfall and will have to reschedule. The problems that were going to be dealt this year will not be dealt with for many years to come. Flooding on the Central Coast is a problem, but it is only one of a multitude of problems that regional areas have. I highlight it today because it indicates the priorities of this government. Despite it being a coalition government which includes the National Party and, despite what would be a normal assumption that the National Party would be seeing the interests of rural and regional areas as uppermost in their priorities, we see that regional areas are being forgotten. Putting this matter on the record, I would hope that the minds of those allocating funds might recognise the assistance required and give regional areas the priorities they deserve.

I have just received exactly 263 letters on this issue of flooding on the Central Coast with people explaining their concerns about flooding and how they see themselves affected. I would like to table them in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—Come on.
—Senator Neal, the convention is usually to ask the duty minister and if leave is not granted—
—I am happy to provide the parliamentary secretary with a copy. They are all on identical terms, but signed by different parties.

— Leave granted. I just want to remind honourable senators that this is the second time today since I have been in the chair that that formality has not been pursued. I would suggest to all honourable senators that they follow the procedure that has been adopted in the Senate of showing the other side before they wish to table or incorporate an item as it would facilitate the proceedings of the Senate.
—Quite right.
—That is the finalisation of my remarks. Thank you.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.50 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, will be absent from question time today. Senator Kemp is in Brisbane to open a national conference of the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia. During his absence I will take questions relating to the portfolios of Treasury and Finance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Employment and Youth Affairs. Minister, will you apologise to the Senate for the stunt you pulled in the Daily Telegraph of 25 September which featured `the Wright family', a family you now admit never existed but which received a front page headline `Millionaires on Welfare'? I ask whether that is not a clear breach of the `Guide to Ministerial Responsibility', which dictates:

QUESTION.PARA: Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the Parliament or the public.

In light of your statements to the Senate estimates committee that `I would like to see the Wright family take their case public whatever their name is', when were you informed that the Wright family was bogus? Why did you not apologise to the Senate last Wednesday when you wrote to the education estimates committee on this issue? Will you now apologise for misleading the Senate and further admit that the most conspicuous bunch of millionaires getting paid by the taxpayer are on the government front bench?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of Senator Carr's question, I do not know whether any of my colleagues are millionaires, so I cannot help him in that respect. Let me come to the matter of the Wright family. You quite properly raise, Senator Carr, some information provided to me by the department, which was passed on to the Senate estimates committee, in which it was indicated that this information was based on an actual family. That information was put together to convey to the community what the purpose of the actual means test was.

ANSWER.PARA: You will be familiar with the actual means test, which goes further than an asset test and further than an income test. It was intended to convey, and did convey, what that test does. It catches out people who are able to artificially reduce their incomes and arrange their affairs so as to enable their kids to get Austudy and other benefits. That was the purpose of the exercise—and you were there, Senator Carr. You will acknowledge, I am sure, the occasion or occasions—I think it was plural but it may not have been—when I turned to one of the departmental people and raised the question of whether this was an actual family. That was the story; that it was based on an actual family.
We discovered some days later—I could not tell you exactly which day—that there was some error in the information. As I understand it—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't get yourselves too carried away. We were contacted by Social Security, either Senator Newman's office or the department, indicating that some of the calculations as to the social security benefits that would have been available were not spot-on.
—Not spot on!

—I would not laugh too much, if I were you, because the message we wanted to convey was that this test gets at people who can artificially arrange their affairs so as to be able to get benefits. Without the exact dollar figure, the benefits that family would have been able to get I am now informed were not in the vicinity of $20,000 but more like $15,000.
—Ha, ha!

—If senators opposite get any joy, as Senator Neal apparently does, in saying `Oh, ho, ho, someone could have got $15,000 worth of benefits' then they are not with me. On the advice of that we obviously wanted to check all of the information. We were then told that what the department had done was taken an actual family but had added a couple of kids to it.
—Ha, ha!

—You might think this is funny but I am trying to give Senator Carr an answer to what I take to be a fairly serious question. The department said that it was based on an actual family but that then some children were added. As to the reporting in the Daily Telegraph , you may well already know, Senator Carr but if you do not—
—Order! Stop the clock. There is far too much noise in the chamber. I received complaints yesterday that some answers were not able to be heard because of the volume of the background noise.

—The matter having been raised that there was some error, the department went to great lengths to try to correct the information, to ensure that we had the right information. I thought it appropriate to let the Senate committee know because it was the Senate committee which had been inadvertently given the wrong information. That is, I think, contained in the remarks you made about `intentionally misleading'. Your job is that, when misinformation is provided, as soon as you discover it, you have to get on to it and get the right information, which in this case took a bit of time, draft an appropriate letter and send it to the Senate committee, which I did. (Time expired)

—Minister, will you also apologise for misleading the Senate for your use of the bodgie figures included in the analysis of this bogus family, because a question on notice at the estimates committee confirmed that the family received only $6 a fortnight in parenting allowance, not $229 as claimed by you on the front page of the Daily Telegraph ? Is this not another example of you scandalously misleading the Senate, the public and the media and yet another example of the coalition's failure of honesty in government, and a clear breach of the Prime Minister's code of conduct which dictates that `any misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have indicated to you that there was misinformation both in the calculation of the benefits and in that the family was based on an actual family and it had been added to. I have told you that I wrote to the committee, correcting that information. I perhaps should have added that I put at the bottom that I apologised to the committee. I also apologise to the Senate. If you do not take it that apologising to the committee that was given the incorrect information is enough—and I think it is—and you think it should be to the Senate as a whole, I unreservedly apologise. That is why I went to the bother of writing to the committee and providing the correct information. If there is any more information I can give you with respect to this, I am quite happy to do so. But the bottom line, Senator Carr, is that the information is intended to convey the truth of the matter, which is that—
—The bottom line is that you made it up. That is the bottom line. It is a fraud. You lied, and you know that you lied.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, withdraw that remark, please.
—I withdraw that remark.
——Without an actual means test you will have millionaires getting Austudy for their kids. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. I refer the minister to a recent statement by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, who said, `We, the Labor Party, are not yet in a position at the moment to fully devise alternatives' to economic and social policy. He said. `We need to see how deep and how serious the problems are.' I ask the minister: how does this admission sit with Labor's decision to sabotage key elements of the coalition's first budget, which has been overwhelmingly endorsed by the Australian community, and what will be the consequences for the people of Lindsay and Australia generally if these proposals succeed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, that is a very good question, if I might say. Is it not astounding that after 13 years in government Mr Beazley, a senior minister throughout that period, retired as finance minister and then said, a few months after being beaten: `We need to see how deep and how serious the problems are.' That in fact is part of the reason that they were defeated. They were not prepared to face up to the reality of the problems they created: problems of record unemployment—unemployment up to 1 million unemployed and 27 per cent youth unemployment, Senator Carr, when your side went out of government; the $10 billion deficit that he, Mr Beazley, left; and the $180 billion of debt. And yet Mr Beazley still today says, `We need to see how deep and serious the problems are.' It is not surprising that they were thrown out of government.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting, however, that, although Mr Beazley and the Labor leadership might not know how serious the problems are, within the Labor Party they do. Since the election, there have been two studies done. The first I want to refer to was from the New South Wales Labor Party Committee. Its report included such people as Leo McLeay and Laurie Ferguson. What they pointed to as the reasons for Labor's defeat included: rampant insecurity; wage stagnation and sacrifice of conditions for every wage increase and unemployment.

It is not surprising that the last one is mentioned again. These are all the things that apparently Mr Beazley, the now leader of the Labor Party, wishes to overlook. They went on to include real wages decline. How often did we say from the coalition side of the chamber, that under Labor real wages were declining? But they refused to accept it. Denial, denial and more denial. And there is still denial from Mr Beazley.
Add to that study by that body of the New South Wales Labor Party the one that has been done by the federal Labor Party. It said:

We failed to recognise or redress a deep‐seated mood of community anxiety and grievance. This related to factors with immediate impact on families, youth, unemployment, waiting lists for hospital beds, leading to scepticism about the more remote big picture issues.

Which, of course, the Labor Party was so carried away with at that time. There you have it again. Out of its own federal report, there is emphasis on Labor's record: unemployment, youth disadvantage, waiting lists for hospital beds and a scepticism and a disappointment that led to voters leaving the Labor party in droves.

Even after that, even still refusing to face up to that reality, the Labor Party expects a former minister to be voted back in at this by‐election coming up in Lindsay. On what basis do they deserve that when they are not even prepared to face up to the reality of the circumstances in which they were overwhelmingly thrown out of government only a few months ago? They have not faced up to their failure, they have not been prepared to look at alternatives, they are not deserving of a vote in Lindsay and they will not get it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Minister for Trade. Is it a fact that the Minister for Trade, Mr Fischer, wrote to the Registrar of Interests of the House of Representatives on 1 August advising of the sale of his interest in Clyde Engineering? Is it also a fact that the Minister for Trade, Mr Fischer, wrote to the Registrar of Interests of the House of Representatives on 14 October advising of further share divestments, including his interests in BHP? When did he sell these shares, and why? Minister, is it a fact that on the John Laws program Mr Fischer stated that he only sold these shares in the last couple of days and that he only sold these shares because he was `not going to allow this mob on the other side with their smear attack any chance to besmirch me'? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The letters to the registrar of interests will presumably show up in the consequence of changes to the register, so I am not sure why I am being asked that question. If you want me to go back and check the dates, and ask him whether those dates are correct, I will do so. On the question as to when he sold any shares, I think that he is probably at this very moment giving that detail in the House of Representatives. But, again, if you want me to go back and ask him when he sold shares and how many he sold, then I will do that. The only part of the question is really the third part—and that is the `why?'—and the attempt of the Labor Party to imply that he is selling these shares because there is some conflict of duty.

ANSWER.PARA: That is not the case. Mr Fischer accepts his obligations under the guidelines of ministerial responsibility. I remind you that those guidelines say that ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in companies or businesses involved in any area of their portfolio responsibilities. It is not Mr Fischer's view that he held shares that would conflict with his area of portfolio responsibility. If he wants to, however, voluntarily sell his shares—to perhaps avoid the consequence of your coming in here and suggesting there is some breach of conflict—he is perfectly entitled to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did Mr Fischer hang on to his shares for so long in defiance of the Prime Minister's guidelines, in obvious breach of the Prime Minister's instructions? Why did he only get rid of these shares when he was panicked into doing it by being exposed by the Labor Party and in the media?
—I thought I made it clear that there has been no defiance. There has been no breach of the guidelines and he has not been panicked.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. What is the government's position on the provision of federal funding to trade unions? Does the government's position match that of previous Labor administrations? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very relevant question when one talks about conflict of interest. What we have here is the most massive and undemocratic conflict of interest that you could ever imagine. Let me just explain this to you. Between the time that you were elected to government in 1983 until the time you went out, $92 million was granted by your lot to the trade union movement, and $130 million in terms of tax exemptions to the union movement. In 1992-93, the Labor government granted $5.6 million to 18 trade union bodies and $2.2 million of that came back through the revolving door. By 1994-95, $16.5 million was going to the trade union movement.

ANSWER.PARA: You ask yourselves: what do the unions get out of this? They get a great deal. Not only did they have a place at the cabinet table but they were also able to stop industrial relations reform dead in its tracks, they made sure there was a closed shop on the waterfront, they kept their very own shipping line to run as they pleased and they had appointments on the boards of the ABC, Telstra, the Reserve Bank and the Council for the Order of Australia—in other words, all those areas of political significance were absolutely dominated by an outfit that claims to represent less than one-third of the workers of Australia.

What do we have sitting on the other side? The trade union movement at prayer. Their prayers have been answered because you have 19 trade union members out of 28 in this place—totally unrepresentative of the community. It is an absolute disgrace that you even purport to come in here and represent the public interest. You do not; you are doing what your masters tell you. It is absolutely clear that you are a wholly owned subsidiary of the trade union movement. You will do what your masters tell you to do. You will not even get up and declare your interest when the Telstra bill comes on. I have no doubt at all that you will report back and get your instructions.

Senator Bishop is a classic example. He put in a submission to the Telstra committee in his capacity as a union representative and then received it as a member of the Senate and, of course, sees nothing wrong with that. They are so used to being the puppets of the union movement that they simply do whatever they are asked to do.

This is the most disgraceful conflict of interest that we could find in our society: the ordinary Australians are simply not able to be represented by one half of the Senate chamber. When you look at the fact that you have a few other odds and sods apart from the unionists, I would have thought Senator Ray has a lot to answer for. He can not only install the left wing in power in the Senate but also ensure that more and more unionists keep pouring through the doors. Since the last election on 2 March, seven out of seven new senators on the ALP side are trade union members.

It is an absolute disgrace. If you are serious about conflict of interest, you will refrain from voting on the IR bill because you simply do not have an open mind on the subject. In no shape or form are you doing anything other than representing the wishes of your masters. That is where the real scandal is in this country. I can assure you it will not be allowed to continue much longer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. In light of the fact that the Minister for Trade owned shares in BHP for six months while discharging his ministerial duties, I ask the minister: did the Deputy Prime Minister promote the interests of BHP in a visit to Indonesia in September? Did the Deputy Prime Minister promote the interests of BHP in a visit to Vietnam in August this year? Did the Deputy Prime Minister meet with the President of BHP Chile, Mr Juan Salazar, in June this year during a visit to Chile? Did the Deputy Prime Minister sign a joint communique with the Venezuelan Minister for Trade in June in relation to a substantial BHP investment in Venezuela? Did the Deputy Prime Minister tie himself to a BHP deal in relation to ANL's trans-Tasman routes during a visit to New Zealand in September? How do these conflicts differ from the conflicts of interests that brought about the resignations of Senator Short and Senator Gibson?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly hope that the Minister for Trade went about the business of promoting Australian companies when he was overseas. That is his job. BHP, as you say, senator, is the `Big Australian', and I guess that we are very proud of its achievements and the wealth that it has enabled to flow to so many Australians. We on this side of the chamber wish BHP well and hope that it continues to be profitable.

ANSWER.PARA: We also wish Mr Fischer well and hope that he continues to sell Australia's interests as effectively as he has done in the past. There is obviously no connection with that and the unfortunate circumstances in which Senator Short and Senator Gibson resigned—and, Senator Schacht, you know that as well as I do.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, my question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Senator Alston, you said yesterday:

QUESTION.PARA: There is a national code designed to regulate the location of mobile phone towers and other transmission facilities. They take account of existing health concerns.

Can you please tell the Senate whether you refer to the new draft code or the existing code, and where in particular the code refers to regulation of infrastructure to take account of health concerns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have either code in front of me at the present time so, obviously, I cannot quote from them. As you would know, we have sought to revise the existing code, to tighten it in a number of respects, to ensure that it is not simply a matter for the carriers to decide where they locate transmission towers and other facilities of particular significance to local communities. The new code is designed to ensure that there is more accountability and more consultation with the local communities.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the locations of those facilities, quite clearly, one of the concerns that local communities have is that they might somehow be responsible for radiation at unsafe levels. That is why we have commissioned the work that I announced yesterday. We are setting aside $4.5 million over the next five years to ensure that we have an independent assessment of the extent to which there might be any validity in community concern.

We are not doing what you are doing—presuming that there is and then going on from that to make out a worst case scenario, and talking doom and gloom. We are simply having an objective assessment of the facts, all of the scientific evidence, and to the extent that that justifies any tighter action in terms of the location of facilities and towers, we will take that very much into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister Alston. If I can rephrase this question: are you willing to say to the Senate that there is a reference within the national code to concerns about health?
—I have just answered that for you. I am not in a position to quote from the code. If you do not have the existing code I will get a copy for you and you can go through it and see for yourself.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Minister, is it not a fact that the Deputy Prime Minister intervened in the controversy surrounding the withdrawal of BHP from a $1.25 billion gas pipeline between Iran and Pakistan? Is it a fact that the Deputy Prime Minister attacked our major ally, the United States, and threatened to take it to the World Trade Organisation as a consequence of the US anti‐terrorist legislation that would have punished the investors in this pipeline? Is it also a fact that the Deputy Prime Minister committed Australia to doing all that it could to oppose this law? Is it a fact that Mr Fischer raised his concerns during a meeting with the US trade representative and the US Secretary of State? Is it a fact that Mr Fischer said:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia will continue to lodge its protest over the principle which sees the US bring in yet another non‐tariff barrier.
If it is not a conflict of interest for Mr Fischer to directly promote the interests of BHP while holding shares in the company, what is?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is Senator Schacht's question rephrased—and you will get my answer rephrased as well. Mr Fischer has a responsibility to represent Australia's interests and to represent Australia's corporate interests. I am sure that he would do that both ably and with determination. He is both an able and determined trade minister, advancing Australia's trade interests wherever it is possible to do so, and he will do so without fear or favour or without any interest in relation to personal benefit. That is not what he is about, and you know that as well as I do.

—My question goes to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs in the Senate. Minister, this morning you and your colleagues voted unanimously in the Senate to call on the Australian government to support self‐determination for East Timor and to represent forcefully to the Indonesian government Australia's support for democracy and the rule of law in Indonesia. I ask: why was the Prime Minister not made aware of the government's new backing for self‐determination in East Timor? He was clearly not aware of it at lunchtime. I further ask: will the government now move without dissembling to renounce the completely inconsistent former policy of backing the military occupation of Indonesia, a fact which effectively prohibits a self‐determination by the East Timorese people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The only dissembling is what we just heard then—not only then but also what we heard in the Senate this afternoon and what Senator Brown said earlier on radio today. We did not vote in that way at all.

ANSWER.PARA: We voted, as you know, to congratulate Bishop Belo and Jose Ramos Horta for receiving their Nobel prizes—and we do so. It was very generous of you to call me the acting foreign minister, but the foreign minister actually has already congratulated them on achieving that prize.
We know that there was a little half trick within the motion, Senator Brown. You can be half smart in this business if you want to, but it will not get you far.

The position is that there has been no change to the government's policy on East Timor, including the East Timorese right to self‐determination. The position means greater autonomy, as it did under the previous government. From the outset, 1975‐76, Australia made it clear that it did not approve of the way in which Indonesia incorporated East Timor but we acknowledge that any form of self‐determination will need the cooperation of the Indonesian government.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning every member of the government, because there was no dissembling whatever, voted to call on the Australian government to support self‐determination for East Timor. That is black and white. Through you, Madam President, I ask the minister: will you re‐endorse that call by government members for an act of self‐determination for the people of East Timor? Moreover, will the Prime Minister be passing that sentiment of this Senate—and government members in this Senate—to President Suharto, whose forces are illegally occupying East Timor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —That question really is just repeating the first question but, as I said, the government believes, as have its predecessors over the last 17 years, that the best means to bring about positive change in East Timor and encourage peace is by recognising the reality of Indonesian sovereignty. That in no way indicates approval of the way Indonesia incorporated East Timor into Indonesia, nor does it derogate from the government's recognition of the valiant efforts of Timorese who fought alongside Australian soldiers during World War II.

ANSWER.PARA: The government's policy towards the East Timor issue includes acknowledgment of the continuing right of the East Timorese to self‐determination in the terms that I put to you in answer to your primary question. The government believes there are several aspects of the current unsatisfactory situation in the territory which clearly need to be addressed by the Indonesian government. You are well aware of those matters, Senator. It would be better if, in future, you did not seek to mislead the Senate in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I take a point of order. The minister said that I sought to mislead the Senate. The government voted for my motion which has been on the Notice Paper for two days. I ask him to withdraw the imputation that I sought to mislead the Senate.
—Order! There is no point of order. There is an opportunity later for you to speak, if you wish to do so.
