DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

The bill provides for this government's programme of assistance to the states and territories for government and non-government schools for the 1997‐2000 quadrennium. It succeeds the States Grants (Primary And Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 which authorised funding for the 1993 to 1996 funding period.

The bill fulfils the government's commitments to promote excellence and achievement through the provision of quality education and prepare our young people for an active and productive life both in the workforce and as participating citizens in the community and global economy.

The bill fosters a partnership approach with states and territories which recognises both the constitutional responsibility of states and territories for education and the Commonwealth's role in guiding national directions and priorities.

The main theme of the bill is the importance of choice in providing for improved educational outcomes for Australian students. The bill further supports the devolution of decision making about education to parents and communities to ensure that education is responsive to student needs.
The bill will provide choice for better options for the future.
This bill provides for significant reform in the emphasis, availability and administration of the Commonwealth's schools programmes.

To support these changes, the bill will appropriate in excess of $14 billion for the coming quadrennium under a rationalised set of programmes which this government believes best meets the needs and aspirations of those in school-level education. The major part of this funding will continue to be directed to the general recurrent and capital grants programmes. The government has, however, decided to replace a complex array of more than 40 school-related programmes of targeted assistance by a streamlined set of 5 programmes, namely:
. literacy;
. languages; and
. special learning needs;
Which are included in the bill before us;
And two other programmes:
. school to work; and
. quality outcomes;
The funding for which is included in other legislation.
A strong determination to secure the foundations of effective learning is behind the government's policy of ensuring that all students are provided with literacy and numeracy skills.
Illiteracy is the worst form of poverty and a blight on society. The government's literacy programme of more than $150 million annually is one of the government's most important equity programmes.

The literacy programme subsumes the general support element of the English as a second language programme and the disadvantaged schools programme. It will also replace the early literacy programme which was due to end in 1996.

Funding is to be provided under the literacy programme for a new national literacy and numeracy strategy directed at improving the literacy and numeracy skills of school leavers. The bill will appropriate some $45 million for this purpose for the next three years.
Many young people, especially those who are educationally disadvantaged, leave school without the literacy and numeracy skills essential for further study or sustained employment.

Two factors will ensure the strategy's relevance to the problems being faced by young people. First, it will draw upon the results of the national schools English literacy survey which are scheduled to be released early next year. Secondly, it will identify best classroom practice.

All of this will underpin progress towards Australia's first national literacy goal—that every child leaving primary school should be able to read, write, spell and communicate at an appropriate level. Progress towards this goal will be measured by national literacy benchmarks at year three and year five which the Commonwealth government will develop in conjunction with state and territory governments.

The languages programme, which is the second in the group of priority initiatives, and for which more than $100 million is included in the bill, provides funding for the national Asian languages and studies in Australian schools strategy and for the teaching of community and priority languages.
While the languages programme is directed at the teaching of a wide range of languages other than English, it gives particular emphasis to Asian languages and cultural studies.

Clearly, it is important to the development of Australia's trade relations for businesses in this country to have leaders and staff who are proficient in Asian languages and who have an understanding of Asian cultures.
The special learning needs programme, which is the third priority initiative, includes funding for three tightly targeted areas addressing the needs of clearly identified clients. These areas are:
. Special education for students with disabilities;
. Provision of intensive English language instruction for newly arrived migrants; and
. Provision of supplementary educational services for students in country areas.

The bill contains some $636 million over four years for the special learning needs programme. The programme will have as its objective the full participation in schooling of students with specific educational needs and the subsequent realisation of their maximum potential in the workforce.

Returning to the theme of choice, the broadbanding effected by this bill, which has brought together a number of related programmes, will give schools a degree of flexibility in determining their priorities which they have never had before. Schools will be able to respond to the changing needs of students and direct their resources to achieving the best possible learning outcomes for their students.

In addition to the literacy, languages and special needs programmes, which are directed at particular needs in the school community, the bill also provides in excess of $11 billion for general recurrent grants and some $1.2 billion for capital grants, including an additional $30 million for non‐government schools capital grants.

The fourth priority initiative which I mentioned earlier, and for which funds will be included in other legislation, is the school to work programme. This programme is intended to make the transition from school to work a natural and successful process for all students.

The final initiative, which will be covered by the appropriation bills, is the quality outcomes programme. This initiative unites a number of programmes directed at teacher development, the civics and citizenship programme and the projects of national significance programme. The unified programme will provide a sharper focus on the achievement of quality outcomes in schooling while giving recognition to the fact that teachers play a key role in the academic and social development of children.

It is vital that teachers have access to quality and regular professional development opportunities to enhance their expertise and professionalism and the programmes contained in the bill will allow for that to occur.

Emphasising the theme of choice, this bill legislates a new and more equitable policy for non-government schools seeking Commonwealth funding. This policy replaces the attempts of the previous government to impose a bureaucratic, unfair and inequitable burden on non‐government schools seeking Commonwealth funding.
The application process under the previous government's new schools policy was bound in red tape as was the process for reviewing the funding category of those schools already in receipt of funding.

Furthermore, the labor government's new schools policy confined non-government schools approved for funding since may 1988 to a maximum funding level of category 6. This arbitrary restriction has jeopardised the existence of many deserving schools worthy of a higher level of support from governments. It also restricted parental choice in non-government schooling for their children, especially for low income families.

This government's policy for newly commencing schools will make a school's entitlement to Commonwealth funding primarily dependent upon state or territory government recognition. There will, of course, be a requirement that schools be run by an incorporated body, be non‐profit-making and enter into an agreement with the Commonwealth. Non‐government school funding will, however, be both simple and equitable.

The government believes that parents should have the choice between schools in both the government and non‐government sectors and between schools in each sector. The government has no preconceived ideas about the size of either sector. It is important that Australia has a strong government school sector and a strong non‐government school sector.

The cost to the Commonwealth of a student attending a non‐government school is more than the cost of a student attending a government school. Conversely, the cost to a state or territory of a student attending a government school is more than the cost of a student attending a non‐government school.

This, coupled with the fact that the proportion of students in non‐government schools has increased from 24.4 per cent in 1983 to 29 per cent in 1995, has meant that states and territories have had the potential to cost shift and save on the education of students in government schools.

Against this background, the government has decided to preserve for the Commonwealth 50 per cent of net recurrent savings to a state or territory from students shifting from the government to the non‐government sector.

Grants to the states and territories for government schools will reflect the choices of parents between government and non‐government schools. This decision is to be effective from January 1997 and operate at least for the 1997‐2000 quadrennial programme for schools.

Many of the provisions of the bill are familiar, as they also appeared in the States Grants (Primary And Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992. Those provisions have been placed in a more rational structure. This is a reflection of the grouping of some of the previous programmes into the 5 priority initiatives I referred to earlier. It also reflects efforts to reduce the amount of repetition prevalent in the previous act.

For the first time, the bill contains provisions to ensure comprehensive reporting on the application of financial assistance provided to schools. This will be achieved through a strengthened national report on schooling in Australia with a range of core data showing what our students are learning and where the greatest needs lie. This information will be a key factor in the Commonwealth's future policy responses in the area of schooling.

This bill provides the bulk of a 5 per cent increase in total Commonwealth funding for schools. In financial year terms this means an increase from $3.3 billion in 1995/96 to $3.4 billion in 1996/97. This demonstrates the government's commitment to ensuring that Australia's young people gain the best possible education opportunities to make the most of their future.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first sitting day of the autumn sittings in 1997, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
This bill introduces many of the initiatives affecting the social security portfolio that were announced either as part of the Government's 1996 election commitments or as part of the 1996 Budget.

The Government made election commitments to carers. It is now proposed to give effect to these commitments by changing the name of carer pension to carer payment and by extending from 10 to 20 hours per week, the number of hours that carers may spend in employment, voluntary work, education or training without affecting their qualification for carer payment. There will also be an increase in the number of days in a calendar year, from 42 to 52 days a year, that a carer may temporarily cease caring without affecting their qualification for carer payment. These initiatives will commence on 1 July 1997.

At the moment, youth training and sickness allowees receive a rate of $65.75 a fortnight even if their parents' income and assets would have otherwise either resulted in a lower rate or precluded them from payment.

The bill provides for the abolition from 1 January 1997 of this minimum payment for customers aged under 18. The parental income test will then be applied to determine the actual rate of payment. This will ensure that there is a more consistent payment structure for youth, as there is no such minimum for AUSTUDY recipients.
The Social Security Act 1991 and the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 will be amended from 20 September 1997 to consolidate and simplify voluntary work provisions in those acts.

A person aged 50 and over who is not subject to an activity agreement, will be able to satisfy the newstart allowance activity test by undertaking approved full‐time unpaid voluntary work for an approved organisation for an unlimited number of days per year for at least 32 hours in a fortnightly period or by a combination of unpaid voluntary work with an approved organisation and suitable paid work for at least 40 hours in a fortnightly period.

Similarly a person aged under 50 who is not subject to an activity agreement, and who has received income support for at least 3 months will be able to satisfy the activity test by undertaking full‐time voluntary work with an approved organisation for six fortnights in their first 12 months of income support.
A person will still be required to be available and willing to undertake suitable paid work.

The Government made an election commitment to improve and tighten administration of the activity test for unemployment payments. This commitment was made in response to community concerns that only those people who are genuinely unemployed and actively seeking to participate in the workforce should receive payment. The measures contained in this bill seek, as part of a wider package of initiatives, to increase community support for assistance to the unemployed by enhancing the integrity of the program.

The measures will tighten the definition of `unsuitable paid work' for job seekers, change the non‐payment period for activity test breaches, replace the current deferment period arrangements for administrative breaches with rate reduction provisions, tighten activity test breach provisions relating to voluntary unemployment and refusal of a job offer, reclassify certain breaches as activity test breaches, extend the non‐payment period for moving to an area of lower employment prospects from 12 to 26 weeks and clarify the operation of the employer contact certificate provisions.

In addition, amendments are included in the bill to change the industrial action provisions in the Social Security Act and the Student and Youth Assistance Act to ensure that where a person is unemployed as a result of industrial action the person will remain disqualified for payment for 6 weeks after the industrial action has ceased.
These measures relating to the unemployed will commence on 1 January 1997. The bill also contains two discrete measures dealing with waiting periods to be implemented from 20 September 1997.

First, the unused annual leave waiting period will be abolished and replaced with an income mainte nance period. The new income maintenance period rules will ensure that leave payments are treated as income from the date of payment over a period equal to that for which the leave refers and apply to newstart, sickness, partner, widow and parenting allowances.

Secondly, the maximum length of the liquid assets test waiting period, which applies to claimants of newstart allowance, youth training allowance and sickness allowance will be extended to 13 weeks and will be variable depending upon the person's available funds.
The bill gives effect, from 20 March 1997, to a number of measures relating to people who are sick and who claim, or are receiving, certain social security payments.

A 14 day grace period will be introduced so as to allow a person to renew qualification for sickness allowance, or to renew exemption from the newstart or youth training allowance activity tests, through providing the necessary medical certificate after the expiry of the person's previous medical certificate.

The sickness allowance qualification rules will be amended by removing the loss of income qualification. Also to be amended are the sickness allowance qualification rules and newstart allowance and youth training allowance activity test exemption rules so that the sole criterion for the continuation of sickness allowance, or exemption from the newstart or youth training allowance activity test, will be a continuing temporary incapacity for work.

Lastly, backdating of disability support pension, newstart allowance, sickness allowance and youth training allowance will be permitted through the deemed earlier date of lodgement of a claim, in circumstances where a sick or disabled person makes a telephone inquiry about claiming payment and then lodges a claim formally and qualifies for payment.

Due to its conceptual and procedural complexity, the earnings credit scheme is difficult to administer and is also difficult for social security recipients to understand. The limited understanding of the scheme by social security recipients puts in doubt its value as a significant incentive to take up casual work opportunities. Given this, as well as the relatively high costs involved in the administration of the scheme, the Government has decided to abolish the earnings credit scheme in respect of both pensions and benefits.
The bill introduces amendments to abolish the earnings credit scheme from 20 March 1997.
The Government has also decided to abolish the employment entry payment from 20 March 1997 and the education entry payment for all but certain pensioners from that date.

Provisions for assistance to widows and partners were reviewed in the 1996 Budget context in response to the need to develop a more rational and integrated social security system, simplify the payment structure and improve services to customers.

As a result, the bill gives effect to a number of measures designed to provide common payment conditions for older women without recent workforce experience, who either are a dependent partner or who lose the support of a partner later in life, as well as ensuring common payment arrangements when customers attain age pension age.
First, qualification for widow allowance will be extended to women who are aged at least 50 years of age and who were widowed, divorced or separated after turning 40 years of age.

Secondly, conditions of payment of widow allowance and partner allowance will be aligned, including common phase‐out arrangements, a common definition of recent workforce experience and common access to ancillary payments.
Thirdly, qualification for partner allowance will be extended to AUSTUDY, ABSTUDY and Student Financial Supplement Scheme partners.

Fourthly, there will be an earlier phase‐out of widow B pension such that there will be no new entrants to this payment and by automatically transferring widow B pensioners of age pension age to age pension.

Finally, arrangements for customers of age pension age will be rationalised by no longer granting widow allowance and partner allowance to people of age pension age and by automatically transferring widow, partner and mature age allowance recipients attaining age pension age to age pension.
These measures are to be implemented from 20 March 1997.

The bill provides for the assessment processes for disability support pension to be tightened to ensure that those people whose impairments have only a relatively small impact on their overall ability to work will not qualify for that pension. Rather, they will receive a more appropriate income support payment. To assist in this process, revised impairment tables, which are used to assess whether a person's impairment is 20 per cent or more, are being introduced from 1 January 1997.

The Government decided in the 1996 Budget to limit payment of child disability allowance arrears to a period of up to 3 months where a person has made an earlier claim for a payment similar to child disability allowance and was qualified to receive child disability allowance at the time of this earlier claim. Currently, child disability allowance arrears of up to 12 months may be paid in such circumstances. The bill gives effect to that decision from 1 January 1997 and will result in child disability allowance being treated consistently with other social security payments.

The bill provides for the amendment of the compensation recovery provisions of the Social Security Act so as to include age pension as a compensation affected payment. The proposal will only apply to age pensioners who receive compensation for economic loss. Age pensioners who receive compensation for non‐economic loss only would not be affected. The proposal would only affect an age pension if the compensation is received on or after 20 March 1997 and the person's provisional commencement day for age pension is on or after 20 March 1997.

The compensation recovery provisions of both the Social Security Act and the Student and Youth Assistance Act will also be amended from 20 March 1997 to enhance the treatment of lump sum compensation payments by using a single pension cut‐out point as the compensation lump sum preclusion period divisor.

For compensation lump sum payments received on or after 20 March 1997, the divisor used to calculate preclusion periods will be changed from the all persons average weekly earnings to the amount above which no pension is payable to a single person under the income test, currently $397 a week. Further, the preclusion period will be applied to the compensation recipient only and not to his or her partner. This means that for lump sums received on or after 20 March 1997, recovery of past payments to partners will not be made, nor will partners be precluded from receiving any future entitlement they may have during their partner's preclusion period.
The existing rules will apply in respect of those compensation lump sum payments received before 20 March 1997.
The bill also includes a number of amendments to the Student and Youth Assistance Act so as to align the compensation provisions of that act with corresponding provisions in the Social Security Act.

The bill includes a number of amendments that are designed to improve the targeting of non‐cash assistance to retirees and low income earners, restore equity by preventing cards being given to people otherwise not entitled and simplify card administration.

The health benefits card will be abolished and health care cards will be issued to sickness allowees. The "savings provisions" that allow people receiving family allowance supplement prior to January 1992 to receive a health care card will be repealed . These people will now have to test their eligibility under the normal four‐weekly income test. Similarly, the modified income test and savings provisions that allow certain social security pensioners to receive concession cards after cancellation of pension will be repealed. These measures will take effect on 1 July 1997.

The bill provides for the removal of the concessional treatment applied to "deposit concession money", as defined in the Social Security Act and the Student and Youth Assistance Act, from 20 March 1997.

As a result, the "below threshold rate" of extended deeming will apply to the first $2,000 of available money or deposit money of a person other than a person who is a member of a "pensioner couple" as defined in the Social Security Act.
The "below threshold rate" will also apply in all cases to the first $4,000 of available money or deposit money of a "pensioner couple".

The Social Security Act and the Student and Youth Assistance Act will be amended, from 1 October 1997, to provide for recovery of social security payments that have been paid to persons in excess of their correct entitlement but which are not currently recoverable as debts. In addition, where possible, the debt creation provisions will be rationalised.

The recovery of overpayments will occur according to the means of a person to pay. This will improve equity between customers, some of whom are now able to retain more than their correct entitlement even though they have ample capacity to repay, while others with limited finances are obliged to repay their debts.

Finally, the bill provides for the modification of the advance payment scheme for recipients of social security entitlements. The modifications include removal of a `permitted purpose' as a qualification requirement for an advance payment, reduction of the maximum advance amount to $500 and restriction of the number of advances payable to a person to one advance in 12 months. This measure will take effect on 1 January 1997.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in 1997, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

DEBATE.TITLE: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I am the last speaker, apart from the minister, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), on this Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. There has been a marathon debate about this matter, and justifiably so. It is a very important bill which will affect—in my view, adversely—hundreds of thousands of people within Australia, and not only workers but also their families. The issue of fairness will be undermined substantially by this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that, before the luncheon adjournment, Senator Andrew Murray of the Australian Democrats was speaking and I was to be the next speaker. I apologise to the Senate that I was not present at that time because I was otherwise engaged in a situation from which I could not extract myself. I thank the Senate for its courtesy in delaying the debate until this moment. I will repay that courtesy with a similar courtesy, namely, restricting my observations to about 10 minutes. If that is a message to the minister to come in and respond in about 10 minutes time, I hope he gets it.

Mr Deputy President, permit me to make some simple observations about this workplace relations bill. Permit me to do so from a perspective of 40 years involvement with the trade union movement and with workers in a variety of industries, not only areas such as administrative and clerical, the commercial shops, manufacturing and the wharves, but also some of the essential services areas, such as fire brigades and ambulances.

Permit me to do so from a perspective of 35 years of commitment to orderly industrial progress, to peace between employers and employees, between union and management. I have been committed to that, not through the narrow interest of the trade union movement alone, but with a commitment to the development and prosperity of industry and commerce within Australia. Indeed, the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, of which I was secretary for a number of years, changed its objective from the old one of socialisation of the means of production, distribution and exchange to one of encouraging the creation of an economic and social order in which persons can live with freedom and dignity and pursue both their spiritual development and material wellbeing in conditions of economic security and opportunity.

It was against the background of those principles that I operated. It was at times at some considerable cost. In the 1960s there were a number of key unions which believed in what the government now believes, which is smashing conciliation and arbitration. They believed in exercising muscle to the extent that `survival of the fittest' was their motto. That, of course, had detrimental effects on those who were least able to withstand that sort of pressure.

I am talking about my own state of Tasmania when, because of shipping disputes and the like, that state was held to ransom. It fell to me and the council, and the supporters that we had in the council, to uphold fairness and justice for the workers of Tasmania against those who were attempting to smash arbitration—principally the unions in the shipping and wharf area. But they were very often assisted by their employers because the stevedoring industry was a cost‐plus industry, and the greater the cost, the bigger the plus for the employers.

As far as I was concerned, I believed that there should be balance and fairness, and we should not operate on the basis of the spoils going to the fittest; that is to say, the survival of the fittest. In fact, in many of those years the whip hand was held by the trade union movement because in many of the industries there was scarcity of labour. Now of course the government appears to look around and see that there is not that scarcity of labour, that there is a surplus of labour in many areas and that the employers do have the whip hand.

I think Senator Ray mentioned on Friday last week the case of that airline where pilots were doing almost anything to get up hours and they were working without pay. As a result of that there were a crash and, tragically, deaths. The commissioner who was chairing the inquiry had specific points to make about the working conditions that applied in that area which resulted in the endangering of the lives of the passengers.

Deeply ingrained in the consciousness of the Australian people is this concept of fairness and equity. We have heard it all, over the years, `Fair go.' That is a common Australian comment. The antithesis of fair go is the survival of the fittest. That consciousness which is ingrained in our societal views was there in the last century and it was placed in our constitution in relation to industrial relations. If anybody has read books about Henry Bournes Higgins they will have seen what was being said both in the debates and the convention and, probably more importantly, outside. There it is in section 51(xxxv) of the constitution. Section 51(xxxv) is very clear. It says:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to—
Conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State.

It is that constitutional provision which enables this parliament to so act that it is being undermined by the workplace relations bill. Yes, the wheel has turned. In my view this piece of legislation will not affect the fittest workers or the fittest or strongest organisations, but it will affect the weak, those least able to defend themselves.

I believe we have been told by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that, if this measure is enacted, no worker, no employee, will be worse off as a result. I am prepared to go outside this chamber, out the front, and take a bet. I will give the minister London to a brick on, if he wants, that that will not occur. In other words, there will not be no worker worse off as a result of the passage of this legislation, there will be thousands of workers worse off as a result.

I am not going to canvass what has been said. Almost everything possible that could be said about this matter has already been said by the 40 or so senators who preceded me in this debate. I am not going to trawl over old ground but the essence of this bill is to undermine the power of workers who are already weak and to undermine their representatives. An example of why that statement by the Prime Minister would not be accurate—I do not suggest he is deliberately stating an untruth, but I believe he is very poorly informed—is the fact that contracts under state jurisdictions will override the provisions of federal awards or certified agreements meaning, ipso facto, as far as Western Australia is concerned there will be hundreds of people who are immediately worse off.

Secondly, there is an attack on the organisations of workers. The membership agreements, for example, that are commonplace now as a result of enterprise bargaining agreements where employers and unions have negotiated wages and working conditions, job security and the like, should also be able to be incorporated into those instruments under the new legislation—provided, of course, they are endorsed by the employees concerned.

Another aspect is the allowable items which are down to 18 conditions. I do not quite see how this will ultimately be regarded as constitutional. Nevertheless, if this particular bill purports to be based on the conciliation and arbitration power, I cannot see that that would stand up to an appeal to the High Court.

There are a number of other issues which I just want to mention briefly: the reduction of the powers of the Industrial Relations Commission to the 18 conditions and the removal of the power of the commission to regulate superannuation, which is a very important thing. The government has encouraged superannuation, but workers ought to have a good deal of control over where their money will go and that can and should be done in many areas within the conciliation and arbitration system itself.

The Prime Minister, or one of the ministers, indicated that this measure is required to boost employment. It probably will boost employment—part‐time employment. It will cut substantially full‐time employment because the bill removes the ability of awards to regulate part‐time work and that is of great concern indeed.

Another area mentioned in debate is the abolition of the ability of the Industrial Relations Commission to scrutinise workplace agreements—AWAs—before they come into force. Another one is the restrictions on the right of entry provisions and that will affect a lot of workers or potential workers.
I do not intend saying anything more. My observation is that this bill is so fundamentally flawed that it ought to be defeated at the second reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The debate over the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill in the Senate over the last few days has been characterised by a large number of inaccurate and misleading statements by the opposition. I will be able to deal with only a few of these statements in the time available.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to begin by addressing some of the more general attacks that we have heard on the government's reforms. In particular, four statements by the opposition misrepresent the content of the bill and the intent of the government. They wrongly claim that the legislation represents a fundamental attack on the independent umpire, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.They wrongly claim that the legislation represents a fundamental attack on the award system. They wrongly claim that it represents a fundamental attack on the rights of workers to participate in collective action. And they wrongly claim that the government is aiming to force workers currently under awards and collective agreements onto individual contracts.

Turning to the first of these wholly unfounded assertions, Senator Sherry, among many others, claimed that the workplace relations bill represents an attack on the independence of the AIRC. He is wrong. It is not the government's policy to attack the commission. Rather, the government proposes making a series of changes to the role of the commission and, in some cases, actually enhancing the commission's role.

The changes to the role of the commission are consistent with the other changes shifting the emphasis of the system to agreement making. While there will be less emphasis on arbitration, the commission will maintain an award safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions, including through determining claims for safety net adjustments. It will also oversee the award simplification process and review awards to ensure provisions are flexible, easy to understand, non‐discriminatory and geared to the needs of individual workplaces and enterprises.

The commission's conciliation role will continue and it will have an important responsibility to encourage the making of agreements between employers and employees at the enterprise and workplace levels. The commission will have a strengthened mediation role. As part of the conciliation process, the parties will be able to request the commission to make a recommendation in relation to matters that they cannot agree on. There will be an express provision requiring the commission to make recommendations in such circumstances and where it is satisfied that the parties will comply with the recommendation. If such a recommendation is ignored, the commission will be able to refrain from dealing with matters involving that party—an end of formal bargaining period for a certified agreement—which would end the parties' rights to take protected industrial action.

The commission will have stronger and clearer powers to stop or prevent industrial action. It will have the power to make orders to deal with disputes between registered organisations over the representation of workers where a business is being adversely affected. It will also have the power to resolve disputes where all attempts to reach an agreement have failed and the disputes threaten serious harm to the community or the economy. In addition, the commission will have responsibility for unfair dismissal matters in the federal jurisdiction. I repeat: this is not a weakened commission or a less independent one, but it is a commission whose role has changed consistent with other changes proposed in the bill.

The second claim made by Senator Sherry is that the workplace relations bill represents a major attack on the award system. Once again, this is not the case. The proposed legislation is not designed to attack the award system; rather, it is designed to ensure that the award provides an effective safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions. At the same time it maintains the focus of the overall system of award making at the enterprise or workplace level. Awards will continue to provide minimum wages and conditions and the AIRC will have jurisdiction to determine safety net adjustments.

Consistent with our policy set out in Better pay for better work, awards will be simplified. This will involve limiting the matters to be included in awards and ensuring that they are more flexibly expressed, with other matters to be determined at the workplace and enterprise levels.

Award simplification is important. It is important in encouraging employers and employees to agree at the workplace about matters of detail or process that are best settled at the workplace level. It is crucial to deliver flexibility in how award provisions are to apply. It is part of a broader process of encouraging dialogue at the workplace about ways of increasing productivity.

Award simplification is not—I repeat, not—a device to reduce wages or key conditions. The allowable matters to be included in awards will cover all key matters relating to pay, allowances and conditions of employment. In addition, awards can include provisions that are incidental to these allowable matters and essential for the effective operation of the award. Labor broke its promise to simplify awards which it made in March 1993 and again in its Working Nation statement of 1994. This government will meet its promise of a simpler, more efficient award system.

As well as criticisms of the award simplification process, there has been a lot of propaganda suggesting that teachers, nurses and other employees currently covered by paid rates awards will be made worse off when they move to minimum rates awards. The truth is they will not have their wages cut if their paid rates awards are phased out over time and after consultation with the parties. The process of converting these awards to minimum rate awards will occur consistent with the government's guarantee on take home pay and will be overseen by the commission.

PARA.BREAK: One of the main reasons that paid rates awards are no longer necessary is that many of the workers covered by paid rates awards have already entered into workplace or enter prise agreements. For this reason, their paid rates awards no longer specify their actual rate of pay. This is the case for many teachers and nurses. In this era of workplace bargaining, the government believes there is no need to continue with different types of awards for different groups of workers. It is true that all awards, including paid rates awards, will be simplified in their scope and reviewed to streamline their operation. But this will not involve reducing the level of existing entitlements for the allowable award matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The third claim made by the opposition is that the workplace relations bill represents a fundamental attack on the rights of workers to participate in collective action. The opposition is wrong here, too. The government is not attacking the rights of workers to participate in collective action or attacking the legitimate role of unions; rather, the government's policy is about giving employers and employees choice in how they handle industrial relations in the workplace.

The workplace relations bill will provide employees with the right to take collective industrial action in appropriate circumstances. Consistent with accepted principles of collective bargaining, the legislation preserves the right to take industrial action in relation to genuine bargaining for agreements. At the same time, the public will be protected against any strike action that threatens health, safety or lives. In this way, the legislation provides a fair balance and protects the interests of employers, employees and the community.

In relation to union membership, the government believes that, just as workers should be free to join a union, so they should be free not to join. The government is also ensuring that if workers choose to join a union, they have a choice about which union they join. The bill will make membership of all organisations truly voluntary. Compulsory unionism and preference will be prohibited. This will be achieved by removing matters which relate to preference from the jurisdiction of the AIRC.

Unions will still have right of entry to workplaces. However, the proposed legislation will ensure that this right operates within reasonable limits and is not abused. Similarly, Australian workplace agreements are not about keeping unions out of the bargaining process; rather, they are about providing workers with more choice. Unions can still represent employees if employees want them as their bargaining agents. However, uninvited union involvement will be excluded. The new options available in terms of bargaining agents will lead to greater competition and encourage unions to provide better service to members.

The fourth claim made by the opposition is that the workplace relations bill is aimed at forcing workers currently under awards and collective agreements onto individual contracts. This claim is again incorrect. The workplace relations bill is about providing employers and employees with much greater choice about how to regulate their relationships. It puts the emphasis on direct workplace relationships and on the mutual interest of the employer and the employee.

More direct employment relationships will give enterprises the flexibility to change and adapt to circumstances and maintain a competitive edge. At the same time, such relationships will enable employees to formalise arrangements which deliver the flexibility that they want. This is not a one size fits all system; it allows people—employers and employees—to tailor arrangements to suit them.

Under this bill the options for agreement making will be significantly expanded and simplified. The parties will be able to choose whether they want informal over‐award arrangements or whether they want to formalise their agreements. They will also be able to choose whether they want to negotiate collective agreements with or without union involvement or negotiate individual agreements. If they choose the latter, they will be able to decide whether to bargain themselves or seek the services of a bargaining agent.

Of course, all formal agreements will be subject to statutory requirements to ensure that employees are protected. The bill also includes significant protection against an employee being forced to sign the new form of agreement, that is, an Australia workplace agreement.

As well as the general claims made by the opposition in this debate, there are a number of specific claims that need to be firmly rebutted. The first of these is the claim by a number of opposition senators that the proposed principal object for the new act does not put sufficient emphasis on fairness and the interests of employees. The proposed legislation is clearly based on a fair go for all so that the system is appropriately balanced and delivers benefits for both employees and employers.

The objects are not aimed at taking sides. Instead, they are aimed at providing avenues for mutual choice, mutual commitment and mutual benefit. The objects of the new act will focus the role of awards on minimum standards and the protection of the low paid; encourage the determination of terms and conditions of employment as far as possible by agreement between employers and employees, either individually or collectively, at the enterprise or workplace level; and protect freedom of choice in relation to agreement making and membership of employer and employee associations.

A key part of the proposed principal object of the bill is `respecting and valuing the diversity of the work force' by helping to prevent or eliminate discrimination on specified grounds. There is also a new emphasis on assisting employees to balance their work and family responsibilities.

The second specific issue I want to address relates to our proposed amendments to section 152 of the existing Industrial Relations Act which provides employers and employees with greatest choice in relation to state and federal agreements. Senator Sherry has claimed that this amendment breaches the government's guarantee that no worker will be worse off as a result of the workplace relations bill. This claim is clearly nonsense.

The amendment proposed to section 152 will prevent a federal award operating where employees currently have their employment regulated by a state employment agreement or where employees freely enter into a new state employment agreement. The amendment is consistent with our election promise to allow employees and employers to choose the jurisdiction and the nature of their legal relationship. Contrary to some claims, employees will not be forced from federal awards onto state awards. For those who are covered by federal awards and who want to make agreements under a state jurisdiction, the legislation will provide access to such agreements.

The third wild assertion that I wish to tackle was that made by Senator Foreman, who stated that the proposal for junior rates of pay means that people will be working for amounts that are no more than social security payments. As any reading of the bill shows, juniors, trainees and apprentices will not have their wages cut under the government's proposed new arrangements. The Industrial Relations Commission has established award rates of pay for these employees, and it is those rates that are incorporated into our system.

Juniors will continue to be paid at the award rate prescribed for their age whether they are employed under an award or workplace agreement. That is, no change. Where there is an award rate of pay established for the particular traineeship, including a national training wage traineeship or an apprenticeship, that rate will continue to apply whether they are employed under an award or workplace agreement. That is, no change.

The only area of change is for new traineeships and apprenticeships where currently there is no relevant training award rate of pay. That will generally occur because a new traineeship or apprenticeship with a different work‐training mix has been developed under the modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system. For these, the wage will be the most relevant award rate adjusted for time spent in training. The principle that trainees be paid only for their productive work is already used in the national training wage, which was agreed to by unions and endorsed by the commission.

Where the training component is increased under a full-time traineeship or apprenticeship to a point where the wage falls below an appropriate level, the government will provide a top up to the weekly wage for MAATS trainees employed under the new wage arrangements. The top up will be to the following guaranteed minimum levels for full-time apprentices and trainees: up to $128 for 16-year-olds, $158 for 17-year-olds and $195 for 18-year-olds and above.

These rates are based on the current minimum national training wage rates. The top up levels are substantially higher than the top up levels implemented for trainees by the previous government and agreed to by the ACTU. Our proposals in this area will not only protect current employment but also encourage more young people to take up traineeships. Under the Brereton laws, junior rates cease next year and some employers estimate this could cost young people 200,000 jobs.

The final point I wish to make about the debate on the bill relates to claims by a number of senators that the government's reforms will adversely affect vulnerable employees. Specific concerns have also been raised about the bill's treatment of equal pay for work of equal value without discrimination based on sex and part-time employment. I want to assure the Senate that the government is committed to ensuring that all workers have fair access to the opportunities to be provided through this legislation.

Like all employees, these employees will be able to benefit from the broad set of changes outlined in the legislation. In particular, they will be able to negotiate agreements that reflect their individual circumstances. For example, workers with family responsibilities will be able to negotiate agreements which provide for more flexible working hours. Provision has been made for protection against discrimination in awards and agreements. In a particular case of pay discrimination, the proposed workplace relations act in combination with existing provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 will ensure that equal pay for work of equal value without discrimination based on sex applies to awards, agreements and over award pay.

PARA.BREAK: Australia will continue to fully meet its international obligations in this area. Dismiss al based on a range of discriminatory grounds will continue to be unlawful. Awards will continue to provide a safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions for all employees, and the AIRC will be required to have particular regard to the needs of the low paid when adjusting the award safety net. Employees will have a range of statutory protections when they choose to enter into agreements with their employers. The employment advocate will be there to provide advice and assistance to employers and employees who want to make use of our new flexibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to part-time employees, the new workplace relations act will ensure that employees have access to part-time work on a regular basis with pro rata benefits. Employers and employees of the workplace and enterprise level will be able to agree to regular part-time agreements. Also, outdated award restrictions on regular part-time employment will be removed from awards.

Many unions have opposed the introduction of regular part-time work. Others have included restrictions such as limits on maximum and minimum weekly hours and quotas designed primarily to protect the interests of full-time workers. Workers who have preferred regular part-time employment of more or fewer hours than allowed for in awards are therefore forced to remain in full-time work, to accept casual employment or to remain outside the paid work force. The new act will increase the opportunities for employees to work less than full-time hours while having predictable work hours, greater job security and access to the conditions enjoyed by other permanent employees on a pro rata basis.

In conclusion, it needs to be stressed yet again that, despite the assertions made by the opposition, the workplace relations bill will provide significant benefits to Australian workplaces and will provide increased opportunities for flexibility for both employers and employees. In addition, by creating opportunities for innovative enterprise agreements that improve productivity, all Australians will be the winners.
