SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me commence my contribution to the debate on the second reading of the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996 by indicating that this bill gives effect to the government's blackmail policy of flogging off our national communications carrier, Telstra, to pay for environment funding through the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia, as announced by the coalition during the election campaign this year. The Labor Party, for its part, is committed to a 100 per cent government owned national communications carrier. We took that commitment to the last election. That has been a longstanding platform commitment of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: We really made our position on this crystal clear during the last election campaign when the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, said on 23 January this year: `Telstra is simply not for sale.' Unlike the government, this rabble over here with their core and non-core promises and commitments, we are going to stick resolutely by that commitment that our leader made during the election campaign.

As we all know, this legislation is not just about selling Telstra; it is also about holding environment funding in this country hostage to the sale of Telstra. We on this side of the chamber have always opposed and stand opposed to that sort of political thuggery. I believe that selling part or all of our national communications carrier—Telstra—worth some $24 billion, would be an act of gross irresponsibility in itself. For the government to claim that it will be a more competitive company after privatisation is just arrant nonsense.

Telstra has been corporatised, and it is already competing very successfully on the international market. It is fair to say that Telstra is a very strong, very vibrant company which achieved record profits of $3 billion in 1994-95. It is aggressively seeking and claiming new markets in Asia. Its value has increased from $18 billion when John Hewson wanted to sell it—remember him?—to around $24 billion now. It has employed an extra 11,000 people since 1993. We believe that, inevitably, a partial sale of Telstra would lead to its complete privatisation under a coalition government.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has found it very hard to hide his intentions on this particular matter, while the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, has not even bothered to try; neither did the Treasurer, Mr Costello, on his gaffe riddled trip to the United States of America. During the election campaign, Mr Howard promised that a third of the company would be sold in this term of government. That was his promise. But he never denied, nor did he at any stage rule out, that all the $24 billion resource would be flogged off in the longer term, including to non-Australian interests.

The coalition's true agenda has been more recently accidentally revealed by Senator Alston. When questioned on Channel 10's Meet the Press program on Sunday, 1 September, whether the eventual total sale of Telstra was inevitable and preferable, he responded in this way:
Indeed it is, Michelle. It is not only inevitable but it is highly desirable.
He was asked further whether he anticipated going to the next election with a platform which says, `We will sell the rest of Telstra,' to which he responded:

That's quite a possibility. It depends on whether we get this Bill through, how it beds down, what we judge the community reaction to be. But if you were asking me in principle, do I have any objection to going further, the answer is clearly no.

After Senator Alston let the cat out of the bag, the Prime Minister was left to try to cover up and repair the damage that was caused by Senator Alston's unfortunate and untimely gaffe—his revelation. This is something, I suppose, that the Prime Minister has become pretty expert in, given the number of gaffes that he has had to cover up for with his front bench. This was John Howard's pathetic defence on this issue:

. . . the government has not taken any decision to sell off the whole of Telstra. The only decision that the Government has taken is the policy that we took to the last election. . . . The only policy commitment we have is a commitment to sell one-third and I said during the election campaign and I repeat it, and nothing has changed, I want to make this very clear, that if there were any intention to go any further that would be the subject of an explicit policy at a subsequent election.

They were Mr Howard's own words. He can try and sleaze out of this with weasel words any way he likes, but he can never hide or cover up the ideological obsession that this government has with privatisation for privatisation's sake.

This government cannot be trusted on this issue. They are trying to con this Senate and the Australian people into selling off part of one national asset to save another. No‐one should for one minute believe these weasel words about not selling more than one‐third of Telstra during this term of government. They will not settle for one‐third of Telstra.

I might say that they have failed to provide any good reason for the partial privatisation of Telstra. Their only defence has been one that the opposition finds thoroughly objectionable. The government's approach of making environment policy in this country some kind of bait or trade‐off for the Senate agreeing to the sale of Telstra is an insult to all of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just can't borrow the money.
—It even ought to be an insult to you, Senator Parer. It is nothing more or less than a straight out political bribe that has been exposed as such during the election campaign and since.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fischer, the Deputy Prime Minister, who has been subject to a lot of interesting parliamentary questioning just today about another issue, said on radio station 2CS on 2 February 1996—let me quote the eloquent and articulate words of Mr Fischer—that the link was merely a `ploy to captivate a Senate vote'. That really says it all. He was being very honest on that occasion. We may not have heard the whole truth about the BHP shares and conflict of interest, but I am sure he was being very frank when he said that the Telstra‐environment link was a ploy to captivate a Senate vote.

The reality is that the coalition's Telstra environment policy was a sham. It was always a sham to con and blackmail the Senate into being part of the coalition's privatisation agenda. If the coalition were really serious about the environment, they would fund the environment off the budget, as we did in government and as we always will when we are returned to government.

I do not believe that the coalition's Natural Heritage Trust is an unworthy objective. I think it is a worthy enough objective. But it has to be funded without resorting to political blackmail and Thatcherite funding mechanisms.

I remind the Senate that the initiatives and policies that are to be funded by the trust—the land and water degradation programs, the rehabilitation of the Murray‐Darling Basin, national river care, the coasts and clean seas initiative and the national reserves cooperative program—are all essentially Labor's policies. They were stolen by the coalition for electoral reasons. The policies were ours, but the lack of commitment to those policies was uniquely yours. It was unique to the coalition. When it comes to the hard question of economic interest versus environmental protection, the coalition's true colours always shine through. They do not believe, and never have, in the protection of the environment. If they did, we would have had an environmental policy implemented well before now. John Howard showed his true colours in April 1992 when he said that Australia's economic progress was being held up by excessive concern for the environment and that this position was exacerbated by skewed media coverage of ecological issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that pathetic.

—It is pathetic, Senator Carr. Instead of care and consideration being given to the implementation of environment policy, we have from this mob the opposite. I recently mentioned to the Senate the absolutely pathetic record of the Howard government's environment policy, a government whose environment credentials are already in tatters after just seven months.

SPEECH.PARA: We have an environment minister in office who shows no interest in the environment, no willingness to take up the cudgels to protect the environment. His record speaks for itself. He has been involved in a massive increase in the amount of woodchips to be exported from Australia. He did not stand up to you, Senator Parer, when he attempted to abolish export control powers for minerals. He has been perfectly happy to give state governments veto powers over listing of World Heritage, and more than happy to support you, Senator Parer, in expanding uranium mining in Australia. He has done nothing—along with you, Senator Parer—in progressing the government's response to the greenhouse effect. He has been absolutely negligent in his responsibilities in giving the green light to the Port Hinchinbrook development in North Queensland and he has presided over a cut in the environment department's budget.

What a miserable, pathetic, disgusting record for a minister after only seven months in office. After just seven months in office he has basically abrogated all responsibility on the environment and handed it willy‐nilly to Senator Parer, the resources minister. The Telstra‐environment link is a shabby link that has been concocted by this government to capture the support of the minor parties in this place. As I have indicated before, the dry agenda far outweighs the wet. I think the coalition failed in this shabby trick. It failed in the election campaign to convince the majority of Australians that this was a reasonable proposal. I have said before in this place that, without doubt, this was the biggest single negative that the coalition had in its election campaign.

The government hoodwinked the people. You were exposed during the election campaign because Australians were able to see that clearly a majority of the Senate did not support the partial privatisation of Telstra. Your commitment to the environment stood exposed as nothing more than mere rhetoric. We in the Labor Party made our level of commitment to the environment very clear. We have always believed the environment in this country should be supported with adequate funding and no strings attached.

We actually happen to believe that the environment and its protection is a vital issue in its own right. We had a tremendous record in government. Without strings or blackmail we were able to achieve an enormous amount in terms of the protection of the environment in this country. The Labor government had those achievements in environmental policy without any strings attached. We never resorted to the sort of blackmail that we have seen from the coalition. There was never any blackmail to flog one national asset to save another.

Labor does not accept that the government has an unfettered mandate to sell Telstra. During the election campaign we made our position on this issue clear. As the former environment minister I well remember the day the coalition announced its policy on the environment in the Dandenong Ranges. The policy was clear—it was the part‐privatisation of Telstra with a link to the environment. One hour after that policy became public I tagged it, quite rightly, the `Telstra environment policy'. We indicated that we would not vote for the partial sale of Telstra in this place regardless of the outcome of the election.

We said that from the time the government announced its policy. We have not wavered. We will not waver on this issue. We gave a commitment to the Australian people, who voted for Labor in the House of Representatives and the Senate, that we would do everything in our power to maintain Telstra in public ownership. We will honour that commitment. I assure those who voted for us that we will keep that commitment.

This is a very important piece of legislation. I do not think that the Australian community has any confidence in or derives any reassurance from any commitment from this government, which has indicated that it stands for nothing more or less than a capacity to break the election promises and commitments that it has made. I urge the Senate to oppose this bill. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that Oscar Wilde remarked 100 years ago that the cynic knew the price of everything but the value of nothing. This is a government driven by economic rationalists who are the ultimate cynics when it comes to social policy and national development. While even these cynics might have some difficulty agreeing on the price of Telstra, Oscar Wilde's observation as to its value is remarkably apt. As far as Labor is concerned, Telstra is far too valuable to ever sell.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has sought to bribe and blackmail the Australian conservation movement and others concerned about Australia's environment by suggesting that we should accept ill-defined and illusionary short‐term financial benefits from the sale of Telstra which themselves are overshadowed by the massive disadvantages to the Australian people and national development at large. It is important to ask: what is it that builds a nation? Nearly 100 years ago our federation came into being. It was just at the time Oscar Wilde was making his comments. Federation meant that all Australian citizens could be represented in one place and at one time.

It is in the last few years that the mainland states of this nation were linked by a common railway. The previous railway system was a blight on our landscape and was a historical monument to our isolation and separatism. One of the first and most significant means of bringing this country and its citizens together was our telephone and postal services. The telephone network became the lifeline and the means by which Australians right across the country could keep in touch, could develop business links and could run public administration properly.

The telecommunications industry that was built around the telephonic network has brought economic growth and thousands of jobs across this country. Labor's opposition to the sale of Telstra is based upon our recognition of the fundamental place that this service provider and employer has in our history and reflects the recent and substantial community disquiet about the government's privatisation plan. It fundamentally recognises the critical importance of Telstra to our economy.

It is based on a firm conviction that the government's claims about the benefits of the sale offered to the nation are illusory. Many will argue that the short-term budgetary implications for this sale would be of huge political benefit to the government. As far as I am concerned, the budgetary gains will be overshadowed by the long-term disadvantages that must attend the loss of such a profitable and strategically significant public asset. I say the `loss' of the asset because Senator Alston, I think, has made his point very clearly, and no-one in this chamber should be under any illusion about the real issues that we face today.

Should this Senate endorse the process of the sale of one-third of Telstra, we will see ultimately the full privatisation of Telstra. As far as Labor is concerned, this country should not embark upon that course. Our resolve has only been strengthened by the evidence against privatisation presented to this parliament via its committee, that is, the inquiry into Telstra.

We have seen that the case for privatisation is based essentially on rhetorical and ideological arguments rather than on any empirical evidence. Telstra is a highly successful company and its record $2.3 billion profit for this year clearly indicates that. Its financial performance is equal to that of its international peers. At the same time, it provides a unique service. Despite the difficulties presented by Australia's geography and its demography, Australian society has one of the highest levels of telephone access in the world.

Telstra has played an important role in nation building through the provision of affordable communications services on a universal basis. It has pioneered research and development of international importance and has been a leader in the introduction of technologies such as ISDN and fibre optics. It has played a critical part in the growth of the Australian electronics industry. At the same time, as well as being one of the country's largest employers, it has provided job opportunities throughout Australia.

Its recent record $2.3 billion profit is sure to grow in future years. The industry is growing at 15 per cent per annum. New investment is set to grow at 22 per cent per annum, sales by 20 per cent per annum and exports at 38 per cent per annum. That, to me, indicates the value of Telstra to the Australian economy and it should not be diverted from the 100 per cent Australian ownership that it currently has. One hundred per cent of Australians currently own Telstra and currently enjoy the benefit of that public ownership.

The government's main rationale for the sale—supposed private sector efficiency gains—clearly fail the test of public scrutiny, and that was clearly demonstrated by the Senate committee. Of the 650 submissions received and 135 witnesses examined, the only real supporters of the sale were government departments acting on the instructions of their political masters; the senior management of Telstra, who stand to gain substantial remuneration increases under a privatised regime; and, of course, government agencies who are under direct political control.

The main argument presented in evidence to the committee was based on a World Bank study which looked at some 6,800 cases. But there were no comparisons with telecommunications companies of equal value or equal profitability to Telstra, no companies that compare with Australia's regulatory framework and no country—even on an international basis—that compares with Australia's demography or geography. After failing to justify the validity of the international studies that had been so heavily cited by the government, the only argument that those supporting privatisation can muster is a mystical and unsupported belief in the power of the market itself.

The undermining of consumer interests—especially in rural communities—that this market power will cause has been ignored by this government in its unrestrained drive to reach the magical world best practice benchmark. The debate about the power of the marker appears to unleash the cowboys of the corporate and political worlds who would follow the unrestrained doctrine of the far Right. In simplistic terms, public ownership, according to this view, is bad and private wealth is good. The private sector is good. This is an ideological belief that has to do more with the political assumptions of this government than with any sound basis in fact.

The ramifications of the sale are very clear. Mr Costello, Mr Howard and Senator Alston have clearly indicated that this government is committed to pursuing the full privatisation of Telstra. We have a situation where, despite the fact that legislation has just come in before the parliament, privatisation is already the driving force within the operations of Telstra itself. This is particularly the case when one looks at the areas of the current round of redundancies being pursued by the Telstra management.

Despite Telstra's desire to reveal only minimal details before the Senate committee, the Senate inquiry was able to clearly identify that project Mercury was operating in such a way as to remove one-third of the company—to remove one-third of the work force within Telstra—and that it was an internal program initiated by the Telstra management in April 1996 to prepare Telstra for privatisation.

Its objective was to identify areas where cost savings could be achieved, largely through staff reductions. The project Mercury documents clearly reveal that this was where the massive job losses would occur as a result of the sale or outsourcing of so-called non‐value added or non‐core businesses within the company. You do not have to be particularly smart to understand that the aim of project Mercury was to prepare Telstra for privatisation itself.

Under this plan, Telstra is to be gutted for the marketplace. It is to be trimmed of its capacity to support Australian technological industry, cured of any sense of community service obligation and packaged for potential investors. The restructuring of Telstra for privatisation comes at considerable costs to consumers, to Telstra workers and to regional communities that benefit substantially from the current industrial practices and the current service delivery of Telstra. We see that no more clearly than in the subsidised service that Telstra currently provides.

This is the international experience of privatisation. Job losses are the most significant common theme of all the international privatisations of telecommunications companies. In the case of Telecom New Zealand, staffing levels declined from 24,500 in 1987, at the time of corporatisation, to 16,000 in 1990, at the time of the privatisation. Now they are down to a mere 8,568. Telstra has already announced job cuts of 9,000 this financial year. Well over fifty per cent of those are coming from the consumer and commercial divisions, which are responsible for network maintenance and installation. The project Mercury process has been followed through to the board level to the stage now where the removal of some 23,000 jobs has been announced—almost one-third of the company's work force. It is clear to me that the first casualties of privatisation are to be the workers themselves.

The majority report was particularly critical of Telstra's privatisation plans. It identified that, in addition to job losses associated with outsourcing, Telstra hoped to reduce staff through internal rationalisations. Redundancies caused by this process were to be `management initiated'. I note that the Telstra management is seeking to change the current redundancy arrangements to see that that happens. I am sure that, if the industrial relations bill currently before the parliament is passed in its present form, that objective will be much easier to achieve. These are not necessarily to be voluntary redundancies. They will inflict great harm and suffering on workers right across this country.

Project Mercury has clearly been identified as a means to reduce the work force within Telstra, to reduce labour costs by employing contractors at lower rates of pay than those of Telstra's current award workers, to take labour costs off the balance sheets through mechanisms such as joint ventures, to dispose of assets in areas considered to be non‐core and to release millions of dollars of investment funds. This process would fundamentally change the character of Telstra in such a way as to see it move towards a much more profit oriented, market driven supplier. It would have dramatic impacts in terms of external suppliers and it would undermine fundamentally Telstra's capacity to produce a high quality service to Australian consumers.

All of this is in line with the program and the policies of this government to pursue the privatisation of Telstra. A lot of this is irrational. It is identifying outsourcing of particular agencies which are currently profitable and are not necessarily a drain upon the company but which will, when removed from the company, reduce the overall employment levels within the company and therefore reduce the company's bottom line for the prospectus. Before the estimates committee Telstra management identified that the net impact to the bottom line profit of the company will be some $600 million per annum.

We can only explain the irrationality of these redundancies by understanding that they are the result of external pressures being placed upon Telstra to meet the head count benchmarks, no matter how crude and inappropriate they may be. It is all part of the process in the run-up to privatisation. These pressures may be coming from the views of the market analysts who have been reported in the media. Such pressures are being transmitted by the CS First Boston Group, which conducted the privatisation scoping study on behalf of the government. In the work of senior Telstra management, senior officials of the Department of Finance and members of the scoping study there has been very close cooperation. This is part of the process of preparing a prospectus which will ultimately identify the value of Telstra.

The committee was presented with no evidence to establish that particular employees retrenched from Telstra would have the appropriate skills to find work in other sections of industry. The historical pattern is that, whilst this industry is growing at a great rate, that does not necessarily translate into growth in employment levels. It is a capital intensive industry. The removal of unskilled or semi-skilled workers, particularly those over 50 years of age and those in regional areas, will have a profound effect on those regions and on those individuals. It is unlikely that they will be able to find work within the telecommunications industry. The historical evidence does not support contrary conclusions.

The international experience is clear. It has to be understood in the context of so‐called efficiencies and market discipline, which is the so-called driving force behind these reductions. It is interesting to look at the contribution that the overseas telcos being promoted by the government have made to their nations in practice. If we look at Ameritech or US West, two of the US Bell operating companies, we see a similar pattern emerge. We see companies that are being compared to Telstra as their international benchmark that have an absolutely appalling record in terms of their treatment of workers and consumers. This is a good example of the so-called power of the market. But I do not believe it is necessarily an example we should try to emulate.

In the case of US West, waiting times for customers attempting to reach a representative have increased in recent times. US West's numbers of employees declined by some 13,500 from 1989 to 1995. We see that a drop in employment leads to a drop in consumer service delivery. There have been increased waiting times for new installations, especially in rural areas. We see an increased number of missed appointments for repairs for both business and residential customers. We see cuts in the construction of basic telephone plant. We see that there has been a 460 per cent increase in the number of customer complaints to the Oregon Public Utility Commission. The service standards of these great models that this government holds up so highly are so bad that in April of this year the commission reimposed rate of return regulations on US West.

PARA.BREAK: A similar pattern emerges with Bell Atlantic. I suggest to the Senate that these are fundamental issues that affect the long-term ability of this parliament to have real influence over telecommunications policy in this country. This policy of privatisation is being pursued at breakneck speed. It is being introduced at a time when the regulatory frame work to operate in the post-1997 environment is yet to be determined. It is being introduced in such a way as to leave huge doubts about the issues of equity and affordability in the provision of key services.

SPEECH.PARA: We see that few in the community believe that social justice policy objectives will survive the privatisation process. We have seen that the recently reconstituted board has been carefully chosen to facilitate a profit driven culture within Telstra in the preparation for privatisation. We see that there is a pattern emerging within this government in terms of not providing adequate protection for parliamentary scrutiny and the commitment that they are prepared to go outside the parliamentary process if necessary so as to have their way, no matter what this parliament suggests. That, to me, is something we should all be resisting with all our political abilities.

It seems to me that this is a time frame that suggests that the government needs to rush this privatisation process because it will not stand up to public scrutiny, it will not stand up to rigorous scrutiny in terms of the post‐1997 telecommunications environment. It is quite clear that over the last eight weeks three major packages of legislation have been introduced into this parliament that are yet to have significant community debate. The consumer groups have had little time to analyse these complex legislative packages. in fact, it would need a team of lawyers working around the clock to make sense of the directions that are being followed by this government and to meet the timetable imposed by this government in the establishment of this new environment.

Of course, is it little wonder therefore that in these circumstances there is still no industry consensus regarding the draft telecommunications bills and the shape of the post‐1997 operating environment? This is quite clearly a measure that this government needs to reconsider very carefully—and I trust that this parliament forces it to reconsider very carefully—and that this is a bill that ought to be rejected by this parliament on its second reading.

BREAK.PARA: It is quite clear that those that are concerned about sustaining a natural environment, a world‐class and affordable telewcommunications service, will look to this parliament to reject this bill and to protect the Australian interest, to protect this nation from what is quite clearly a wrong policy, a socially destructive policy, which is founded upon the assumption of political bribery and blackmail. It is is ill considered, ideologically driven, based on rhetoric rather than on empirical evidence, and it does not deserve the support of this chamber. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with pleasure in this debate to support the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996. It is rather strange that Senator Carr and I actually sat throught the same set of hearings and read the same evidence. I sat there listening to what he had to say and was absolutely amazed that he came to some of the conclusions that he did. He must have been listening to the evidence out of his left ear, I fear.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us return to what this bill was about and the importance of it for Australia. What it will do is bring Telstra up to world‐class standard. The opponents of this bill like to play on public fear of the unknown by suggesting that this is a giant leap in the dark. In fact, it is quite the opposite.

Australia is probably the last cab off the rank in terms of advanced countries in the world and even some of those that are not so advanced. Telstra is the only one of about 20 major telcos around the world that has not been partly privatised or privatised, and this bill is proposing the sale of only one‐third of Telstra. When you get Fidel Castro part‐privatising his telco and selling off a fair bit of it over to the people in Mexico you know you are in a rather strange situation in Australia where we have all the opposition parties off to the left of Fidel Castro and Cuba and indeed the former regime in Albania.

Let us examine the opposition's hypocrisy on this part‐privatisation of Telstra. In 1994, the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, was asked on the ABC program Lateline about the privatisation of Telstra. Reporter Kerry O'Brien asked whether it really mattered if Telstra was privately or publicly owned. The answer from Mr Keating was both accurate and succinct: `Ah, not of its essence, no.' That was his response, and that was consistent at the time with Labor's other privatisation decisions with the Commonwealth Bank and the Qantas float.

It is very difficult to understand why you can support the privatisation of Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank and not support the privatisation of Telstra. I fail to see the ideolgocal basis of one set of decisions and not of the other. The reason you cannot sort of work out the ideology of it is that it is just purely a matter of expediency. It is expedient and it is tragic, particularly when such a sale is in the best interests of Australia.

The Australian Democrats' position is probably even more curious. They have shown some sensible approaches here today on IR, and I would urge them to do a similar thing with the Telstra bill. They claim, curiously, that they have some sort of mandate to oppose Telstra. They have got a very funny idea of what a mandate is. I thought in that last election that the coalition parties in 1996 won 50 per cent of the Senate seats. I thought we won a 45‐seat majority in the lower house—an outstanding majority in the lower house—and, in the upper house, 50 per cent of the seats. I would have thought that 50 per cent was a pass, and that is exactly what should happen with the Telstra legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you get 50 per cent?
—Just look at the maths there, Senator. If you get out a pen and paper and work through it slowly, you might actually work out that 50 per cent is a pass.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to the Telstra inquiry, that famous delaying tactic where the government had totally made up its mind. The opposition sent it off to a reference committee, which was terribly dishonest, because it is a bill. It is called the Telstra bill and, as a matter of fact, at each site for our inquiry they had a sign up that said `Teltsra Bill this way'. So why did it not go to a legislative committee? It did not because they added in a few other bits and pieces to try and make out that this was about a reference. And of course they had control, they had the majority.

The real game was exposed in this place by Senator Faulkner, who belled the cat by announcing before we had the inquiry that Labor was going to oppose it. Why waste all that money having an inquiry if they were already opposed to it before we went to an inquiry? They compromised the terms of reference of this inquiry by throwing in a whole range of issues unrelated to the terms of reference.

Sixty per cent of the submissions dealt with overhead cabling. Senator Carr trumpeted the number of submissions, but over two-thirds of those submissions were only one page in length. A lot of the information before the inquiry—even by the people who turned up—was ill‐informed, particularly as we could not find any opponents to the bill who had even read the bill. How on earth can you come out in a public hearing opposed to it if you have not even had a look at it? A substantial number of the submissions did express support for the part‐privatisation of Telstra.

After all those hearings, all that time and all those witnesses, we ended up with what was a pretty poor report. The majority report of the opposition simply ignored the majority and weight of the evidence favouring a one-third sale of Telstra. It was intellectually dishonest and it produced a report with a very predetermined position. The majority report quotes evidence from the National Farmers Federation and Australian Women in Agriculture, yet fails to acknowledge their pro-privatisation stance. There is no comparable body of evidence to demonstrate the benefits of keeping the business in public ownership.

We had a seminar in this parliament with a speaker in favour of keeping Telstra in full public ownership. He looked for examples around the world to see where it would work better. He could come up with only one—Iceland. Iceland is the only place where full public ownership works better. I suppose the telephone system in Reykjavik goes about two kilometres out of town, and that is about it. In that sort of area, you could probably run a fairly efficient system.

BREAK.PARA: The inquiry basically was a waste of time. There was no tidal wave of community support for what the opposition was trying to do here on the core issues of the bill. The number of hearing dates was cut by 50 per cent. We could not find much interest out in rural and regional Australia. As a matter of fact, the evidence that we did gain supported the bill.

It is somewhat hypocritical for the Labor Party, on the basis of that lack of evidence and on the basis of their former government's position—former Prime Minister Keating wanting to sell the lot of it a few years ago—to want to go ahead with that. What people have to remember is that it was the Labor Party that actually started this whole process by giving away half of Telstra's monopoly to Optus and then planning for it to expand further.

What we are proposing is a logical extension of that process. In every country where government owned monopolies have been changed—exposed to competition—part‐privatisation or privatisation has actually followed. This government has placed telecommunications reform very high on its list of priorities for its first term. That is why we are debating it here so early in the time of the new government. The reasons for this are quite obvious.

Australia's telecommunications sector must maintain the momentum of change to ensure that we have a world-class communications infrastructure. The Australian telecommunications market has doubled in size over the last few years. It is a highly contested domestic and international environment and it cannot afford to have a bloated and inefficient Telstra that will not be able to compete in the new markets in the post-1997 environment.

We must be prepared for new growth. We must have a dynamic flexible company which will take on new demands like the Internet and other telephone based services. Telstra is also facing the reality that its operating expenses are increasing faster than its revenue growth. That also brings in the need for market discipline to get Telstra working as a more efficient operation.

There have been some advances in the efficiency of Telstra in recent years, but there is considerable room for improvement. The part‐privatisation of one-third of Telstra can deliver efficiencies and these can be passed on to consumers. Benefits in the form of improved services—

The National Science and Technology Centre represents a very important national institution in a number of respects. I have to point out that I speak not just as a representative of the people of the ACT, given that the centre's main building is housed here in the national capital in the parliamentary triangle, but also on the basis that the work of this institution extends far beyond the borders of the ACT.

It takes science and technology right around the country but I would like to note specifically the work of this institution in rural and regional areas of Australia. Its travelling programs have become a feature of this organisation. They have in place a program which takes science and technology issues and quite successfully attempts to popularise them with schoolchildren in country areas.

Science and technology is an area in which Australia has great strengths. Nothing highlights this more than the context of the debate we are having at the moment about the partial privatisation of Telstra. The very issue on which we are at a turning point in Australia, technology and industry development in the whole telecommunications area, really highlights, I believe, the base from which we are working in our society when it comes to science and the base level of knowledge and participation in areas such as this.

The point I make this evening is that it is okay to have policies that put in place programs to advance industry research and development but if we have not got a solid base of knowledge or infrastructure on the ground in Australia that really promotes knowledge amongst children and communities right around the country, it makes it very hard for us to establish that base. There has been quite a significant amount of research done to show the relationship between that base knowledge in the community and participation with technology, and the ability of a country to expand in a particular field.

BREAK.PARA: With respect to this institution, not only do they manage to run their programs with proportionately less funding than every other major institution, but they manage to do it in a way where they actually take the issues to the people. They set some great examples about how national institutions can run in an inclusive and participatory way, in a way that really brings together and involves just about every aspect of our community.

If you have not visited Questacon during your visits to the ACT, may I suggest you take the time, as it is a very innovative place, full of interest. Everyone who attends there really reaps significant benefit from having a look and participating in the hands‐on science and technology exhibits that are a feature of the institution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to speak on the 1995‐96 annual report of the National Science and Technology Centre. For most of the time covered by this report I have to confess that I had the privilege of being the minister for science. Therefore, the balance of this report covers my period of office. I would like to, first, pay a tribute to the people at the National Science and Technology Centre. They are a fine example of Australian scientists taking the scientific message to the community and encouraging a greater awareness of science in the broad Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: In science circles there is a bit of a fear of the image science has. The belief is that science is not seen as an attractive area for Australian students to seek degrees in, or for graduates to do postgraduate or doctoral research in. The belief broadly is that science has a threatening, almost science fiction type image, in which scientists are seen as the bad guys rather than the good guys helping society overcome problems and finding answers to complex issues. So the National Science and Technology Centre does, as Senator Lundy has so capably described, take the message of science to the community and provides a series of exhibits and other facilities for people to become used to dealing with issues of science at the centre.

The situation for Australia is roughly this: we create every year between one per cent and three per cent of all the new knowledge discovered in science in the world. That means that our ability to create new knowledge is well ahead of our population as a percentage of the global population and well ahead of our GDP as a percentage of global GDP. We now have nine Nobel Prize winners in Australia which also means that per head of population, or as a percentage of our GDP, measures by which you would assess Australia's standing in the world, we are well ahead of most other countries in the world. We are essentially a very creative country. The trouble for us in this country is that as we sell our commodities like wheat, wool, iron ore and coal in the most unimproved form in the world—we sell them as base commodities at the lowest price and, therefore, get the least return—so too does Australia sell its intellectual property.

Our scientists create this knowledge but other economies take their creations and turn them into developed products which they sell back to us. We have seen a syndrome in Australia of our creative community in the science sector coming up with new ideas and trying to commercialise those ideas only to find there is a lack of interest in the financial sector or hurdles put in the way of commercialisation that make it impossible or very difficult within this country.

Someone else comes along and buys that intellectual property, turns that intellectual property into a commodity, a good or a service, and we then participate in the world market buying it back. The issue for the previous government was how you build on and strengthen the creative base of Australian science so that we continue to be a site for creativity and intellectual property creation, and then put in place the various steps necessary to take that intellectual property to the market by commercialising it. That was the fundamental core of the innovation statement brought down by the Keating government in December last year. It put a series of steps down so we could value add to the intellectual property we create.

Until we start doing that more effectively there will always be a situation where science is not understood in the community because its end purpose is not seen or valued. There is a problem that science enrolments at university are falling—that is a global trend. There is a problem as well with the drop‐out rate of those enrolled. That is also a global trend.

The National Science and Technology Centre, by sparking the imagination of young Australians about the potential of science, is aimed at arresting and turning around that trend. They do a very good job of it. I commend them. I wish there was more of it and I hope the now government continues to fund this centre and the budget for science awareness in Australia, to support things like the ANZAAS conference and to encourage the young Helix club of the CSIRO to bring young students into the science realm, and to do all those things to promote science understanding in Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Institute of Marine Science is located at Cape Ferguson on a 207 hectare site just 50 miles south of Townsville where I have my electorate office, and also in the Dampier‐Karratha region of north west Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Marine industries are worth some $35 billion annually to Australia and these have been growing at eight per cent per year. The need for ensuring the natural system is protected and managed for sustainable development is quite evident. I was interested to hear Senator Cook's speech on the previous report and I concur with a lot of what he said about Australia's pre‐eminence in science.

The Australian Institute of Marine Science—AIMS—has established itself in strategic basic marine science and is supported by both public and private sector interests. The institute recently restructured its three science programs into 12 projects of national significance, removed a layer of management by abolishing program level management and introduced a formal system of project evaluation.

As well, the institute has conducted a voluntary redundancy scheme to enable efficiency gains through restructure of support sections, shifted the budget towards increased support for capital and maintenance and upgraded its computer systems to allow a modern management information system to be introduced during 1996 and 1997.

The institute has built very strong links with Australian industries, particularly in the petroleum, pharmaceutical and computer technology industries and the wider Asia‐Pacific region. It has established a long‐term environmental monitoring program and it has built skills, knowledge and resource assessment, especially in tropical mangrove and coral reef systems.

AIMS is a recognised leader in setting environmental assessment standards. The effectiveness of the improved links with industry, which I mentioned previously, were reflected in the level of the institute's external earnings. In the term of this report, the external earnings of the institute were some $4½ million. I am personally aware of a number of the people who work at AIMS and of the tremendous work they do and the income they earn for Australia in their science works and in their collaboration with private drug companies in particular, and this is good.

I do, however, note with just a fraction of concern the National Commission of Audit which reported in June of this year recommending a range of reviews by the government of its objectives and justification for all programs and services. In particular, the commission noted that a plethora of Commonwealth government science and technology programs were inefficient, unaccountable and complicated. The report concluded that there was considerable scope for rationalisation, improved efficiency and achievement of more targeted outcomes.

In the Townsville community there is a concern that this may mean that AIMS is somehow joined with CSIRO and loses its independence and its independent function. There is no factual basis for that at this time, but there is that feeling around scientific, academic and business circles in Townsville that this might happen. From the comments that have been made to me by the people at AIMS—and I do not profess to be in any way an expert in this area—I share this concern about a move which may be detrimental to the whole system of science agencies in Australia.

I know the member for Herbert, Mr Peter Lindsay, has also been approached. Whilst it would be improper for me to say he shares my concerns, because that is for him to say, I know that he is following this matter as well. Obviously, as well we have spoken to the relevant ministers and no decision has been made; it is part of a long‐term process.

I thought this was an appropriate time, while discussing this report, to place on record the great work that AIMS does as an independent scientific organisation. Until I can be convinced that some other form of structure would be beneficial, I remain a very strong and firm supporter of AIMS as an independent scientific organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I sought leave to continue my remarks on AIMS earlier. But now that it has been addressed, I seek leave to speak to that paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too regard AIMS as one of the premier science research establishments in Australia and their annual report now before the chamber covers the period in which I too was mostly the minister; but I acknowledge that, of course, it is the prerogative of the current government to sign off the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I relate to many of the things the previous speaker said. We are well served by AIMS; it is in many senses a classic science research institute which delivers a high quality product for Australia and is overshadowed, to some extent, by its bigger brother, the CSIRO. Nonetheless, nothing can detract from its work. It is well known in the fields of research associated with the Great Barrier Reef, fisheries, offshore management of the marine environment and whole areas of other research that it conducts which is globally recognised as being of world quality. It is seen as an agency to which other agencies in the world turn for particular information, particularly tropical marine environments as well other marine environments.

The agency is chaired by a board of which Professor Peter Andrews is the chairman, joined by Dr Meryl Williams, Mr Malcolm Kinnaird, Dr Ray George and Mr Geoff Hill. It is a board with a blend of scientific expertise and commercial understanding. AIMS has come up with a number of scientific breakthroughs which, if taken to commerciality, will benefit Australian science and give a return to this nation. Getting the right balance between research and discovery and getting the commercial advantages out of that for this nation is something that AIMS is very serious about. Its external earnings reflect its success in that regard. This board is balanced to achieve that result. I think all of them should be commended. In particular, I would like to commend the Director of AIMS, Dr Russell Reichelt. He is indeed a fine example of one of Australia's leading scientists.

The challenge for AIMS is not only to maintain and continue its fine reputation, something I am sure it will do, but to look to the future and see what the challenges are for an institute like this. In September 1994, as a consequence of a decision of the United Nations, the territory of Australia was enlarged by 150 per cent—that is, the exclusive economic zone for Australia meant that our seabed boundary was extended from the three‐mile limit to 200 nautical miles from the low tide mark or the edge of the continental shelf, whichever is the farthest.

For a continent like Australia, which stretches across many latitudes and, when you consider our island territories as well, covers climatic conditions ranging from tropical to Antarctic and all sea conditions and sub‐sea surfaces that could be imagined, this is a massive challenge. Australia now ranks as the second largest country in the world in terms of its offshore marine responsibilities.

Under the law of the sea, the requirement is that nations have access to the resources— that is, the living organisms in the water column as well as seabed resources and surface rights—if they exploit them to a sustainable level. In order to know what a sustainable level is, baseline studies need to be conducted to work out what the current level is and what sustainability looks like. If we do not exploit those resources to sustainability, some other nation can do so under the terms of this treaty.

What is in Australia's national interest is to employ the expertise of an agency like AIMS, which would be the leading agency in scientific research in this field in Australia, to work with the states and the Commonwealth, and other scientific agencies such as the Oceanography Division of the CSIRO, to commence a series of baseline studies so that we can be clear as to what the sustainability of Australia's marine environment might be. That means if we are challenged about our rights to exploit resources, living and mineral, hydrocarbon or whatever, we are able to produce the definitive argument as to what sustainability is.

I think AIMS can do that job. It is the agency that should lead in that job. I know the government is moving towards setting up that inquiry. I commend AIMS as being the body that can carry it through.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Industrial Chemicals Notification and Assessment Scheme

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate
