INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 pm, the time for consideration of government documents has concluded. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that I wish to raise this evening in the adjournment debate is the question of certain legal aid guidelines that applied in Tasmania in relation to the capacity of certain people to get aid in certain circumstances. As a result of the former government's so‐called access to justice program, a guideline was developed whereby women would be provided with assistance to institute property settlement proceedings where the principal asset of the marriage was equity in the former matrimonial home of between $30,000 and $60,000. Another guideline provided for assistance to women to obtain the return of furniture and chattels.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no objection to those guidelines as such, other than that they were framed in a blatantly sexist way. Under those guidelines a husband and wife could be in exactly the same financial position, seeking legal aid to fight or argue over property, and the Legal Aid Commission could say to the wife, `You're a woman, we will fund you', but to the man, `Because you're a male, we won't fund you.' I thought that was grossly unjust and grossly inappropriate. Indeed, I would suggest that that is political correctness gone mad.

As a result, I raised it at Senate estimates committee with the Attorney-General's Department. They then considered the guideline and provided me with an answer just a day or so ago, indicating that they thought the guideline was in breach of anti‐discrimination legislation. It would be fair to say that, if it were couched in non-sexist terms, this particular guideline would undoubtedly favour 95 per cent women and five per cent men. That would be appropriate, because it would be fair to say that in these sorts of disputes the majority of people who do not have the funding to pursue such claims are women. However, to couch the guidelines in such a sexist way was inappropriate. I am glad that I have been fortified in that view by the Attorney-General's Department which, as a result, will be writing to the Legal Aid Commission in Tasmania about that.

What this issue highlights is that the former government, in trying to be so politically correct, unfortunately created injustice and alienated people within the community by having such guidelines. The chances are that they were well intentioned, but it was political correctness gone mad which had an impact of creating this injustice.

I would not have raised this matter this evening but for some of the gratuitous comments made by the director of legal aid concerning me. In making these comments, I did not in any way refer to anybody in particular or seek to identify or embarrass anybody in particular. Unfortunately, the director of legal aid in Tasmania made some gratuitous comments, such as, `We have heard nothing from Senator Abetz about legal aid funding in Tasmania.'

For the record, let me say that Mr Colin Brown has been in my office. We have discussed the very issue of legal aid funding in Tasmania. Further, as chair of the government members committee on Attorney-General and justice matters, I was involved in an extensive campaign to assist the community legal centres to ensure that they were quarantined as much as possible from the government cutbacks that were necessary because of the previous mismanagement of our economy by Labor. I have received many letters of thanks from those community legal centres right around Australia for my involvement. So it is somewhat incongruous for the director of legal aid to have made those sorts of comments.

Let me also say that the director of legal aid gave me what I believe to be a very fruitful avenue of inquiry to try to save money in the Attorney-General's Department and thus free up extra money for legal aid. In fact, anybody who is interested can have a look at the Hansard of the Senate estimates committee where I followed up a number of questions and suggestions put to me by the director of legal aid in Tasmania as to how moneys might be saved. I find it somewhat unfortunate that Mr Brown has found it necessary to make those comments in the media, which I think most people would see as a cheap, political shot, when he was unable to deal with the substance of the complaint.

Having said that, I look forward to ongoing, meaningful discussions with Mr Colin Brown, the director of legal aid in Tasmania. I look forward to him providing me with further suggestions as to how savings can be made in the Attorney General's Department. He can be assured that I will continue to follow them up at estimates or with the minister or directly with the Attorney‐General.

I wanted to place on record a response to those comments by the director of legal aid and also remind those who are administering schemes such as legal aid that they have to be careful no matter how well intentioned they may be to try to couch the guidelines so that they are fair to everybody and not alienate what could be potentially a large section of the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about the remarks that Senator Abetz has made. He has raised the issue of how legal aid is expended and the guidelines by which they are expended. He mentioned Tasmania, the state from which he comes.
—A great state.

—A very great state, because that was where I was born. He has said that the former government created injustice and that their adherence to political correctness was one of the means by which they did that. I think Senator Abetz raises a very big issue, and that is the issue of how we run our legal system, how we run that arm of government which is dealt with in chapter 3 of the constitution—that is, the judicial arm of government.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is not so much a previous government's adherence to political correctness but the fact that proper funding has not been put into this area. Fortunately, Senator McKiernan has decided to have an inquiry, and the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee is presently preparing to hold public hearings into this.Senator Abetz is on that committee and no doubt he will make his usual great contribution to it. It would be a good thing if we waited until that inquiry was held before we came to conclusions about whether guidelines are correct or where the problems lie.

Last Thursday the Senate voted against a motion of disallowance which referred to the increase in fees in the Commonwealth courts. This is a related issue because it deals with the question of how we are going to finance our judicial system, our legal system. Unfortunately, much of the debate centred around the question of whether or not it ought to be user pays. In the end, the Senate came down very largely on the side that the users should pay in this area.

It seems to me extraordinary that one of the core functions of government should be approached on the basis that the people who are going to have access to that core function have to pay for it. The other core functions are the government itself, the administration of the Commonwealth, and the legislature. It seems to me to be extraordinary that at least one arm of that is looked at in terms of value for money. In that context, there is an article in the New Statesman & Society magazine of 8 December 1995 which has a bit to say about the attitudes and the way in which we run society. It states:

The arguments about values are disingenuous; calculated to conceal what has become obvious to all over the past 20 years—that monetary values have superseded all others, and that the sublimest expression of idealism, hope and high moral purpose in the world now is "value for money": if money has become the supreme measure of value, why should those who have been so happy to underwrite this development complain?

That perhaps sums up the sorts of presumptions and suppositions that too many people are making about the legal system. Instead of facing the need to make the system fair, just and available, we look for excuses for not so making it. The excuses include the following propositions: that injustice is brought about because the former government adhered to what is said was political correctness; that the guidelines in Tasmania are the problem; and that everything is the problem, except the fact that there ought to be adequate resources devoted to this arm of government so that it can work properly.

May I say in passing that it is not only the judicial arm that is being starved of resources but also this very legislature. The facilities made available to people both in this place and in the other place are also being cut down. Having listened to the contribution made by Senator Abetz, it is proper that the true picture is raised; that is, a lot of work has to be done to make sure that everybody in the community, no matter how poor or how rich, has equal access to the law. Equal access to the law means not simply being represented by somebody but being represented by a person who is competent, who has time and who has the resources available to give to not only the richest but also the poorest and all those in between. That, unfortunately, is not happening now. I doubt very much whether anybody in this chamber at the moment could afford to run a case that went for any length of time, and that is a tragedy. It is a tragedy brought about—in part at least—by the corruptions of the values by which we live, which have occurred in recent times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, said yesterday in this place:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the weight of national and international scientific opinion is that there is no substantive evidence of adverse health and safety effects from radiofrequency emissions at typical levels.

What needs to be understood however is that very few studies in the so-called weight of national and international scientific opinion, which is the sort that is to be re-examined by the World Health Organisation, are relevant to the evaluation of radiofrequency exposure on the development of cancer in humans. These are not my words; they come from the International Commission on Non-Ionising Radiation Protection. The commission stated:

Most of the established biological effects of exposure to RF fields are consistent with responses to induced heating—thermal effects—resulting in rises in tissue or body temperature of greater than one degree Celsius. Most studies examined endpoints other than cancer, many examined physiological and thermoregulatory responses, effects on behaviour and on the induction of lense opacities (cataracts) and adverse reproductive outcomes following acute exposure to relatively high levels of radiofrequency fields.

The minister failed to point out yesterday that the current research is primarily about heat effects of radiation. The minister's words also deny the fact that a growing body of work does show adverse health effects. These denials are just like the denials which we heard and still hear from the tobacco industry, and which were once heard from the proponents of the asbestos industry. The government is using the defensive words of the telecommunications industry and yet accuses those of us who want to know what is really going on of having closed minds.

The government and industry are saying, `You have not yet proved that some children are getting leukaemia as a result of living close to a TV transmitter tower. You have not yet proved that brain tumours are the result of using mobile phones and you have not yet proved that the damage electromagnetic radiation has been shown to cause human cells has ramifications for human health.' If the telecommunications carriers and others were pharmaceutical manufacturers, they would be required to prove that their products were not harmful to human health. They would not expect the research to be done after millions of people had already used their product.

The telecommunications industry says we should be reassured because the technology meets Australian standards. A CSIRO report entitled `Radiofrequency radiation exposure standards in Australia and New Zealand: biological effects, part 1' raises concerns about potential adverse health effects of long‐ term, low‐level, chronic exposure to radiofrequency radiation.

It says some of the effects which have emerged include: promotion of cancer growth, including leukaemia, breast cancer and brain tumours; degenerative changes in the retina, cornea and iris of the eye; changes in brain chemistry and drug effectiveness; impaired learning and memory function. It also says extremely low levels of radiofrequency radiation—that is, thousands of times less than the safety limits given in the US and Australian standards—have promoted cancer and birth defects in animal experiments.

Studies have been done and are currently under way by independent researchers who do not have to adopt a defensive stand—studies which have been criticised by an industry which has a great deal to lose if the preliminary findings are any indication of what we might find.

Dr Peter French, head of immunology at St Vincents Hospital in Sydney, has commenced laboratory testing of human cell culture and found that electromagnetic radiation causes changes to genetic make‐up. Gene transcription—the way in which genes are activated to form different cell types—is affected by exposure. Some DNA expression is turned on and some is turned off by exposure to electromagnetic radiation. He has also found that proteinaceous water in the body in places such as the eyeballs and surrounding the brain is affected by electromagnetic radiation. Dr French says it is possible that headaches associated with mobile phones are likely to be caused by the exposure of blood vessels. He regards this as fundamental and important work, but I remind the Senate that there is presently no funding to continue his research.

Dr Bruce Hocking undertook an epidemiological study last year and found that, within four kilometres of a television transmitter tower in a residential area of Sydney, rates of childhood leukaemia were 60 per cent higher than in another area away from the tower, and mortality rates from the illness were 100 per cent higher. More work needs to be done to expand the study and look, for instance, at impacts on adults as well as children.

BREAK.PARA: The same researcher invited responses from mobile phone users who experienced effects from their use of mobile phones. More than 50 complained about a range of consistent symptoms, including headaches, numbness, aching jaw and hot spots in the head. For very many these symptoms disappeared when they stopped using their mobiles.

These studies do not prove that brain tumours are caused by mobile phones or mobile phone towers—very far from it. They merely alert us to the fact that we do not know. They say we must be cautious, we must adopt the precautionary principle and we must do more research—research which is independent, not research which merely confirms what the industry would hope to find.

I finish by noting the remarks of Senator Boswell this afternoon in the Telstra debate. He said, `I think that the Democrats are fools to have promoted recommendation No. 35 of the report of the inquiry, which proposes that a levy be raised from contributors responsible for electromagnetic radiation to finance independent research into public health issues concerning EMR.' Quite obviously, he has not caught up with Senator Alston's announcement yesterday that $4.5 million would pay for such research over the next four years and that it would be funded by increases on industry licences. I will see that Senator Boswell gets a copy of the press release shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In common with other senators in this place, I have the opportunity to have artworks from the Parliament House collection in my office. Some we choose; some we get because no‐one else wants them.

SPEECH.PARA: One painting that attracted my eye and my curiosity now hangs in my office. It is a painting of the right honourable Sir George Pearce by Dargie in original oil. I chose it originally because it was a pleasant painting, but on inquiring as to the background of this man, I was impressed to learn he had served in the Senate for 37 years. I thought he was an appropriate role model. I also learnt that he had held a number of positions, including chairman of committees. As I asked about him so often, my staff even put a short `biog' against the portrait.

Some weeks ago, my office received a phone call from the guide desk, advising that a granddaughter of Sir George Pearce was keen to view the portrait of her grandfather. Regrettably I was not here, but my staff met with Mr and Mrs Janet and Alan Righetti from Queensland and they learnt so much more about this famous Australian that I thought I would like to share it with other senators.

While it is true that Sir George Pearce did serve for 37 years and was a chairman of committees, he was so much more than that. I was particularly interested in the fact that he was a member of three political parties.

Sir George was one of 10 in a poor family, his father being a blacksmith in South Australia. His formal education finished at 12 years of age and he walked beside his horse with pick and shovel to Kalgoorlie from Perth to try his luck at the goldfields—obviously none too successfully, because he returned to Perth and started a 57‐hour a week job as an apprentice carpenter.

He rose through the trade union movement and was elected as a senator for Western Australia in the first federal government in 1901. He became defence minister in 1910 and, among other credits, founded the Royal Australian Navy. He was also defence minister during the First World War. He had a long interest in aviation being the first politician in Australia to use air travel to cover his vast electorate.

Before the First World War he set up a flying school at Point Cook in Victoria and in 1921 he brought the RAAF into existence. Other portfolios that Sir George held at the same time as his defence portfolio were external affairs and home territories. He was appointed a privy counsellor in 1921 and knighted in 1927. He retired from the Senate in 1938 and died in 1952, aged 82. In 1964, Sir Robert Menzies said about Sir George:

BREAK.PARA: In my opinion speaking about Cabinet, I have never sat in with an abler man than George Pearce. He was a man of extraordinary experience and he had great wisdom.
Sir Robert Menzies went on to say:
I look back on my good fortune to have sat in a cabinet with him for three years as one of the highs in my life.
This praise from a Liberal Prime Minister about a man who started his political career with the ALP—and then saw the light obviously—and left school at 12 years of age says something.

The Parliamentary Handbook lists his political affiliations as being firstly a member of the Labor Party, then a member of the National Party from 1917 and finally a member of the United Australia Party from 1931. Obviously, he was a great political survivor. I have always admired the portrait of the Rt Hon. Sir George Pearce. Now that I know more of his background I am even more pleased to have it in my office. I am also pleased that his granddaughter knows her grandfather has not been forgotten and that his portrait is not languishing in some basement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I pay tribute to Senator Brownhill for those comments even though I may not agree with everything he said. I note that the honourable past senator had been a trade union member. It is actually pleasing to hear someone on the other side recognise the worth and value of trade union members who end up in the Senate. They obviously make great contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to return to some of the issues I raised today in the Senate during the debate on matters of public interest which go to the question of political leadership and political integrity. Unfortunately, I was unable to finish my remarks due to the constant interruption of senators on the government side who were obviously most embarrassed about the revelations that I was bringing to the attention of the Senate relating to the infiltration of Liberal Party branches in southern Sydney by extreme right‐wing elements. In particular, I referred to newspaper reports emanating from more moderate members of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, including Liberal members of the state parliament. Those reports referred to the grave concerns they have about what was happening in their own branches.

I want to go back to refer to an article that was published in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, 27 July which dealt with this very serious issue. The Liberal Party hierarchy in New South Wales, at the pinnacle of which is none other than the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has really failed to do anything to curb this issue. The article states:
The man regarded as the leader of the young right‐wingers is a Sydney lawyer, John White, who was one of the unsuccessful candidates for preselection at Hughes.

Mr White had been involved in the stacking of the Menai branch where there was, and one could describe it as, a right‐wing almost neo‐fascist takeover. One of Mr White's colleagues was a chap by the name of Wade McInerney. The McInerney family are members of the Liberal Party. Wade's brother, Dallas McInerney, is rather notorious.

Dallas McInerney, as I am sure honourable senators will recall—and certainly members of the Liberal Party will recall—gained some notoriety during the last state election in New South Wales. Mr Dallas McInerney was on the staff of Chris Downy the Liberal member for Sutherland. He used the telephone in the member's office to make threatening phone calls to the owner of a pizza shop who, according to Mr McInerney, had made a terrible mistake of actually leasing premises to a then Labor candidate for the seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't for making bad pizzas?

—It was not for making bad pizzas. This gentleman happened to lease a shop to the Labor candidate so Mr McInerney took it upon himself to make threatening phone calls. He was arrested, charged and convicted of offences relevant to his action. That is an indication of the sorts of people who have been active in the Sutherland shire and southern Sydney branches of the Liberal Party.

BREAK.PARA: I also want to draw to the attention of the Senate what has been happening since that article was written. There was a further article in the Daily Telegraph on 31 August this year which revealed that branches of the Young Liberals in this region had put onto the Internet what could only be described as fascist or Nazi party propaganda. The Daily Telegraph article states:
The NSW Liberal Party has demanded its youth wing remove an Internet site that invites young computer users to read the views of extreme right‐wing groups, including Nazis.
The party has been embarrassed by the web site of the Young Liberals' Hughes‐Sutherland branch, which includes "Frequently Asked Questions" about the Nazi movement.
The site, set up by a small number of members in the southern Sydney branch, describes the Holocaust as an "unfortunate but understandable" event that result from "allied inflicted acts of war".

Up until 11.30am yesterday, visitors to the "links page" of the Sutherland‐Hughes Young Liberals web site would have found the Nazi site—along with "other interesting pages", such as the Prime Minister's Home Page.
By early afternoon, following inquiries by The Daily Telegraph , the Nazi "link" had been removed on the orders of Riley St headquarters.
That is the headquarters of the New South Wales Liberal Party. The article goes on:

Despite this intervention, intrepid Internet users could still gain access to the Nazi site late yesterday by clicking onto Queensland University of Technology Liberal Club (also listed on the Hughes‐Sutherland Young Liberals page).
The Queensland site contains a link to the same propaganda as well as a pointer to the extreme right‐wing League of Rights.
The Nazi site, compiled in the US, celebrates the "outstanding leadership" of Adolf Hitler and claims "no genocide" took place during World War II.

What we have here are some very extreme, dangerous young Liberals infiltrating the branches in the Sutherland shire and surrounding areas—only a stone's throw from the St George area where the Prime Minister lived for many years—and touting this type of absolute garbage, this revisionist history promulgated by the likes of David Irving and others. We have never really experienced the provision of this sort of information by major political parties before. This type of political propaganda has not been a feature of Australian politics in the past, except in very limited circumstances. Now we have seen examples of where, unfortunately in the Liberal Party, there are people who want to push this barrow.

I have to say that action was taken by the New South Wales branch officials to stop that. I think that is to be commended. It is unfortunate, particularly given the current climate of some of the political debate taking place in this country, such as the extremist views of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), that some people are allowed to put this type of propaganda over the Internet and through other official party organs of the Liberal Party. I believe it is the duty of the Prime Minister to stamp out this sort of thing, to do it at the outset—not to flounder around talking about the right to free expression and freedom of speech.

Today I heard ministers stand up and attack the Labor Party—the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, did so in response to a question from Senator Boswell—because we happen to have a reasonable percentage of our members of parliament with trade union backgrounds. They condemn individuals for the simple fact they happen to be trade union members. Trade unions around the world have been at the forefront of standing up for freedom and democracy. There are trade unions leaders even today putting their lives on the line in other countries for the right of workers to have democratic and collective representation. Fortunately, that has never had to happen in this country. I think it is about time the Prime Minister, leading ministers of the government and other members of the government stopped these sorts of disgraceful and disparaging attacks upon individuals and started to clean up the mess that certainly exists in some of the Liberal Party branches in New South Wales.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26 July 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will an assurance be given that new migrants who are unemployed and seeking work, but who are otherwise ineligible for monetary benefits, will not be denied access to labour market training programmes during their first 2 years in Australia.
(2) To which labour market programmes will those new migrants be able to have access.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Recent migrants who are not eligible for Social Security income support within their first two years of residence in Australia will continue until 1 December 1997 to be eligible for the following labour market programme assistance:

PARA.TAB: English language training element of the new Job Seeker Preparation and Support Programme;
Advanced English for Migrants Programme (AEMP);
National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition (NOOSR) Bridging Courses for Overseas Trained Professionals; and

financial assistance under the Job Seeker Preparation and Support Programme for travel and other expenses incurred when starting English language training, AEMP or NOOSR Bridging Courses for Overseas Trained Professionals.

ANSWER.PARA: With the introduction of the Government's reformed employment assistance arrangements on 1 December 1997 these migrants will be treated the same as other job seekers who are not eligible for Social Security income support. Recent migrants who wish to have higher level English language training after completing the 510 hours of English language training provided by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will retain eligibility for AEMP. Professional migrants will retain eligibility for NOOSR Bridging Courses for Overseas Trained Professionals.

Migrants most in need of assistance including refugees and humanitarian migrants will remain eligible for Social Security income support and will be eligible for the same range of labour market assistance as other disadvantaged job seekers who are in receipt of Social Security income support.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the 294 government ministerial staff positions referred to by the Minister in a question without notice on 9 May 1996 (House of Representatives Hansard , p751) all Members of Parliament (Staff) Act positions; if not, how many are Members of Parliament (Staff) (MOPS(S)) Act positions and what other positions make up this number.
(2) What is the breakdown of the different classifications in the 294 ministerial staffing positions; for example, senior adviser, adviser and assistant adviser.
(3) Are all government MOP(S) Act positions located in ministerial offices; if not, where else within the government or bureaucracy are people employed under MOP(S).
(4) How many Departmental Liaison Officers (DLOs) are working in ministerial offices (including those of parliamentary secretaries): (a) on a temporary basis; and (b) on a permanent basis.
(5) How many departmental staff other than DLOs are working in ministerial offices (including those of parliamentary secretaries): (a) on a temporary basis; and (b) on a permanent basis.

(6) How many consultants are employed in ministerial offices (including those of parliamentary secretaries): on a short‐time (contract under 6 months) basis; and (b) on a longer term (contract over 6 months) basis.
(7) Are there any staff working in ministerial offices who are not employed under the MOP(S) Act or by a government department; if so, how many are there and who is paying them.
(8) How many government ministerial staff (including those of parliamentary secretaries) are based in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: Consultant 1
Principal Adviser 5
Senior Adviser 40
Media Adviser 32
Adviser 80
Assistant Adviser 50
Clerk to Whip 7
Personal Secretary 79
(3) No. Staff are also employed in the offices of Parliamentary Secretaries, Whips, Leader of the National Party in the Senate, the Government Members' Secretariat and the Cabinet Policy Unit.

(4)(5)(7) These are questions which would need to be put to individual Ministers. In my case my Department has provided one DLO. Under the established arrangements, which also applied under the previous Government, when a personal staff member is absent on approved leave for periods of less than 12 weeks a Minister's home department is responsible for providing any relief required. There are no staff working in my office who are paid from other sources.

(8) As at 30 September 1996—177.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 16 September 1996.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What forms of Commonwealth or international recognition, such as National Estate listing and RAMSAR Convention listing, currently apply to the Creery wetlands area near Mandurah in Western Australia.
(2) What forms of Commonwealth or international recognition are being proposed or considered for the Creery wetlands area.
(3) What is the current involvement of the Australian Nature Conservation Agency (ANCA) in the Creery wetlands.
(4) What is the current status of the draft memorandum of understanding involving ANCA, the developer Cedar Woods Properties Limited, and the Western Australia Government.
(5) Is funding to be provided to assist in the acquisition of the Creery wetlands area; if not, why not.

(6) Is the Minister aware of the recently released `Inner Peel Regional Structure Plan', produced by the Western Australia Ministry for Planning, under which only about one‐third of the Creery wetlands would be protected.
(7) Will a submission be made to this plan now that it has been released for public comment.
(8) What action is the Minister currently engaged in, or considering, to further the Commonwealth's role in protecting this important wetland area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The privately owned property known as Creery wetland, lies adjacent to Creery Island in the Peel Inlet, which is part of an area listed as a Wetland of International Importance under the Ramsar Convention. None of the Creery property itself is included in the currently listed area. The Peel Inlet area is of major significance as habitat for migratory shorebirds listed for protection under Australia's bilateral migratory bird agreements with the Governments of Japan and China. The property is not on the Register of the National Estate.

(2)‐(3) With my agreement, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency has been involved in the drafting of a memorandum of understanding for the cooperative future management of the Creery site, in recognition of its high conservation values. This document provides for the permanent conservation of the most significant wetland portion of the site, and is being developed through discussions with the property owner, Cedar Woods Properties Limited, the Western Australian Government, and Mandurah City Council.
(4) The Commonwealth has provided comments on the draft memorandum of understanding, which is now with Cedar Woods Properties Limited for consideration.
(5) The Commonwealth does not propose to acquire the Creery wetlands site, and has been advised that the property is not currently for sale.
(6) Yes.
(7) Yes, a submission is being prepared by my portfolio.

(8) I am satisfied that an acceptable outcome for the protection of this important wetland can be achieved through the proposed cooperative management arrangement being finalised through the memorandum of understanding under discussion at present.
